(d)  Persons arrested for violations of the Code, when appropriate, may post a bond of not less than $100.00 for each violation. 
(e)  In addition to and supplemental to any other provision of this Code, the City shall be entitled, as a prevailing party, to recover reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in any legal proceeding brought by the City to enforce any provision of this Code through all appellate proceedings. 
(Code 1982, § 10.99; Ord. No. 03-1100, § 2, 9-22-03) 
Charter reference- Power of City to enforce ordinances, § 8(o). 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Form of government, City Commission, §§ 9-22; elections, Art. VII. 
Cross reference- Emergency management, Ch. 30; reimbursement for extraordinary expenses, § 30-51 et seq.; emergency services, Ch. 34; law enforcement, Ch. 54; personnel, Ch. 62; planning and development, Ch. 66; taxation, Ch. 78; utilities, Ch. 86; unified land development regulations, Part III. 
State Law reference- Formation of local governments, F.S. §§ 165.011-165.093. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Amendment of budget; exceeding budget. 
(a)  Any amendments, modifications or alterations of the annual City budget or of any rights and obligations of the City may be approved at any regular or special meeting of the City Commission by a resolution duly adopted by the affirmative vote of a majority of the City Commission so as to implement the appropriate expenditures of revenue. 
(b)  A record of all proceedings amending, modifying or altering an approved budget shall be prepared by the City Clerk at the regular or special meeting. This record shall be attached to the original annual budget resolution and become an original counterpart of the budget subject to inspection by the public and any other persons that are duly authorized to make inspection of the financial records of the City. 
(c)  No warrants or obligations against the City shall be drawn in excess of the appropriations made in accordance with the annual City budget. 
(Code 1982, § 30.02) 
Sec. 2-2. - Fee for dishonored checks presented to city. 
    The City shall collect, in addition to all other charges or penalties imposed by law, the service fee authorized under F.S. § 832.08(5) or five percent of the face amount of any check, draft or order, whichever is greater, for the collection of any dishonored check, draft or order presented for payment of money to the City. This service fee shall be in addition to all other penalties imposed by law. 
(Code 1982, § 130.07; Ord. No. 99-961, § I, 8-16-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.251. 
Sec. 2-3. - Planning. 
    The City Commission shall cause to be developed and adopt a comprehensive master plan to provide for the mapped definition of zoning ordinances and for the projected orderly growth of the municipality in a series of steps to achieve determined community growth and goals. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 65; Ord. No. 448, § 2, 1-11-82) 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 66; unified land development regulations, Part III. 
Sec. 2-4. - Zoning. 
    The City is vested with all powers set forth in the Florida Statutes with reference to municipal zoning. The City Commission shall cause to be prepared zoning ordinances, regulations, and maps, together with amendments thereto, if and when necessary. Zoning ordinances adopted shall, so far as possible, be related to the comprehensive master plan designed to provide for the orderly and desirable growth of the City. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 66; Ord. No. 448, § 2, 1-11-82) 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 66; unified land development regulations, Part III. 
Sec. 2-5. - Community redevelopment trust fund. 
(a)  There is hereby established and created in accordance with the provisions of the Act, a Community Redevelopment Trust Fund (the "fund") for the Community Redevelopment Area, which fund shall be utilized and expended for the purposes of, and in accordance with, the Plan, including any amendments or modifications thereto approved by the City Commission including any "community redevelopment," as that term is defined in F.S. § 163.340(9) under the Plan. 
(b)  The monies to be allocated to and deposited into the fund shall be used to finance "community redevelopment" within the Area according to tax increment revenues attributed to the Area, which shall be appropriated for the Agency. The Agency shall utilize the funds and revenues paid into, and earned by, the fund for community redevelopment purposes as provided in the Plan and as permitted by law. The fund shall exist for the duration of the "community redevelopment" undertaken by the agency pursuant to the Plan to the extent permitted by the Act. (Monies shall be held in the fund by the City for, and on behalf of, the Agency, and disbursed from the fund as provided by the Agency.) 
(c)  Commencing in the tax year 2000, there shall be paid into the fund each year by the City of Casselberry as the "taxing authority" as that term is defined in F.S. § 163.340(2), levying ad valorem taxes within the Community Redevelopment Area, a sum equal to 95 percent of the incremental increase in ad valorem taxes levied each year by the taxing authority, as calculated in accordance with Section 5 and the Act, based on the base tax year established in Section 4 (such annual sum being hereinafter referred to as the "tax increment.") 
(d)  The most recent tax roll used in connection with the taxation of property prior to the effective date of this Section shall be the preliminary assessment roll of taxable real property in Seminole County, Florida, prepared by the Property Appraiser of Seminole County, Florida, and filed with the Department of Revenue pursuant to F.S. § 193.1142, 1990, reflecting valuation of real property for purposes of ad valorem taxation as of January 1, 1995 (the "base year value"), and all deposits into the fund shall be in the amount of tax increment calculated as provided in Subsection (e), below, based upon increases in valuation of taxable real property from the base year value. 
(e)  The tax increment shall be determined and appropriated annually by the taxing authority and, commencing in the tax year 2000, shall be an amount equal to 95 percent of the differences between: 
(1)  That amount of ad valorem taxes levied each year by all taxing authorities on taxable real property within the geographic boundaries in the Community Redevelopment Area; and 
(2)  That amount of ad valorem taxes which would have been produced by the rate upon which the tax is levied each year by or for all taxing authorities, upon the total of the assessed value of the taxable real property in the Community Redevelopment Area as shown upon the assessment roll used in connection with the taxation of such property by all taxing authorities, prior to the effective date of this Section. 
(f)  The taxing authority shall annually appropriate to, and cause to be deposited in, the fund the tax increment determined pursuant to the Act and Subsection (e), above, at the beginning of each fiscal year thereof as provided in the Act. The obligation of the taxing authority to annually appropriate the tax increment for deposit in the fund shall commence immediately upon the effective date of this Section and continue to the extent permitted by the Act so long as any indebtedness pledging "increment revenue" has been paid. 
(g)  The fund shall be established and maintained as a separate trust fund by the Agency so that the fund may be promptly and effectively administered and utilized by the Agency expeditiously and without undue delay for its statutory purpose pursuant to the Plan. 
(h)  The governing body of the Agency shall be the trustees of the fund and shall be responsible for the receipt, custody, disbursement, accountability, management, investments and proper application of all monies paid into the fund. 
(i)  The potential consolidation of the Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency with other community redevelopment areas in a multi-jurisdictional Community Redevelopment Agency shall be optional with regard to the City of Casselberry. All documents of creation and implementation of the Community Redevelopment Agency shall provide for the contingent future transfer of any and all projects, programs, assets, property, funds, obligations and liabilities to Seminole County and/or a multi-jurisdictional or countywide Community Redevelopment Agency established by Seminole County; provided, however, that any funds on account at the time of termination, expiration or dissolution of the City of Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency that are not encumbered or pledged as security for any indebtedness shall be transferred to the City of Casselberry for use, as the City of Casselberry deems fit, within the proposed City of Casselberry Central City District; provided, further, however, that any real or personal property that has been purchased with Community Redevelopment Agency funds shall become the property of the City of Casselberry unless pledged or encumbered. 
(j)  As provided in Seminole County Resolution No. 98-R-181, commencing in the tax year 1998, 70 percent of the increment revenues derived by Seminole County for those properties located within the Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency's redevelopment area shall be appropriated by Seminole County and deposited in the Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency Trust Fund in accordance with F.S. § 163.387 (1997). Such increment revenues, when deposited into the Trust Fund, may be used by the Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency in a manner consistent with its redevelopment plan and with general law. Any such funds may be pledged as collateral for the repayment of bond revenues, consistent with F.S. ch. 163, pt. III (1997) and general law. This funding shall continue through the existing term of the Casselberry Redevelopment Plan. 
(Ord. No. 95-852, §§ 1-8, 12-11-95; Ord. No. 98-918, §§ I, II, 10-19-98; Ord. No. 00-981, § 1, 2, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 2-6. - Reimbursement of attorneys' fees and costs. 
(a)  Intent. As used in the balance of this Section, the words "successfully defend or prevail" shall apply to individual counts, charges and/or allegations, and shall mean the dismissal, the finding of not guilty, or a verdict in favor of the person covered herein as set forth in Subsection (c). A failure to successfully defend or prevail against one or more counts, charges or allegations shall not necessarily affect the application of this Section to other counts, charges and/or allegations which were successfully defended or against which the officer or employee prevailed. 
(b)  Definitions. "Reasonable attorney's fees" shall mean fees earned by an attorney and/or attorneys licensed to practice law in the State of Florida, based on the customary per hour rate charged in Seminole County, Florida, for similar work performed by attorneys within the county. 
(c)  Subject to Subsection (g), the City Commission shall, pursuant to the procedures set forth herein, reimburse present and former City Commissioners and City public officers, and their present and former employees and agents, including appointees of the Commission or such officers, for the reasonable attorney's fees and costs that such persons have incurred when they successfully defend or prevail in civil, criminal, and/or ethical investigations and/or actions that arise out of and in connection with their scope of city employment and city function, while acting in their official capacity, and while serving a public purpose. The City Commissioners shall determine if the attorney's fees and costs shall be reimbursed, and if so, in what amount. 
(d)  Any person who believes that he or she is allowed or entitled to payment for reasonable attorney's fees and costs pursuant to the provisions of this Section shall file within 30 days of conclusion of the matter a written request for such fees and costs with the City Attorney, which request shall at the minimum state: 
(1)  The name and current address of the person making the request; 
(2)  A description of the entity conducting the investigation or proceeding; 
(3)  The case number or file number of the investigation or proceeding, if known; 
(4)  A description of each count, charge and/or allegation made or being investigated; 
(5)  The date(s) of the occurrence(s); 
(6)  The person's office or position of employment with the City on the dates described in Subsection (5) above; 
(7)  A narration of the reasons why such person believes that the request meets the criteria set forth in this Section and that his or her attorney's fees and costs should be reimbursed by the City; 
(8)  The name(s), address, and telephone number of the attorney(s) representing such person against the counts, charges, and/or allegations described in Subsection (4) above; 
(9)  A description of the fee arrangement or agreement between the person and his or her attorney(s); the amount of attorney's fees and costs paid to the date of the written request for attorney's fees and costs for defense against the counts, charges, and/or allegations described in Subsection (4) above; and the total balance due, if any, of all attorney's fees and costs that have been incurred in defense against the counts, charges, and/or allegations described in Subsection (4) above; and 
(10)  Such other information as the City Commissioners and/or the City Attorney's Office may reasonably require. 
(e)  Within a reasonable time following receipt of the written request for payment of attorney's fees and costs, the City Attorney, in conjunction with the Mayor and City Manager, shall prepare and present an agenda item for consideration by the City Commission. In the agenda item for the Commission's consideration, the City Attorney shall include a recommendation on the applicability of this Section to the request for payment of attorney's fees and costs. The Commission may: (1) request additional relevant information from the applicant; (2) continue the request to a date and time certain; or (3) take action upon the written request and determine if the attorney's fees and costs shall be reimbursed, and if so, in what amount. 
(f)  Upon receipt of the written request, the City Attorney shall also communicate with the City's "insurance" providers to determine and advise the Commission whether such "insurance" providers will indemnify the City for any attorney's fees and costs incurred by the applicant in defense against such counts, charges, or allegations. 
(g)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary stated or implied herein, this Section does not address or pertain to recall proceedings or to employee discipline or termination proceedings. In the event such recall, discipline or termination proceedings occur concurrently with the issues and/or proceedings described above, such recall, discipline or termination proceedings shall not affect the application of this Section to the above described non-recall, non-discipline or non-termination issues or proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 03-1101, §§ 1-7, 10-13-03) 
Cross reference- General penalty, attorney's fees and § 1-13. 
Secs. 2-7-2-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COMMISSION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Authority and duties of City Commission regarding planning and zoning, § 66-31. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-35. - Election procedures. 
(a)  Generally. Pursuant to Section 37 of the City Charter, the City Commission hereby provides for election procedures to ensure the secrecy of the ballot and integrity of the poll for all city elections. 
(b)  Conduct of elections. The City Clerk shall coordinate the conduct of all city elections with the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections. All city elections shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(c)  Printing of ballots. The City Clerk shall coordinate the printing of ballots for any city election with the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(d)  Absentee procedures. The City Clerk shall coordinate absentee ballot procedures with the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(e)  Canvass of returns. The Seminole County Canvassing Board shall canvass the returns of all city elections, in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(f)  Electronic filing of campaign finance reports required. All candidates for elected office in the City of Casselberry shall electronically file their campaign treasurer's reports required by State law utilizing the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections Office's electronic filing system. 
(Ord. No. 08-1248, § 2, 7-28-08; Ord. No. 09-1308, § 1, 12-14-09; Ord. No. 13-1399, § I, 12-9-13) 
Sec. 2-36. - Election of members of city commission. 
(a)  Generally. Candidates for the office of City Commission seats 1 through 5 inclusive shall file, qualify and run at large for a specifically numbered seat, and shall be elected to office by a majority of the votes cast for that seat in the election. 
(b)  Run-off election; unopposed candidates. 
(1)  The candidate for any office receiving the majority of votes cast shall be elected. If there should be more than two candidates for any office and no one candidate receives a majority of the votes cast in the municipal election held pursuant to Section 31 of the City Charter, or in the event of a tie vote, then the two candidates receiving the highest votes in the first election shall run again in a run-off election to be held on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November. The run-off election shall be held in the same manner as the prior election. The candidate receiving the majority of the votes cast at such run-off election shall be elected. In the event of a tie vote at the run-off election, the tie will be dissolved by a lottery pursuant to state statute. 
(2)  If not more than one person is qualified as a candidate for any particular office, the unopposed candidate for that office shall not appear on the general election ballot, and each unopposed candidate shall be deemed to have voted for himself. If no eligible office draws opposed candidates in a particular election, then no election shall be held. The nonopposed candidate shall be certified elected and take office in accordance with the requirements of the Charter and general law on the date candidates in a contested election would be certified and take office. 
(Code 1982, §§ 30.05, 30.06; Ord. No. 08-1248, § 1, 7-28-08) 
State Law reference- Election, campaign and voting regulations, F.S. § 97.011 et seq. 
Sec. 2-37. - Vacancy in candidacy for city commission. 
(a)  Special election; supplemental qualifying period. 
(1)  If the death, withdrawal or removal from the ballot of a qualified City Commission candidate following the end of the qualifying period results in only one candidate or no candidate remaining for that office, a special election shall be scheduled by the City Commission not less than 60 days and not more than 120 days after the vacancy in the candidacy has occurred. 
(2)  A supplemental qualifying period shall be established beginning on the day the vacancy in the candidacy has occurred and ending at noon on the 46th day prior to the date of the special election. Any candidate wishing to qualify during this supplemental qualifying period shall comply with the requirements of Section 36 of the City Charter prior to the end of the supplemental qualifying period. 
(3)  The one candidate remaining for the seat shall not be required to requalify for election. The remaining candidate shall not be declared an unopposed candidate under F.S. ch. 106 unless no additional candidate qualifies for election during the supplemental qualifying period. The remaining candidate may continue to accept contributions until declared unopposed. If the remaining candidate is declared unopposed pursuant to this Section, the remaining candidate shall be declared elected and the special election shall be canceled. 
(b)  Filing of campaign expense statements. The filing of campaign expense statements pursuant to F.S. ch. 106 by candidates in a special election called under Subsection (a) of this Section, including the remaining candidate, shall not be later than such dates as fixed by the City Clerk. In fixing such dates, the City Clerk shall take into consideration and be governed by the practical time limitations and the dates established for such statements in a regular City election. 
(c)  Supplemental absentee ballots. If a special election is called pursuant to Subsection (a) of this Section and other candidates qualify for election during the supplemental qualifying period, supplemental absentee ballots for the special election shall be mailed to any absentee voter who was mailed an absentee ballot for the regular election. If an absentee voter returns the initial ballot that was mailed, the vote for the seat for which the special election was called will be null and void, but the votes on all other offices and issues shall be counted. 
(d)  Removal of names from ballot. The name of any qualified candidate who has died, withdrawn or been removed from the ballot shall not be printed on the ballot. If the ballot cannot be changed, any votes for that candidate shall be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 699, § I, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 2-38. - Restrictions on authority of city commission. 
(a)  Appointment and removal of officers and employees. Neither the City Commission nor any of its members shall in any manner control or demand the appointment or removal of any City administrative officer or employee whom the City Manager or any subordinate of the City Manager is empowered to appoint, but the City Commission may express its views and fully and freely discuss with the City Manager anything pertaining to appointment and removal of such officers and employees. 
(b)  Interference with administration. Except for the purpose of inquiries and investigations under Section 13(4) of the Charter, the City Commission or its members shall deal with City officers and employees who are subject to the direction and supervision of the City Manager solely through the City Manager, and neither the City Commission nor its members shall give orders to any such officer or employee, either publicly or privately. 
(Ord. No. 725, § I, 12-16-91) 
Secs. 2-39-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LEGISLATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Minimum procedural requirements and prohibitions for adoption of ordinances and resolutions, F.S. §§ 166.041-166.0445. 

Sec. 2-51. - Passage of nonemergency and emergency ordinances by majority vote or by vote of four Commissioners. 
(a)  The City Commission may enact ordinances by majority vote at any regular meeting of the Commission. A proposed ordinance may be read by title, or in full, on at least two separate days and shall, at least ten days prior to adoption, be noticed once in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. The notice of proposed enactment shall state the date, time, and place of the meeting; the title or titles of proposed ordinances; and be posted in at least three public places. The notice shall also advise that interested parties may appear at the meeting and be heard with respect to the proposed ordinance. 
(b)  The City Commission may enact emergency ordinances by an affirmative vote of not less than four members of the Commission at any regular or special meeting of the Commission without compliance with the requirements of Subsection (a) of this Section. 
(c)  An emergency ordinance is defined as an ordinance to provide for the immediate preservation of the public peace, property, health, or safety or in the event of an emergency in the daily operation of City government. Ordinances appropriating money may be passed as emergency measures, but no measure to make a grant, renew, or extend a franchise or special privilege or to regulate the rate to be charged for its services by any public utility shall ever be passed as an emergency measure. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, §§ 39, 40; Laws of Fla. ch. 69-927, § 7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.041(3)(a), (b). 
Sec. 2-52. - Form of ordinances. 
    Every proposed ordinance shall be introduced in typewritten form and shall not contain more than one subject. This single subject shall be clearly stated in the title. Emergency ordinances shall be defined in the title by authority of the Commission. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 41; Laws of Fla. ch. 69-927, § 7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.041(2). 
Sec. 2-53. - Enacting clause. 
    The enacting clause of all ordinances shall be: "Be it enacted by the Commission of the City of Casselberry." 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 42; Laws of Fla. ch. 69-927, § 7) 
Sec. 2-54. - Effective date. 
    Every ordinance unless otherwise specified shall become effective ten days after passage. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 43; Laws of Fla. ch. 69-927, § 7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.041(4). 
Sec. 2-55. - Recording of ordinances. 
    Every ordinance shall be numbered consecutively. Upon enactment the ordinance shall be recorded in a book kept for that purpose and shall be authenticated by the signatures of the Mayor and the City Clerk. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 44; Laws of Fla. ch. 69-927, § 7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.041(5). 
Sec. 2-56. - Resolutions. 
    All proposed resolutions shall be introduced in typewritten, written, or printed forms at any regular or special meeting and shall embrace but one subject which shall be clearly stated in the title. Adoption of resolutions will require a majority vote of the City Commission. Resolutions shall become effective immediately upon passage. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1351, § 45; Laws of Fla. ch. 69-927, § 7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.041(2), (4). 
Sec. 2-57. - Powers of initiative and referendum. 
    The registered voters of the City of Casselberry shall have the right to initiate City ordinances in order to establish new ordinances and to amend or repeal, in whole or in part, existing ordinances by petition as follows: 
(1)  Sponsors of petition; affidavit. Any five registered voters of the City may commence initiative proceedings by filing with the City Clerk an affidavit stating they will constitute the sponsors of the petition and be responsible for circulating the petition and filing it in proper form, stating their names and addresses and specifying the address to which all notices to the sponsors are to be sent. All petitions shall be uniform in character and shall have printed or written thereon in the caption the name and address of the five registered voters of the City who shall constitute the sponsors of the petition. 
(2)  Submission of petition. The sponsors of the petition shall, prior to obtaining any signatures on the petition, file the text of the title, summary and proposed ordinance with the City Clerk, with the petition on which signatures will be affixed, and shall obtain the approval of the City Clerk of the form of the petition. The City Clerk shall complete a review of the sufficiency of the form of the petition, specifying, if the form is insufficient, the particulars wherein it is defective and notifying the sponsors of the approval or rejection of the form of the petition within ten days from the filing of the petition with the City Clerk. The title and summary of the substance of the proposed ordinance shall comply with F.S. § 101.161(l), or its successor provision. The petition form which shall be used for proposing an ordinance is attached hereto as Exhibit "A". 
(3)  Requirements for signing. The initiative petition shall be signed by registered voters of the City equal in number to at least fifteen percent of the total number of registered voters registered to vote at the last regular City election. The beginning date of any petition drive shall commence upon the date of approval by the City Clerk of the form on which signatures will be affixed, and said drive shall terminate six months after that date. In the event sufficient signatures are not acquired during that six month period, the petition shall be rendered null and void and none of the signatures may be carried over onto another identical or similar petition. The sponsors shall submit signed and dated forms with the current residential address of each petitioner. 
(4)  Affidavit of circulator. Each paper of a petition shall have attached to it when filed an affidavit executed by the person circulating it stating that he or she personally circulated the paper, the number of signatures thereon, that all the signatures were affixed in his or her presence, that he or she believes them to be the genuine signatures of the persons whose names they purport to be and that each signer had an opportunity before signing to read the full text of the proposed ordinance. 
(5)  Filing with the City Clerk. All papers comprising the petition shall be assembled and filed with the City Clerk as one instrument. Within five days after receipt of the petition, the City Clerk shall request the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections to verify the signatures thereon. The sponsors shall pay all fees as required by law for the verification of signatures by the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections. The Seminole County Supervisor of Elections shall verify the signatures on the petition within three weeks from receipt of the petition. 
(6)  City Commission consideration. Upon verification by the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections that the petition contains the required number of signatures, the City Clerk shall complete a certificate as to the petition's sufficiency, specifying, if it is insufficient, the particulars wherein it is defective and shall present the certificate to the City Commission at its next regular meeting. If the petition is determined to be sufficient by the City Commission, the City Commission shall consider the proposed ordinance pursuant to the requirements of F.S. § 166.041(3)(a), and take final action on the proposed ordinance within 60 days from receipt of the certification from the City Clerk. 
(7)  Certification by sponsors. If the City Commission rejects the proposed ordinance or passes it in a revised form, the sponsors may require that the proposed ordinance be submitted to a vote of the electors in its original form. When the proposed ordinance is to be submitted to a vote of the City, the sponsors shall certify that fact to the City Clerk within 20 days from the date of the final City Commission vote on the proposed ordinance. Upon receipt of said certification by the sponsors, the City Clerk shall present the certification to the City Commission at its next regular meeting. 
(8)  Scheduling for election. If the City Clerk receives the certification by the sponsors (see Subsection (7), above) from January 1 through May 1, the vote of the City on the proposed ordinance shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of the same calendar year. If the City Clerk receives the certification by the sponsors (see Subsection (7), above) from May 2 through December 31, the vote of the City on the proposed ordinance shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of the next calendar year. 
(9)  Proposed ordinance. The power to enact, amend or repeal an ordinance by initiative shall not include ordinances relating to administrative or judicial functions of City government, including but not limited to, budget, debt obligations, capital improvement programs, salaries of officers and employees, the levy and collection of taxes, and the rezoning of an individual parcel of land or as otherwise prohibited by law. Each proposed ordinance shall embrace but one subject and matters properly connected therewith. 
(10)  Authorization for amendment or repeal of existing ordinances. Proposed ordinances amending or repealing any existing ordinance or ordinances, in whole or in part, may be submitted to the City Commission by initiative petition as provided in this Section. 
(11)  Withdrawal of petition. The petition may be withdrawn at any time prior to the fifteenth day preceding the day scheduled for a vote of the City by filing with the City Clerk a request for withdrawal signed by at least three members of the petition sponsors. Upon the filing of such request, the petition shall have no further force or effect and all proceedings thereon shall be terminated. 
(12)  Effective date. Ordinances enacted under this Section shall become operative on the date specified therein, or, if not so specified, on January 1 of the succeeding year. 
(13)  Results of election. If a majority of the registered voters voting on the proposed ordinance vote in its favor, it shall be considered adopted upon certification of the election results and shall be treated in all respects in the same manner as ordinances adopted by the City Commission. If the provisions of two or more ordinances adopted or approved at the same election conflict, the ordinance receiving the highest affirmative votes shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 98-911, §§ 1, 2, 6-1-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 98-911, §§ 1 and 2, adopted June 1, 1998, repealed the former Section 2-57 and enacted a new Section as set out herein. The former Section 2-57 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 69-926, § 1. 
Secs. 2-58-2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- City Attorney, § 28. 
Cross reference- Coordinator of Emergency Services, § 30-5; authority; duties of Chief of Fire Department, § 42-3; powers of City Engineer and Police Chief regarding traffic control and engineering, § 82-39. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-81-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- City Manager, §§ 23-26. 

Sec. 2-101. - Appointment; qualifications. 
(a)  Appointment generally. The City Commission shall appoint a City Manager of the City government pursuant to Article V, Section 5.01, of the City Charter, who shall serve as the chief executive, administrative and enforcement officer of the City in accordance with the City Charter, ordinances, resolutions, and rules and regulations established by the Commission time to time. 
(b)  Eligibility of City officials. No elected City official shall be eligible for the position of City Manager during his term of office or for a period of two years from the expiration of the elected official's last term of office. 
(Ord. No. 696, art. I, 5-6-91; Ord. No. 12-1381, § 1, 10-22-12) 
Charter reference- Appointment of City Manager, § 23. 
Sec. 2-102. - Compensation. 
    The City Manager shall receive such salary or compensation as the Commission shall fix in the annual budget of the City, and the sum shall be payable to the City Manager at the same time as other employees of the City are paid. 
(Ord. No. 696, art. VI, 5-6-91) 
Sec. 2-103. - Influence of Manager by Commission members. 
(a)  The Commission shall not direct or request the City Manager, either individually or through its boards or committees, to appoint or remove any person, assistant to the City Manager or other subordinate from City office or City employment. The Commission members shall not coerce or attempt to coerce or influence the City Manager with respect to the award or rejection of contracts, the purchase of supplies or the fair and reasonable application of required bid procedures. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this Section shall be construed to prohibit the Commission, while in open session, from fully and freely discussing with the City Manager matters pertaining to appointment and removal of an officer of the City, contracts, purchases, bidding procedures and any and all City affairs. 
(Ord. No. 696, art. II, 5-6-91) 
Sec. 2-104. - Political involvement of Manager or designee. 
    Neither the City Manager nor his or her direct designee shall engage in any city, county, state or national political campaign or take any active part in securing or contributing funds toward the nomination or election of any candidate for election. 
(Ord. No. 696, art. III, 5-6-91) 
Sec. 2-105. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1381, § 2, adopted Oct. 22, 2012, repealed § 2-105, which pertained to removal of the city manager from office and derived from Ord. No. 696, art IV, adopted May 6, 1991, and Ord. No. 724, § I, adopted Dec. 16, 1991. 
Sec. 2-106. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  Powers. The City Manager shall be responsible to the City Commission for the proper administration of all affairs of the City, and to that end shall have the powers as provided in the Charter Section 5.04, and the following additional powers and duties: 
(1)  To act as conservator of the peace under the direction of the City Commission, to see that all laws and ordinances of the City are duly enforced, and to sue in the proper federal, state and county courts to ensure enforcement of all laws and ordinances of the City. 
(2)  To appoint officers not provided for by election. 
(3)  To supervise and direct the affairs of the City directly under his or her supervision, including all departments and divisions of City government, all contractual obligations of the City, and fulfillment of the performance of all City obligations under contract, the Charter, ordinances and other applicable law. The supervisory and investigative powers granted in this Subsection shall not extend to the legislative branch of the City government. 
(4)  To direct the maintenance and repair of all City property, buildings, furnishings and equipment. 
(b)  Duties. The City Manager shall be responsible to the City Commission for the proper direction, supervision and administration of all duties connected with City government, and to that end shall have the following specific duties: 
(1)  To investigate, evaluate and supervise existing and proposed organizational and administrative procedures of all City departments. 
(2)  To direct, supervise and implement new organizational and administrative procedures. 
(3)  To direct, supervise and administer the implementation of new procedures. 
(4)  To direct, supervise and administer all City departments in policy, budgetary and administrative matters. 
(5)  To direct, supervise and assist all departments in accomplishment of City functions. 
(6)  To prepare factual reports with specific recommendations based on statistical studies and surveys. 
(7)  To conduct special program studies and direct and supervise the establishment and implementation of all current policies adopted by the Commission. 
(8)  To handle all incoming and outgoing correspondence as assigned by the Commission. 
(9)  To supervise and direct agenda preparation, and to provide the Mayor the opportunity to review said agenda to ensure items previously requested publicly by the City Commission are included. 
(10)  To direct, supervise and administer all Commission activities with other governmental agencies. 
(11)  To attend all Commission meetings, conferences and work sessions and provide recommendations and assistance on all subjects under discussion and consideration. 
(12)  To receive, investigate and effect the timely resolution of all complaints concerning City functions. 
(13)  To administer and maintain the City human resources program. 
(14)  To direct and administer the City central purchasing procedure. 
(15)  To implement and administer all the City budgets. 
(16)  To direct, supervise and implement all policies formulated by the Commission. 
(17)  To prepare and submit to the Commission the annual City budgets and the reports required by Article V, Section 5.04, Subsection (5), of the City Charter. 
(18)  To keep the Commission advised at all times of the financial condition and needs of all departments of City government. 
(19)  To approve and submit for payment to the Commission all claims, allowances, bills and expenditures incurred under his control, direction or supervision. 
(20)  To devote his entire time to his duties as City Manager and be engaged in no other venture or enterprise. 
(21)  To perform all other duties assigned by the Commission. 
(22)  To perform such additional duties as shall be prescribed from time to time by the Charter or by ordinance or resolution of the City. 
(23)  To supervise and direct the scheduling of Commission meetings. 
(Ord. No. 696, art. V, 5-6-91; Ord. No. 06-1180, §§ 1, 2, 3-13-06; Ord. No. 12-1381, § 3, 10-22-12) 
Charter reference- Powers and duties of City Manager, § 26. 
Secs. 2-107-2-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- City Clerk, § 29. 

Sec. 2-116. - Custody. 
    The City Clerk is designated as the custodian of the minute books, ordinances and resolutions of the City, and these records shall remain at all times within the custody and control of the City Clerk. All of these records shall at all times be open for the inspection of any of the citizens of the City or their duly authorized representatives. 
(Code 1982, § 31.06) 
Secs. 2-117-2-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Civil Service Board, § 64. 
Cross reference- Occupational License Review Board, § 26-29; Civil Service Board, § 62-36 et seq.; Land Planning Agency, § 66-26 et seq.; Planning and Zoning Commission, § 66-56 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-136-2-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, adopted Mar. 1, 1999, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1982, §§ 33.41-33.50; Ord. No. 697, § III, 4-15-91. 
State Law reference- Code enforcement generally, F.S. § 162.01 et seq. 

Sec. 2-146. - Title of Division. 
    This Division shall be known and cited as the Code Enforcement Ordinance of the City. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99) 
Sec. 2-147. - Intent of Division. 
    It is the intent of this Division to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City by authorizing the creation of an administrative board with authority to impose administrative fines and other noncriminal penalties, to provide an equitable, expeditious, effective and inexpensive method of enforcing any codes and ordinances in force in the City where a pending or repeated violation continues to exist. 
    It is further the intent of this Division to provide the City Commission with the ability to appoint a Special Magistrate in addition to, or in place of, a Code Enforcement Board. To that end, a Special Magistrate shall have the same status as a Code Enforcement Board under this Division. References in this Division to an enforcement board shall include a Special Magistrate, if the context permits, except for Section 2-148, Board Membership. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 3, 1-13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.02. 
Sec. 2-148. - Board membership; appointment and removal of members; term of office; counsel. 
(a)  Membership; compensation of members. There is created a Code Enforcement Board of the City, which shall consist of seven members to be appointed by the City Commission. All members shall be residents of the City and shall serve without compensation. In addition, the City Commission may appoint one qualified elector of the City to serve as an alternate member, designating him/her as such. The alternate member shall only vote in the temporary absence or disability of any regular member or when a regular member is otherwise disqualified in a particular case, but in all other respects shall be subject to the same regulations as any other Board member, such as attendance requirements and term limits. 
(b)  Composition. Appointments shall be made on the basis of experience and interest in the subject matter jurisdiction of the Code Enforcement Board, in the sole discretion of the City Commission. The membership of the Board shall, whenever possible, include an architect, a businessperson, an engineer, a general contractor, a subcontractor and a Realtor. 
(c)  Term of office. Each appointment shall be made for a term of three years. A member may be reappointed upon approval of the City Commission. 
(d)  Removal of members; filling of vacancies. Members of the Board may be removed from office by the City Commission for good cause upon written charges and after public hearing. Any member who fails to attend two out of three consecutive meetings without cause and without prior approval of the chairman of the Board shall automatically forfeit his appointment, and the City Commission shall promptly fill the vacancy. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment by the City Commission for the unexpired term affected. 
(e)  Counsel. The City Attorney is designated as counsel to the Board, and shall assist the Board in the conduct of its hearings. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 05-1161, § 1, 6-27-05; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 4, 1-13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.05 
Sec. 2-149. - Special magistrate selection; qualifications; compensation; duties and powers; policies. 
(a)  Selection. If the City Commission chooses to appoint a Special Magistrate, a committee composed of the City Manager, the Building Official, City Attorney and the Community Development Director, shall solicit applications from persons willing to serve as special magistrate, shall interview and evaluate applicants, and shall make recommendations to the City Commission regarding the designation of a special magistrate under this subpart. 
(b)  Qualifications. Special Magistrates shall be members of the Florida Bar in good standing for five or more years. The Special Magistrate must demonstrate satisfactory knowledge of municipal law and the general procedures for enforcement of municipal codes, and must demonstrate a temperament suitable for the exercise of the quasi-judicial powers vested in each special magistrate 
(c)  Compensation. A special magistrate so designated shall be compensated as agreed upon by the Special Magistrate and the City Manager. 
(d)  Duties and powers. Special Magistrates shall have the same duties, powers, and limitation on powers as those conferred on the Board under this Article, as the context permits. 
(e)  Policies. 
(1)  Should the City Commission appoint a Special Magistrate, the City Attorney may attend the code enforcement hearings conducted by the Special Magistrate and represent the City staff in the presentation of cases, or the Code Enforcement Officer may present the cases, at the option of the Community Development Director. 
(2)  Hearings before a Special Magistrate shall be conducted as often as necessary. At any hearing, the Special Magistrate may set a future hearing date. All hearings before the Special Magistrate shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 13-1400, § 5, 1-13-14) 
Sec. 2-150. - Jurisdiction. 
    The Code Enforcement Board and the Special Magistrate shall have the jurisdiction and authority to hear and decide alleged violations of any ordinances or codes in force in the City. The jurisdiction of the Board and Special Magistrate shall not be exclusive. Any alleged violation of any codes or ordinances may be pursued by additional or supplemental means, including appropriate remedy in court, at the option of the administrative official whose responsibility it is to enforce that respective code or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 6, 1-13-14) 
Sec. 2-151. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the Code Enforcement Officer to initiate enforcement proceedings of the various codes and ordinances; however, no member of the Code Enforcement Board shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceedings. 
(b)  Except as provided in Subsections (c) and (d) of this Section, if a violation of a code or ordinance is found, the Code Enforcement Officer shall notify the violator and give him a reasonable time to correct the violation. If the violation continues beyond the time specified for correction, the Code Enforcement Officer shall notify the Board and request a hearing. The Board, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing, and written notice of the hearing shall be hand delivered or mailed as provided in Section 2-157. At the option of the Code Enforcement Board, notice may additionally be served by publication as provided in Section 2-157. If the violation is corrected and then recurs or if the violation is not corrected by the time specified for correction by the Code Enforcement Officer, the case may be presented to the Code Enforcement Board even if the violation has been corrected prior to the board hearing and the notice shall so state. 
(c)  If a repeat violation is found, the Code Enforcement Officer shall notify the violator but is not required to give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation. The Code Enforcement Officer, upon notifying the violator of a repeat violation, shall notify the Code Enforcement Board and request a hearing. The Code Enforcement Board, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing and shall provide notice pursuant to Section 2-157. The case may be presented to the Code Enforcement Board even if the repeat violation has been corrected prior to the Board hearing, and the notice shall so state. If the repeat violation has been corrected, the Code Enforcement Board retains the right to schedule a hearing to determine costs and impose the payment of reasonable enforcement fees upon the repeat violator. The repeat violator may choose to waive his or her rights to this hearing and pay said costs as determined by the Code Enforcement Board. For purposes of this Section, the term "repeat violation" means a violation of a provision of a code or ordinance by a person who has been previously found through a code enforcement board or any other quasi-judicial or judicial process, to have violated or who has admitted violating the same provision within five years prior to the violation, notwithstanding the violations occur at different locations. 
(d)  If the Code Enforcement Officer has reason to believe a violation or the condition causing the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the Code Enforcement Officer shall make reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the Code Enforcement Board and request a hearing. 
(e)  If the owner of property which is subject to an enforcement proceeding before the Code Enforcement Board or court transfers ownership of the property between the time the initial pleading or notice was served and the time of the hearing, such owner shall: 
(1)  Disclose, in writing, the existence and the nature of the proceeding to the prospective transferee. 
(2)  Deliver to the prospective transferee a copy of the pleadings, notices, and other materials relating to the code enforcement proceeding received by the transferor. 
(3)  Disclose, in writing, to the prospective transferee that the new owner will be responsible for compliance with the applicable code and with orders issued in the code enforcement proceeding. 
(4)  File a notice with the Code Enforcement Officer to the transfer of the property, with the identity and address of the new owner and copies of the disclosures made to the new owner, within five days after the date of the transfer. 
A failure to make the disclosures described in Subsections (1), (2), (3) and (4) above before the transfer creates a rebuttable presumption of fraud. If the property is transferred before the hearing, the proceeding shall not be dismissed, but the new owner shall be provided a reasonable period of time to correct the violation before the hearing is held. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 00-975, § 1, 2-7-00; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 7, 1-13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. §§ 162.04(5), 162.06. 
Sec. 2-152. - Conduct of hearings. 
(a)  Upon request of the Code Enforcement Officer, or at such other times as may be necessary, the chairperson of the Code Enforcement Board may call a hearing of the Board. A hearing also may be called upon written notice signed by at least three members of the Board. Notice of hearing shall be circulated to all members of the Board. Minutes shall be kept of all hearings of the Board, and all hearings and proceedings shall be open to the public. The City Manager, upon request of the City Commission, shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the Board for the proper performance of its duties. 
(b)  Special emergency meetings of the Board may be convened by the chairperson upon the giving of notice thereof to each of the other members of the Board. Written notice of a special emergency meeting shall be delivered at least 24 hours prior to convening the Board. 
(c)  Each case before the Board shall be presented by the Code Enforcement Officer, a member of the City's Administrative Staff or special counsel. If the City prevails in prosecuting a case before the Code Enforcement Board, it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in prosecuting the case before the Board, and such costs may be included in the lien authorized under Section 2-154(e). 
(d)  The Board shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. 
(e)  The Board shall take testimony from the Code Enforcement Officer, the alleged violator and all witnesses called before the Board. 
(f)  Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern all proceedings. Irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded, but all other evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs shall be admissible, whether or not that evidence would be technically admissible in a trial before the state courts. Any part of the evidence may be received in written form acceptable to the Board. 
(g)  Four members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the lawful performance of the duties of the Board at any meeting. 
(h)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the Board shall issue findings of fact based on the evidence of record and conclusions of law, and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with the evidence and the powers granted herein. 
(1)  The findings shall be by motion approved by a majority of those members present and voting, except that at least four members of the Board must vote in order for the action to be official. 
(2)  The Board's order shall be pronounced orally at the meeting, and shall be reduced to writing and mailed by regular U. S. Mail to the alleged violator. 
(3)  The order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date and that a fine may be imposed, and under the conditions specified in Section 2-154, the cost of repairs may be included along with the fine if the order is not complied with by said date. 
(4)  A certified copy of such order may be recorded in the public records of the county and shall constitute notice to any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest or assigns if the violation concerns real property, and the findings therein shall be binding upon the violator and, if the violation concerns real property, any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest or assigns. If an order is recorded in the public records pursuant to this Subsection and the order is complied with by the date specified in the order, the Code Enforcement Board shall issue an order acknowledging compliance that shall be recorded in the public records. A hearing is not required to issue such an order acknowledging compliance. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 8, 1-13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. §§ 162.07. 
Sec. 2-153. - Powers. 
    The Code Enforcement Board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings. 
(2)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings. Subpoenas may be served by the sheriff of the county or the Police Department of the City. 
(3)  Subpoena tangible evidence to its hearings. 
(4)  Take testimony under oath. 
(5)  Issue orders having the full force of law to command whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. 162.08. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1400, §§ 8, 9, adopted January 1, 2014, renumbered former §§ 2-151 and 2-153 as §§ 2-152 and 2-154, respectively. Thus, at the editor's discretion, former § 2-152 has been renumbered as § 2-153. 
Sec. 2-154. - Administrative fines and liens, costs of repair; and filing of liens. 
(a)  The Code Enforcement Board, upon notification by the Code Enforcement Officer that an order of the Code Enforcement Board has not been complied with by the set time or, upon finding that a repeat violation has been committed, may order the violator to pay a fine in an amount specified in this Section for each day the violation continues past the date set by the Code Enforcement Board for compliance, or, in the case of a repeat violation, for each day the repeat violation continues, beginning with the date the repeat violation is found to have occurred by the Code Enforcement Officer. In addition, if the violation is a violation described in Section 2-151(d), the board shall notify the City Commission, which may make all reasonable repairs which are required to bring the property into compliance and charge the violator with the reasonable cost of the repairs along with the fine imposed pursuant to this Section. 
(b)  A fine imposed pursuant to this Section shall not exceed $250 per day for a first violation and shall not exceed $500 per day for a repeat violation, and, in addition, may include all costs of repairs pursuant to Subsection (a). However, if the Code Enforcement Board finds the violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature, it may impose a fine not to exceed $5,000 per violation. 
(c)  In determining the amount of the fine, if any, the Code Enforcement Board shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The gravity of the violation; 
(2)  Any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation; and 
(3)  Any previous violations committed by the violator. 
(d)  The Code Enforcement Board may reduce a fine imposed pursuant to this Section. 
(e)  A certified copy of an order imposing a fine may be recorded in the public records of the county and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists and upon any other real or personal property owned by the violator. Upon petition to the circuit court, the order may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of this state, including levy against the personal property, but such order shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. A fine imposed pursuant to this Section shall continue to accrue until the violator comes into compliance or until judgment is rendered pursuant to this Section, whichever occurs first. A lien arising from a fine imposed pursuant to this Section runs in favor of the City council and the City may execute a satisfaction or release of lien entered pursuant to this Section. 
(f)  After three months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the Code Enforcement Board may authorize the City Attorney to foreclose on the lien or to sue to recover a money judgment for the amount of the lien plus any accrued interest. No lien created pursuant to the provisions of this Section may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under Section 4, Article X of the State Constitution. The money judgment provisions of this Section shall not apply to real property or personal property which is covered under Section 4(a), Article X of the State Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 00-975, § 2, 2-7-00; Ord. No. 00-1003, § 1, 2, 11-27-00; Ord. No. 13-1395, § 1, 8-12-13; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 9, 1-13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.09. 
Sec. 2-155. - Duration of lien. 
    No lien provided for under this Section shall continue for a period in excess of 20 years after the certified copy of an order imposing a fine has been recorded, unless within that time an action commenced in a court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to Section 2-154(f). In an action to foreclose on a lien or for a money judgment, the prevailing party is entitled to recover all costs, including a reasonable attorney's fee, that it incurs in the action. The City shall be entitled to collect all costs incurred in recording and satisfying a valid lien. The continuation of the lien affected by the commencement of the action shall not be good against creditors or subsequent purchasers for valuable consideration without notice, unless a notice of lis pendens is recorded. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 00-1003, § 3, 11-27-00; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 10, 1-13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.10. 
Sec. 2-156. - Appeals. 
    An aggrieved party, including the City, may appeal a final administrative order of the Code Enforcement Board to the circuit court. Such an appeal shall not be a hearing de novo, but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the Code Enforcement Board. An appeal shall be filed within 30 days of the execution of the order to be appealed. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.11. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1400, §§ 10, 11, adopted January 1, 2014, renumbered former §§ 2-154 and 2-157 as §§ 2-155 and 2-158, respectively. Thus, at the editor's discretion, former § 2-155 has been renumbered as § 2-156. 
Sec. 2-157. - Notices. 
(a)  All notices required in this Division shall be provided to the alleged violator by certified mail, return receipt requested; by hand delivery by the sheriff or law enforcement officer of the City Code Enforcement Officer, or other person designated by the City Commission; or by leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of residence with any person residing therein who is above 15 years of age and informing such person of the contents of the notice. In the case of commercial premises, leaving the notice with the manager or other person in charge. 
(b)  In addition to providing notice as set forth in Subsection (a) of this Section, at the option of the Code Enforcement Board, notice may also be served by publication or posting as follows: 
(1)  Such notice shall be published once during each week for four consecutive weeks, with four publications being sufficient, in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. The newspaper shall meet such requirements as are prescribed under F.S. ch. 50 for legal and official advertisements. 
(2)  Proof of publication shall be made as provided in F.S. §§ 50.041 and 50.051. 
(3)  In lieu of publication as described in Subsection (1) above, such notice may be posted for at least ten days in at least two locations, one of which shall be the property upon which the violation is alleged to exist and the other of which shall be at City Hall. Proof of posting shall be by affidavit of the person posting the notice, which affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted and the date and places of its posting. 
(4)  Notice by publication or posting may run concurrently with, or may follow, an attempt to provide notice by hand delivery or by mail as required under Subsection (a) of this Section. 
(c)  Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice as provided in Subsection (a) together with proof of publication or posting as provided in Subsection (1) shall be sufficient to show that the notice requirement, of this part has been met, without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received the notice. 
(Ord. No. 99-928, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 00-975, § 3, 2-7-00) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.11. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1400, §§ 10, 11, adopted January 1, 2014, renumbered former §§ 2-154 and 2-157 as §§ 2-155 and 2-158, respectively. Former § 155 was subsequently renumbered as § 2-156 at the editor's discretion. Thus, at the editor's discretion, former § 2-156 has been renumbered as § 2-157. 
Sec. 2-158. - Application for satisfaction or release of code enforcement liens. 
    Where a certified copy of an order imposing a penalty or fine, as described above in Section 2-154, has been recorded in the public records and has become a lien against the land and/or property of the violator/property owner, such violator/property owner may apply for a satisfaction or release of such lien as follows: 
(a)  Upon full payment by the violator/property owner/property owner of the fine or penalty imposed in accordance with this chapter, the City Manager or designee is hereby authorized to execute and record a satisfaction of lien. 
(b)  Upon request for a reduction or forgiveness of a fine or penalty imposed in accordance with this chapter, the violator/property owner shall submit a written application to the Community Development Director or designee. 
(c)  The application shall include, but may not be limited to the following: 
(1)  The code enforcement case number; 
(2)  The date upon which the violator/property owner brought the subject property into compliance with the City Code; 
(3)  The factual basis upon which the violator/property owner believes the application for reduction or forgiveness of the lien should be granted; 
(4)  The terms upon which the violator/property owner believes a satisfaction or release of lien should be granted; 
(5)  The reasons, if any, compliance was not obtained prior to the order of penalty or fine being recorded; 
(6)  The reduction in penalty or fine sought by the violator/property owner; 
(7)  Any other information which the violator/property owner deems pertinent to the request, including but not limited to the circumstances that exist which would warrant the reduction or forgiveness of the penalty or fine; and 
(8)  This application shall be executed under oath and sworn to in the presence of a notary public. 
(d)  The violator/property owner shall submit at the time of application payment to the City in the amount necessary to reimburse the City for its costs associated with recording the order imposing a penalty or fine and the requested satisfaction or release of lien. These costs are non-refundable, without regard for the final disposition of the application for satisfaction or release of lien. 
(e)  Upon receipt of the application for satisfaction or release of lien and payment provided above, the Fire Chief or designee shall confirm through the Code Enforcement Officer that the violation which resulted in the order imposing penalty or fine has been brought into compliance. If the violator/property owner has been brought into compliance and there is no current code violation upon the property in question, the Community Development Director or designee shall place the application upon the agenda of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the Code Enforcement Board for the City of Casselberry. 
(f)  At the hearing before the Code Enforcement Board, the Board shall review and consider the application for satisfaction or release of lien, provide the violator/property owner with an opportunity to address the Board regarding the application for satisfaction or release of lien, and to take the testimony of other interested parties, including but not limited to city staff. 
(g)  Upon review of the application and any testimony presented, the Code Enforcement Board shall recommend to the City Commission approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the application for satisfaction or release of lien. The Code Enforcement Board, in determining its recommendation, shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The gravity of the violation; 
(2)  The time in which it took the violator/property owner to come into compliance; 
(3)  The accrued amount of the code enforcement fine or lien; 
(4)  Any previous or subsequent code violations; 
(5)  Any financial hardship; and 
(6)  Any other mitigating circumstances which may warrant the reduction or satisfaction of the penalty or fine. 
(h)  After a recommendation has been rendered by the Code Enforcement Board, the Community Development Director or designee shall place the application for satisfaction or release of lien upon the agenda of the next regularly scheduled City Commission meeting. The City Commission may take action solely based upon the sworn application and recommendation of the code enforcement board, and information previously provided by the violator/property owner to the Code Enforcement Board, in considering the application for satisfaction or release of lien. 
(i)  The City Commission may approve, approve with conditions, or deny the application to satisfy or release the lien. If the City Commission approves the application to satisfy or release the lien and the approval is conditioned upon the violator/property owner paying a reduced penalty, fine, or any other condition, the satisfaction or release of lien shall not be prepared or recorded until the condition(s) placed by the Commission have been satisfied. 
(j)  The violator/property owner shall have 30 days in which to comply with the conditions imposed by the City Commission. Failure of the violator/property owner to comply will result in the automatic denial of the application for satisfaction or release of lien. 
(k)  If the application is denied or if the application is automatically denied due to the failure of the violator/property owner to comply with the conditions imposed by the City Commission, the violator/property owner shall thereafter be barred from applying for a subsequent reduction or forgiveness of the lien for a period of one year from the date of denial. During the one-year period, the lien may only be satisfied and released upon full payment of the fine or penalty imposed in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05-1157, § 2, 4-11-05; Ord. No. 13-1400, § 11, 1-13-14) 
Secs. 2-159-2-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 784, § 1, adopted Jan. 3, 1994, repealed the former Div. 3, "Leisure Services Advisory Board," which derived from Ord. No. 698, § I, adopted June 17, 1991. 

Sec. 2-166. - Established; purpose. 
    There is hereby created and established in the City a Parks and Recreation Advisory Board. The principal function of this advisory board is to advise and make recommendations to the City Commission on matters concerning park facilities and recreational activities. 
(Ord. No. 784, § 2, 1-3-94) 
Sec. 2-167. - Membership; term of office; appointment and removal of members. 
(a)  The Parks and Recreation Advisory Board shall consist of five members who shall be residents of the City and shall remain City residents for the duration of their membership on the Board. All members shall be appointed by the City Commission for staggered two year terms. In addition, the City Commission may appoint one City resident to serve as an alternate member, designating him/her as such. The alternate member shall only vote in the temporary absence or disability of any regular member or when a regular member is otherwise disqualified in a particular case, but in all other respects shall be subject to the same regulations as any other board member. 
(b)  The terms of all members appointed shall commence on February 1 and shall be for a period of two years. The City Commission shall make all appointments and shall fill all vacancies occurring on the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board. The City Commission may remove any member of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board for incompetency, corruption, misconduct, conflict of interest, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, or for unexcused absence from two out of three consecutive meetings of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board, or for other good and sufficient cause. 
(c)  Members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for such travel, mileage, and per diem expenses as may be authorized in advance by the City Commission. 
(d)  Those City residents eligible for membership on the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board shall apply to the City Clerk's office for consideration by the City Commission. Eligibility guidelines shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Expressed interest in parks and recreational facilities and a commitment to the beliefs and values of each. 
(2)  Expressed interest in recreational and cultural programs and activities, and a commitment to the beliefs and values of each. 
(3)  Evidence of sensitivity to the recreational and cultural needs and wishes of the community. 
(4)  Ability to work well with others. 
(5)  Good judgment and the ability to inspire the confidence, respect, and support of the total community. 
(6)  Availability to attend meetings and events. 
(Ord. No. 784, § 3, 1-3-94; Ord. No. 18-1475, § 1, 3-12-18) 
Sec. 2-168. - Meetings; officers; quorum. 
    The Parks and Recreation Advisory Board, as soon as practicable after its appointment and annually thereafter, shall meet and organize by electing one of its members chairman, and electing one of its members vice chairman, and appointing the Recreation Manager or his/her designee as Board Secretary, to serve at the pleasure of the Advisory Board until a successor is appointed. The Advisory Board shall meet thereafter at some designated place within the City upon some designated date in each month for the transaction of its business, and more often if necessary. A majority of the Advisory Board shall be necessary to constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. A smaller number may act only to adjourn meetings for lack of a quorum. The affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum shall be required to pass any action of the Advisory Board. 
(Ord. No. 784, § 4, 1-3-94; Ord. No. 18-1475, § 2, 3-12-18) 
Sec. 2-169. - Powers, duties, and responsibilities; assistance of City employees. 
(a)  The functions, powers, duties and responsibilities of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board shall be as follows: 
(1)  In conjunction with the Public Works Department, presentation of an annual report to the City Commission of the status of parks and recreational facilities within the City. This report is intended to include a survey and assessment of the needs for park facilities, recreational programs and activities, and cultural resources; an inventory of facilities and programs available during the previous year, status of programs and facilities being discussed and/or investigated by the Advisory Board, and recommendations by the Advisory Board for City Commission consideration of potential future facilities and programs to serve the citizens of the City. 
(2)  Encourage and facilitate opportunities for City residents to participate in recreational and cultural activities. 
(3)  Promote, encourage, and assist where appropriate in the development of City community and civic organizations sponsoring recreational and cultural activities. 
(4)  Support and facilitate the preservation and growth of the City's recreational, leisure, natural, and cultural resources. 
(5)  Stimulate greater governmental and public awareness and appreciation of the importance of park facilities and recreational programs in the City. 
(b)  In connection with its duties, the Advisory Board may request the City Commission to provide assistance in the form of City staff and other resources to facilitate the Advisory Board in its duties and responsibilities. The City Commission shall review any such requests, and refer any such requests to the City Manager where it feels such requests are appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 784, § 5, 1-3-94; Ord. No. 18-1475, § 3, 3-12-18) 
Secs. 2-170-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT AGENCY 

Sec. 2-181. - Established. 
    The City Commission does hereby expressly authorize the Community Redevelopment Agency, pursuant, to F.S. § 163.356, which shall be a public body, corporate and politic, and constitute a public instrumentality. 
(Ord. No. 95-851, § 1, 12-11-95) 
Sec. 2-182. - Authority. 
    The City Commission does hereby expressly authorize the Community Redevelopment Agency to exercise all the powers conferred, and as limited, by F.S. ch. 163, pt. III, necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes of community redevelopment within the boundaries of the Community Redevelopment Area, more particularly described in Exhibit A, attached hereto by reference. 
(Ord. No. 95-851, § 2, 12-11-95) 
Sec. 2-183. - Board of agency commissioners. 
    A Board of Commissioners of the Community Redevelopment Agency (CRA) is established which shall consist of the governing body of the City of Casselberry (City Commission). The Mayor shall serve as Chairman of the Board of Commissioners of the Community Redevelopment Agency. 
(Ord. No. 95-851, § 3, 12-11-95; Ord. No. 98-917, § I, 10-19-98; Ord. No. 02-1048, § 1, 5-13-02; Ord. No. 15-1424, § 1, 4-13-15) 
Sec. 2-184. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-1424, § 2, adopted April 13, 2015, repealed § 2-183, which pertained to board of agency commissioners-terms of office; vacancies; reappointments. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-185. - Multi-jurisdictional Community Redevelopment Agency. 
    The potential consolidation of the Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency with other community redevelopment areas in a multi-jurisdictional Community Redevelopment Agency shall be optional with regard to the City of Casselberry. All documents of creation and implementation of the Community Redevelopment Agency shall provide for the contingent future transfer of any and all projects, programs, assets, property, funds, obligations and liabilities to Seminole County and/or a multi-jurisdictional or countywide Community Redevelopment Agency established by Seminole County; provided, however, that any funds on account at the time of termination, expiration or dissolution of the City of Casselberry Community Redevelopment Agency that are not encumbered or pledged as security for any indebtedness shall be transferred to the City of Casselberry for use, as the City of Casselberry deems fit, within the proposed City of Casselberry Central City District; provided, further, however, that any real or personal property that has been purchased with Community Redevelopment Agency funds shall become the property of the City of Casselberry unless pledged or encumbered. 
(Ord. No. 98-917, § II, 10-19-98) 
Secs. 2-186-2-200. - Reserved.
