(c)  There shall be imposed and levied by the City a tax upon purchase within the municipality of telecommunications service which originates and terminates in this state, at a rate not to exceed seven percent of the total amount charged for any telecommunications service provided within the municipality or, if the location of the telecommunications service cannot be determined, the total amount billed for such telecommunications service to a telephone or telephone number, a telecommunications number or device, or a customer's billing address located within a municipality, excluding public telephone charges collected on site, charges for any foreign exchange service or any private line service except when such services are used or sold as a substitute for any telephone company switched service or dedicated facility by which a telephone company provides a communication path, access charges, and any customer access lien charges paid to a local telephone company. However, telecommunications service as defined in F.S. § 203.012(5)(b) shall be taxed only on the monthly recurring customer service charges excluding variable usage charges. 
(d)  The tax shall be paid by the purchaser to the seller for the use of the City at the time of paying the charge for the service, but not less often than monthly. The seven percent or ten percent tax levied in this Section may be computed on the aggregate amount of sales during the monthly period; however, the amount of tax collection shall be calculated to the nearest whole cent. 
(Code 1982, § 95.01; Ord. No. 98-908, § I, 5-18-98) 
Sec. 78-27. - Exemptions. 
    The United States and the state, and all political subdivisions, agencies, boards, commissions and lawful authorities thereof, and entities of the board of public instruction are hereby exempt from the payment of the tax levied under Section 78-26. 
(Code 1982, § 95.02) 
Sec. 78-28. - Collection by seller; remittance to City. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), water service, telephone service and telegraph service within the City to collect from the purchaser for the use of the City the tax levied by this Article at the time of collecting the selling price charged for each transaction, and to report and pay over on or before the 15th day of each calendar month to the City all taxes levied and collected during the preceding month. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect for any service without at the same time collecting the tax levied by this Article, unless the seller elects to assume and pay the tax without collecting it from the purchaser. Any seller failing to collect the tax at the time of collecting for any service where the seller has not elected to assume and pay the tax shall be liable to the City for the amount of the tax; however, the seller shall not be liable for the payment of the tax on uncollected bills. If the purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay for the service, including the tax imposed, the seller shall immediately discontinue further service to the purchaser until the service is paid for in full. 
(Code 1982, § 95.03) 
Sec. 78-29. - Records of sales. 
    Each and every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), water service, telephone service and telegraph service shall keep complete records showing all sales in the City of these commodities or services. These records shall show the price charged upon each sale, the date of the sale and the date of payment, and shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the City during business hours on all business days. The duly authorized agents of the City shall have the right, power and authority to make transcripts of these records during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1982, § 95.04) 
Secs. 78-30-78-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FUEL OIL TAX 

Sec. 78-51. - Applicability of Article. 
    The term "fuel oil," as used in this Article, shall include fuel oil grade numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6, and kerosene and coal oil. The City Commission has investigated all utility services and all utility commodities sold within the territorial limits of the City and concludes that fuel oil grade numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6, and kerosene and coal oil, are furnished within the City as a competitive utility commodity and as a competitive utility service to all of the citizens of the City. 
(Code 1982, § 95.10) 
Sec. 78-52. - Levy; amount. 
    There is imposed and levied by the City a tax upon each and every purchase of fuel oil in the City, in the amount of $0.04 per gallon. 
(Code 1982, § 95.11(A)) 
Sec. 78-53. - Exemptions. 
    Purchases of special fuels as defined in F.S. ch. 206, and purchases by those entities described in Section 78-27, are excluded from the tax levied and imposed under this Article. 
(Code 1982, § 95.11(B)) 
Sec. 78-54. - Collection by seller; remittance to City. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every seller of fuel oil, in acting as a tax-collecting medium or agency for the City, to collect from the purchaser for the use of the City the tax levied and imposed by this Article at the time of collecting the purchase price charged for the sale, and to report and pay over, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, to the City Clerk, all the taxes imposed, levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. It shall be unlawful for any seller of fuel oil to collect the price of any sale of fuel oil without at the same time collecting the tax imposed and levied by this Article in respect of each purchase thereof, unless the seller elects to assume and pay the tax without collecting it from the purchaser. 
(1)  Any seller of fuel oil failing to collect the tax at the time of collecting the price of the sale, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay the tax, shall be liable to the City for the amount of the tax in like manner as if it had been actually paid by the purchaser to the seller. 
(2)  The City Manager shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and shall take any proceedings in the name of the City necessary for the collection or recovery of the tax; however, the seller of the fuel oil shall not be liable for payment of the tax upon uncollected charges. 
(3)  If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge for the sale, and the tax imposed, levied and required by this Article on account of the purchase for which the charge is made, or either, the seller shall have the right, power and authority to immediately discontinue further service to the purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill have been paid in full. 
(b)  In all cases where the seller of fuel oil collects the price thereof at monthly periods and intervals, the tax imposed and levied by this Article may be computed upon the aggregate amount of purchases during that monthly period; however, the amount of tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1982, § 95.12) 
Sec. 78-55. - Records of sales. 
    Each and every seller of fuel oil shall keep complete records showing all purchases within the City of fuel oil, the price charged upon each purchase, the period of time covered thereby, the amount of tax levied and imposed under this Article, and the date of payment. The records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized officers or agents of the City during business hours on all business days, and the duly authorized officers or agents of the City shall have the right, power and authority to make transcripts or photocopies during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1982, § 95.13) 
Sec. 78-56. - Exclusion of fuel adjustment charge. 
(a)  For purposes of this Section, the term "fuel adjustment charge" means all increases in the cost of utility services to the ultimate consumer resulting from an increase in the cost of fuel to the utility subsequent to October 1, 1973. 
(b)  The tax imposed by this Article shall not be applied against any fuel adjustment charge, and such charge shall be separately stated on each bill. 
(Code 1982, § 95.14) 
Secs. 78-57-78-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARI-MUTUEL TRACK FACILITY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Tax imposed on dog and horse racing facilities by cities, F.S. § 550.11. 

Sec. 78-76. - Levy; amount. 
    A tax of $50.00 per racing day is levied on all pari-mutuel dog track facilities and a tax of $150.00 per racing day is levied on all pari-mutuel horse track facilities within the City. This tax shall be paid for each day, or part thereof, that pari-mutuel dog or horse racing is conducted. 
(Code 1982, § 116.01) 
Sec. 78-77. - Payment. 
    The tax levied by this Article shall be paid by each pari-mutuel dog or horse track facility to the City on the first day of the month for the preceding month. However, all tax due and owing on the last day of a meet shall be paid within five days thereafter. The tax shall be paid by check. 
(Code 1982, § 116.02) 
Sec. 78-78. - Delinquency. 
    Failure to pay the tax levied by this Article as it becomes due shall give rise to a lien in favor of the City on all property, real or personal, owned by the delinquent dog or horse track facility in the amount of the taxes due, as well as all costs required to collect the delinquent taxes, including attorney fees, assessable costs, and other costs attributable to the collection of the taxes or the enforcement of the lien. The lien shall have priority over all other liens, claims or encumbrances on the property of the delinquent dog or horse track facility. 
(Code 1982, § 116.03) 
Secs. 78-79-78-81. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ADDITIONAL HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION FOR SENIOR CITIZENS 

Sec. 78-82. - Authority and purpose. 
    This Article is adopted pursuant to the specific authority of Section 6(f), Article VII of the Florida Constitution, and F.S. § 196.075, and the City's broad home rule powers granted by F.S. Ch. 166, and the City's Charter. 
(Ord. No. 99-970, § I, 11-29-99) 
Sec. 78-83. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this Article, shall have the meanings, unless clearly indicated otherwise: 
    City means the City of Casselberry, Florida. 
    Department of revenue means the same as Department of Revenue for the State of Florida. 
    Household means a person or group of persons living together in a room or group of rooms as a housing unit, but the term does not include persons boarding in or renting a portion of the dwelling. 
    House income means the adjusted gross income, as defined in Section 62 of the United States Internal Revenue Code, of all members of a household. 
    May is permissive when used herein. 
    Property Appraiser means the Seminole County Property Appraiser. 
    Shall is mandatory when used herein. 
    Sixty-five (65) years of age means a person who has attained the age of 65 prior to January 1st of the tax year for which the additional homestead exemption is sought. 
(Ord. No. 99-970, § I, 11-29-99) 
Sec. 78-84. - Entitlement to additional homestead exemption. 
(a)  Any person 65 years of age or older and who has legal or equitable title to real estate located within the City and who maintains thereon his or her permanent residence, which residence qualifies for and receives homestead exemption pursuant to Section 6(a), Article VII of the Florida Constitution, and whose household income does not exceed $20,000 shall be entitled to an additional homestead exemption of $5,000 as provided in this Article. The additional homestead exemption provided herein applies only to ad valorem levied by the City. Not more than one additional homestead exemption shall be allowed on individual or family unit or with respect to any residential unit. 
(b)  The additional homestead exemption provided herein shall be applicable to all tax levies of the City; and, if applicable, shall be subject to the provisions of F.S. §§ 196.131 and 196.161, . If title to the property is held jointly with right of survivorship, the person residing on the property and otherwise qualifying for the additional homestead exemption may receive the entire amount of the additional homestead exemption provided herein. 
(c)  The additional homestead exemption provided herein shall be available to qualified persons beginning with the year 2000 tax roll. 
(Ord. No. 99-970, § I, 11-29-99) 
Sec. 78-85. - Annual adjustment of income. 
    Beginning January 1, 2001, and continuing every January 1st thereafter, the $20,000.00 income limitation shall be automatically adjusted by the percentage of change in the average cost-of-living index in the period of January 1st through December 31st of the prior year as compared to the same period for the year prior to that year. As used herein, the term "index" shall be the average of the monthly consumer price index figures for the stated 12-month period, for the United States as a whole, issued by the United States Department of Labor. 
(Ord. No. 99-970, § I, 11-29-99) 
Sec. 78-86. - Requirements for claiming additional homestead exemptions. 
(a)  Every person claiming the additional homestead exemption pursuant to this article shall file an application with the Seminole County Property Appraiser no later than March 1st of each year for which such exemption is claimed. The application shall be on a form prescribed by the Department of Revenue and shall include a sworn statement of household income for all members of the household. On or before June 1st of each year, each applicant shall file supporting documentation with the Property Appraiser, including copies of all federal income tax returns, wage and earning statements (W-2 forms), and such other documentation the Department of Revenues requires, for each member of the household. The applicant's statement shall attest to the accuracy of all documentation provided, and the Property Appraiser shall not grant the additional homestead exemption without the required documentation. 
(b)  Failure to file the application and sworn statement by March 1st or failure to file the required supporting documentation by June 1st, of any given year shall constitute a waiver of the additional homestead exemption for that tax year. 
(Ord. No. 99-970, § I, 11-29-99) 
Sec. 78-87. - Notice requirements. 
(a)  The City Clerk shall, prior to December 1, 1999, provide a copy of the ordinance approving this Article to the Property Appraiser, and, in the event this Article is subsequently repealed or modified, notification of such repeal or modification shall be provided to the Property Appraiser not later than December 1st of the year prior to the year in which the homestead exemption provided herein expires or is modified. 
(b)  The City Manager shall annually report to the City Commission the economic impact associated with this Article. 
(Ord. No. 99-970, § I, 11-29-99) 
Secs. 78-88, 78-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TAX ABATEMENT PROGRAM 

Sec. 78-90. - Authority and purpose. 
    This article is adopted pursuant to the specific authority of Section 196.1995, Florida Statutes and referendum approved by the citizens of Casselberry on November 6, 2012. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-91. - Legislative findings. 
    Article VII, Section 3, of the Constitution of the State of Florida and Section 196.1995, Florida Statutes, enables municipalities to grant economic development ad valorem tax exemptions to certain new businesses and expansions of existing businesses expected to create new jobs, after the electors of the municipality, voting on the question in a referendum, authorize such exemptions. In a referendum held on November 6, 2012, the electors of the City of Casselberry authorized the City Commission to grant economic development ad valorem tax exemptions. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-92. - Definitions. 
    The following words, phrases, and terms shall have the meanings set forth below. Except where indicated otherwise, such words, phrases and terms shall have the same meanings attributed to them in the Florida Statutes and Florida Administrative Code as amended from time to time: 
Administrator.  The City Manager of the City of Casselberry or such other person designated by the City Manager. 
    Applicant. Any person, firm, partnership or corporation who files an Application with the City Commission seeking an exemption. 
    Application. A written application for an Exemption on the form prescribed by the Florida Department of Revenue, together with any supplemental form prescribed by the Administrator and such other certificates, representations, document, data, or additional information requested by the Administrator or the Seminole County Property Appraiser from time to time as may be reasonably necessary or useful for the determinations contemplated by this Ordinance. 
    Authorizing Ordinance. Ordinance 13-1389. 
    Average Wage in the City. The City of Casselberry average annual wage which may be adjusted from time to time. 
    Brownfield Area. An area designated as a Brownfield area pursuant to Section 376.80, Florida Statutes. 
    Business. Any activity engaged in by any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other business organization or entity with the object of private or public gain, benefit, or advantage, either direct or in direct. 
    City. The City of Casselberry. Florida. 
    City Commission. The elected Commissioners for the City of Casselberry, Florida. 
    Community Redevelopment Area. The agency with jurisdiction over an area designated as a community redevelopment area pursuant to Part III, Chapter 163, Florida Statutes. 
    County. Seminole County. Florida. 
    Enterprise Zone. An area designated as an enterprise zone pursuant to Section 290.0065, Florida Statutes. 
    Exemption or Economic Development Ad Valorem Tax Exemption. An ad valorem tax exemption granted by the City Commission in its sole and absolute discretion to a Qualified Business pursuant to this article as authorized by Article VII, Section 3 of the Constitution of the State of Florida and Section 196.1995, Florida Statutes. 
    Exemption Criteria. The criteria to be applied by the City Commission in making its determination as to whether to grant an Exemption. 
    Expansion of an Existing Business. As defined in Section 196.012(16), Florida Statutes, specifically: 
A.  A business or organization establishing ten or more new jobs to employ ten or more full-time employees in the City, paying an average wage for such new jobs that is above the average wage in the City which: 
1.  Principally manufactures, processes, compounds, fabricates, or produces for sale items of tangible personal property at a fixed location and which comprises an industrial or manufacturing plant: or 
2.  Is a Target Industry Business. 
B.  A business or organization establishing 25 or more jobs to employ 25 or more full-time employees in the City, the sales factor of which, for the facility with respect to which it requests an Exemption, is less than 0.50 for each year the Exemption is claimed; provided that such business increases operations on a site collocated with a commercial or industrial operation owned by the same business, or organization under common control with the same business or organization, resulting in a net increase in employment of not less than ten percent or an increase in productive output of not less than ten percent. 
C.  Any business or organization located in an Enterprise Zone or Brownfield Area that increases operations on a site located within the same zone or area collocated with a commercial or industrial operation owned by the same business or organization. 
    Implementing Ordinance. An ordinance enacted pursuant to Section 78-95 hereof for the purpose of granting an Exemption. 
    Improvements. Physical changes made to raw land and structures placed on or under the land surface, including all Tangible Personal Property acquired to facilitate an Expansion of an Existing Business, provided that the Tangible Personal Property is added or increased on or after the day an ordinance specifically granting a Business an Exemption is adopted. Tangible Personal Property acquired to replace existing property shall not be considered to facilitate a business expansion. 
    New Business. A "new business," as defined in Section 196.012(15), Florida Statutes, specifically: 
A.  A business or organization establishing ten or more new jobs to employ ten or more full-time employees in the City, paying an average wage for such new jobs that is above the average wage in the City which principally engages in any one or more of the following operations: 
1.  Manufactures, processes, compounds, fabricates, or produces for sale items of tangible personal property at a fixed location and which comprises an industrial or manufacturing plant; or 
2.  Is a Target Industry Business. 
B.  A business or organization establishing 25 or more new jobs to employ 25 or more full-time employees in the City, the sales factor of which, for the facility with respect to which it requests an Exemption, is less than 0.50 for each year the Exemption is claimed: or 
C.  An office space in the City owned and used by a business or organization newly domiciled in the City; provided that such office space houses 50 or more full-time employees of such business or corporation; provided that such business or organization office first begins operation on a site clearly separate from any other commercial or industrial operation owned by the same business or organization. 
D.  Any business located in an Enterprise Zone or Brownfield Area that first begins operation on a site clearly separate from any other commercial or industrial operation owned by the same business or organization. 
E.  A business that is situated on property that is annexed into the City and that, at the time of annexation, is receiving an Exemption from the County. 
    Qualified Business. Either a New Business or an Expansion of an Existing Business, as defined herein, that meets the criteria to be considered for an Exemption. 
    Sales Factor. As defined in Florida Statutes Section 220.15(5), a fraction, the numerator of which is the total sales of the taxpayer in this state during the taxable year or period and the denominator of which is the total sales of the taxpayer everywhere during the taxable year or period. 
    Tangible Personal Property. The meaning set forth in Section 192.001(11)(d), Florida Statutes. 
    Target Industry Business. An Expansion of an Existing Business or a New Business that is engaged in a Business designated, at the time of consideration of an application for Exemption, as a target industry business pursuant to Section 288.106, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-93. - Establishment of economic development ad valorem tax exemption. 
A.  The improvements to the expansion of real or tangible personal property may be granted or refused at the sole discretion of the City Commission. 
B.  The Exemption shall not accrue to Improvements to real property made on or after the effective date of this code, as provided in Section 78-95 hereof. 
C.  Any Exemption granted may apply up to 100 percent of the assessed value of all Improvements to real and tangible personal property made by or for the use of a New Business, or up to 100 percent of the assessed value of all added Improvements to real and tangible personal property made to facilitate the Expansion of an Existing Business, provided that the Improvements to real property are made or the tangible personal property is added or increased on or after the effective date of an Implementing Ordinance for a specific Business, as provided in Section 78-95 hereof. Property acquired to replace existing property shall not be considered to facilitate the Expansion of an Existing Business. 
D.  Each Exemption may be for a period up to ten years from the date the City Commission grants the Exemption to a specific Business. 
E.  No Exemption shall be granted for the land upon which a New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business is to be located. 
F.  The Exemption applies only to taxes levied by the City. The Exemption does not apply to taxes levied by a county, school district, or water management district, or to taxes levied for the payment of bonds or taxes authorized by a vote of the electors pursuant to Section 9 and Section 12, Article VII of the State Constitution. 
G.  Each Exemption shall be subject to each of the following conditions: 
1.  Each Business granted an Exemption shall maintain the New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business throughout the entire period of the Exemption; 
2.  Each Business granted an Exemption shall be required to submit an annual report and employee roster to the City Manager, or their designee, evidencing satisfaction of the foregoing condition. The report and employee roster shall be submitted on or before January 1 of each year the Exemption is in effect. 
3.  Each Business granted an Exemption shall furnish to the City Commission, or its designee, such information/report as the City Manager, or Community Development Director, may reasonably deem necessary for the purpose of determining continued performance by the Business of the conditions stated and the representations made in the application process. The City Manager, or Community Development Director, shall provide a copy of each annual report to the Property Appraiser by April 1. 
4.  Failure to adhere to these conditions may result in forfeiture of an Exemption. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-94. - Application. 
A.  Any eligible person, firm, partnership or corporation which desires an Exemption shall file with the City Manager, or Community Development Director, a written Application in the form prescribed by the City Commission. The Application must be filed with the City Manager, or Community Development Director, no later than January 1 of the year the Exemption is desired to take effect. 
B.  The application shall request the City Commission to adopt an Implementing Ordinance granting the Applicant the Exemption and shall include, at a minimum, each of the following components: 
1.  The name and location of the New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business; 
2.  The name of the owner or owners of the New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business; 
3.  A description of the improvement to the real property for which an Exemption is requested and the date of commencement of construction of such improvement; 
4.  A description of the tangible personal property for which an Exemption is requested and the dates when such property was or is to be purchased; 
5.  Proof to the satisfaction of the City Commission that the Applicant meets the criteria for a New Business or for an Expansion of an Existing Business as defined in Section 78-92 hereof; 
6.  The following information: 
a.  The current number of full-time/equivalent (FTE) and seasonal employees of the expanding Business; the total number of FTE and seasonal jobs to be created and maintained by the new or expanding Business, and the period (total number of years) needed to fill all of the new jobs; 
b.  The expected number of employees who will reside in the City of Casselberry and Seminole County; 
c.  The number and average annual wage of the new jobs, identifying the average annual salary; 
d.  The expected time schedule for job creation; 
e.  The type of industry or Business; 
f.  The environmental impact of the Business; 
g.  The current and anticipated volume (in dollars) of business or production, and the percentage of total product sales outside the City of Casselberry; 
h.  Whether relocation or expansion would occur without the Exemption; 
i.  The source of supplies (local or otherwise); 
j.  Whether the Business will be/is located in a Brownfield; 
k.  The total length (number of years) of the Exemption period being requested; and 
7.  Such other information as may be deemed necessary by the City Commission. 
C.  A Business shall be required to enter into an agreement with the City Commission to ensure that the Business will satisfy its job creation and maintenance obligations. 
D.  A Business will be required to commence the creation of full-time jobs within the period of the Exemption and to maintain any newly filled jobs for its facility in the City at a minimum through to the expiration of the Exemption granted by the City Commission. If a Business requires additional time beyond the date of the expiration of the Exemption to satisfy all new job creation, maintenance and salary commitments identified in the application, it will be necessary for the Business and the City to enter into a separate agreement which will obligate the Business to comply fully with those commitments. 
E.  If a New Business is locating to, or an Expansion of an Existing Business is occurring in, a Community Redevelopment Area, the City Manager, or Community Development Director, shall promptly so notify the Community Redevelopment Agency Board overseeing such area, and the Board shall be provided a copy of the Application for review and comment. Input from the Community Redevelopment Agency will be considered by the City Commission in deciding whether an Exemption is to be granted. 
F.  An Application for an Exemption shall be submitted in advance of any necessary permit application changing the future land use or changing zoning for proposed sites. In the case of existing sites or facilities where adequate zoning and future land use is in place, an Application shall be submitted prior to application for building permits. 
G.  Upon submittal of the application, the City Manager, or their designee, shall review same, and within a reasonable time of submission, notify the Applicant of any deficiencies. 
H.  The application shall be filed on or before January 1 for the year in which an Exemption is requested. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-95. - Consideration of applications. 
A.  The City Commission shall take action on each application, including the enactment of the Implementing Ordinance, should the City Commission decide to grant the application. 
B.  The threshold for eligibility is whether the Business meets the definition of a New Business or of an Expansion of an Existing Business as set forth in Section 78-92 of this Authorizing Ordinance, and one which is not an ineligible business or industry, as set forth in Subsection (D) of this Section. 
C.  The next level to determine eligibility is the City Commission's consideration of the information in the application to determine whether the Exemption, if granted, would result in an economic benefit to the City. 
D.  Any existing Business in violation of any federal, state, or local law or regulation governing environmental matters is not eligible for an Exemption. 
E.  Before the City Commission takes action on an application, the City Manager, or Community Development Director, shall deliver a copy of the same to the Property Appraiser for review. After careful consideration, the Property Appraiser shall report to the City Manager, or Community Development Director, the fiscal impact of granting the Exemption. 
F.  The Property Appraiser's report shall include the following: 
1.  The total revenue available to the City for the current fiscal year from ad valorem tax sources, or an estimate of such revenue if the actual total available revenue cannot be determined; 
2.  The amount of revenue lost to the City for the current fiscal year by virtue of Exemptions previously granted, or an estimate of such revenue if the actual revenue lost cannot be determined; 
3.  An estimate of the amount of revenue which would be lost to the City for the current fiscal year if the Exemption applied for was granted, had the property for which the Exemption is requested otherwise been subject to taxation; and 
4.  A determination as to whether the property for which an Exemption is requested is to be incorporated into a New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business, or into neither, which determination the Property Appraiser shall also affix to the face of the application. Upon request, the Department of Revenue will provide Appraiser such information as it may have available to assist in making this determination. 
G.  After consideration of the application and the report of the Property Appraiser on the application, the City Commission may choose to adopt an Implementing Ordinance granting the Exemption to a New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business. If an Exemption is granted, the Implementing Ordinance shall include the following information: 
1.  The names and address of the New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business; 
2.  The names of the owner or owners of the New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business; 
3.  The total amount of revenue available to the City from ad valorem tax sources for the current fiscal year, the total amount of the revenue lost to the City for the current fiscal year by virtue of Exemption currently in effect, and the estimated revenue loss attributable to the Exemption granted to the New Business or the Expansion of an Existing Business; 
4.  The period of time for which the Exemption will remain in effect and the expiration date of the Exemption; and 
5.  A finding that the Business meets the definition of a New Business or an Expansion of an Existing Business, as set forth in Section 78-92 hereof. 
H.  The Business granted an Exemption shall be required to inform the City Manager, or Community Development Director, in writing within ten days as to any changes in ownership of the Business granted an Exemption. Failure of the Business granted an Exemption to notify the City Manager, or Community Development Director, in writing of any such changes in ownership is cause for revocation of the Exemption. 
I.  No precedent shall be implied or inferred by the granting of an Exemption to any New Business or Expansion of an Existing Business. Application for Exemptions shall be considered by the City Commission on a case-by-case basis for each application, after consideration of the application and the Property Appraiser's report on the application. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-96. - Revocation. 
A.  Should any New Business or Expansion of an Existing Business (1) fail to file the annual report and employee roster with the City Manager, or Community Development Director, on or before January 1 of each year the Exemption has been granted as required in Section 78-93 hereof, (2) fail to continue to meet the definition of a New Business or an Expansion of an Existing Business, (3) fail to fulfill any other representation made to the City Commission during the application process, including but not limited to the creation and maintenance of the total number of new jobs identified in the application, or (4) fail to comply with any other statutory requirement for continuation or renewal of the Exemption, the City Manager, or the Community Development Director shall advise the City Manager, who will then in turn advise the City Commission who may enact an ordinance revoking the Exemption. 
B.  The Exemption may be revoked after expiration of this Authorizing Ordinance on November 6, 2022, for a Business that fails to fulfill its obligations as provided for under the Implementing Ordinance. The effective date for revocation of the Exemption will be identified in the Implementing Ordinance. 
C.  Upon revocation of an Exemption, the City Manager, or Community Development Director shall immediately notify the Property Appraiser. 
D.  For any year that taxes may have been exempted and the City Commission finds that the Business was not entitled to the Exemption, such taxes may be recovered. The Property Appraiser will assist the City Commission to recover any taxes exempted. 
E.  Nothing herein shall prohibit a Business from reapplying for an Exemption. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 78-97. - Sunset date. 
    Pursuant to Section 196.1995, Florida Statutes, and the referendum approved by the citizens on November 6, 2012, the City Commission's authority to grant Exemptions shall expire on November 6, 2022. 
(Ord. No. 13-1389, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Chapter 82 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire lanes and fire zones, § 42-6; excessive emissions, § 50-1; planning and development, Ch. 66; construction affecting streets, rights-of-way or easements, § 68-26 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Definitions. 
    The words and phrases used in this Chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in F.S. ch. 316, as it may be from time to time amended, except where the context otherwise requires. 
(Code 1982, § 71.002) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-2. - Penalty for violation of Chapter. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided, whenever in this Chapter or in any other traffic ordinance or resolution of the City, or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the City under authority duly vested in him or it, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such a provision of this Chapter or other ordinance or resolution of the City or rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $300.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  Except where otherwise provided, every day any violation of this Chapter or other ordinance or resolution of the City or rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  In addition to the penalties provided in this Section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter or any other ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the City as provided by law, and each day that the condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(b)  Parking fines. Where no other penalty is provided, any person violating Article IV of this Chapter or F.S. chs. 316 and 318, by unlawfully parking a motor vehicle or vehicle as those terms are defined in this Chapter or F.S. ch. 316, shall be fined as follows: 
(1)  For the following violations, the fine shall be $30.00: 
a.  Obstructing traffic; 
b.  Blocking a driveway; 
c.  Parking within 30 feet of a traffic control device; 
d.  Parking on a crosswalk; 
e.  Parking on the sidewalk; 
f.  Parking where prohibited by official marking or sign; 
g.  Parking where prohibited in residential districts; 
h.  Parking large vehicles where prohibited in nonresidential districts; 
i.  Any other parking violation of this chapter; or 
j.  Parking which otherwise violates F.S. ch. 316. 
(2)  For the following violations, the fine shall be $30.00: 
a.  Parking within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; or 
b.  Parking in a designated fire lane. 
(3)  For unauthorized parking in a designated handicapped parking zone, the fine shall be $250.00. For purposes of this Section, unauthorized parking in a designated handicapped parking zone shall mean any vehicle so parked which does not bear a license plate or taglet as provided in F.S. § 320.0842, 320.0843 or 320.0848. 
(c)  Violation of truck route regulations. A violation of any of the provisions of Article V of this Chapter shall be deemed an infraction as defined in F.S. § 318.13(3), and shall be punished as provided in F.S. § 318.18 and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1982, §§ 70.99, 71.999; Ord. No. 06-1178, § 1, 3-13-06; Ord. 17-1453, § II, 2-13-17) 
Sec. 82-3. - Adoption of state law. 
    F.S. chs. 316, 318, 320 and 322, and F.S. ch. 325, part II, are adopted as the traffic code of the City, and, in accordance with the requirements of Laws of Fla. ch. 71-135, § 6, the matters and contents in these chapters are made a part of this Chapter by reference as fully and completely as if set forth in this Chapter. Copies of the law shall remain on file in the office of the City Clerk, and shall be available for public inspection and use. 
(Code 1982, § 70.01) 
Sec. 82-4. - Applicability of state uniform traffic control law. 
    F.S. ch. 316, known as the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, is applicable in the City, and supersedes this Chapter in the event of any irreconcilable conflict. 
(Code 1982, § 71.003) 
Sec. 82-5. - Powers of local authorities. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by the provisions of this Chapter or other ordinances of the City, the City Engineer, the Police Chief, and the City Manager shall have the power to designate, install and regulate and enforce the operation and parking of vehicles within the corporate limits of the City by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers as follows: 
(1)  Prohibit or limit parking. 
(2)  Restrict speed. 
(3)  Establish one-way streets, through or arterial streets, stop streets, U-turns, play streets, school zones, hospital zones, loading and unloading zones, and quiet zones, subject to City Commission approval. 
(4)  Designate bus stops and taxicab stands and erect signs to prohibit the parking of vehicles other than buses and taxicabs in such stands. 
(5)  Designate truck routes, subject to City Commission approval. 
(6)  Regulate parking of vehicles of various sizes and weights. 
(7)  Mark traffic lanes on streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic. 
(8)  Establish parking meter zones, including the size and number of spaces therein, the erection of parking meters, and the parking time allowed, after public hearing and subject to City Commission approval. 
(b)  The existence of these signs or markers at any place within the corporate limits of the City shall be prima facie evidence that the signs or markers were erected or placed by and at the direction of the Police Chief, the City Engineer or the City Manager in accordance with the provisions of this Section. 
(Code 1982, § 70.02) 
State Law reference- Powers of local authorities, F.S. § 316.008. 
Sec. 82-6. - Speed limits. 
    The state traffic laws (F.S. ch. 316) shall regulate the speed of vehicles and shall be applicable upon all streets within the City. 
(Code 1982, § 71.040) 
Sec. 82-7. - Operation of golf carts on road- way. 
    The operation of a golf cart upon the public roads or public streets within the City shall be as provided in F.S. § 316.212, which Section is incorporated in this Section by reference and shall govern the operation of a golf cart in the City. 
(Code 1982, § 71.034) 
Sec. 82-8. - Operation of pushcarts on road- way. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the responsibilities applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this Chapter and by the rules of the road portion of the state uniform traffic control law, except those provisions which, by their very nature, can have no application. 
(Code 1982, § 71.045(A)) 
Sec. 82-9. - Use of skateboards, roller skates and similar devices on roadway. 
(a)  No person upon roller skates or roller blades, or riding in or by means of any coaster, skateboard, scooter, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk. When so crossing, that person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the responsibilities applicable to pedestrians. 
(b)  This Section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street as authorized in this Chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 71.046) 
Sec. 82-10. - Driving on bicycle trails and footpaths. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle, ATV (all-terrain vehicle) or moped within the City, except in conformity with state traffic laws regulating the operation of such vehicles, upon any private or public bicycle trail or footpath, except upon a permanent or duly-authorized temporary driveway. 
(Code 1982, § 71.047) 
Sec. 82-11. - Parades, processions and special events. 
(a)  Permit required; conduct generally. It shall be unlawful for any procession, except funerals, or special event such as a block party, road or foot race, or the like, or parade, to occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the City Commission and such other regulations as are set forth in this Code which may apply. Applications shall be made to the office of the City Engineer. 
(b)  Permit fee. The City Commission may, from time to time, establish by resolution such permit fees as the Commission shall deem equitable and necessary. Applications for a permit shall be accompanied by any fee established under this Subsection. 
(c)  Revocation of permit. The City Engineer may revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this Section if there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to a material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based. 
(Code 1982, §§ 71.050, 71.052, 71.053) 
Sec. 82-12. - Oversize or overweight vehicle or load. 
(a)  Permit required; removal of traffic control devices. Pursuant to F.S. § 316.550, any person wishing to move any overheight, overweight or overwidth vehicle or load upon a road shall obtain a permit from the office of the City Engineer. If the vehicle shall require the removal of any official traffic control devices, that removal and reinstallation shall be accomplished by the Public Works Department. The cost of labor and equipment will be billed to the applicant for the permit. If the move necessitates the removal of traffic signals, such as for moving a house, a bond may be required. 
(b)  Permit fee. The City Commission may, from time to time, establish by resolution such permit fees as the Commission shall deem equitable and necessary. Applications for a permit shall be accompanied by any fee established under this Subsection. 
(c)  Revocation of permit. The City Engineer may revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this Section if there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to a material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based. 
(Code 1982, §§ 71.051-71.053) 
Sec. 82-13. - Abandoned or derelict vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Property means any real property in the City other than a road, street, alley, highway or other public easement. 
(2)  Road, street, alley, highway and other public easement mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every public right-of-way. 
(3)  Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by the use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and to transport persons or property or pull machinery, and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles and tractors. 
(b)  Abandonment prohibited. No person who is the owner or in control of the vehicle shall abandon any dismantled, partially dismantled, wrecked, junked or nonoperating vehicle on any road, street, alley, highway or other public easement or on private property, except on private property as provided for in this Section. Such a vehicle shall be deemed to have been abandoned if it remains parked on a City right-of-way for more than 48 consecutive hours. 
(c)  Storage of unlicensed and/or inoperable vehicles on private property. No person in charge or in control of any property within the City, whether an owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, shall allow any unlicensed and/or inoperable vehicle to be placed or remain on such property unless such vehicle is within a completely enclosed building or is on the premises of an automotive repair or storage business, for which the owner of the business has a current city occupational business tax receipt and zoning approval. However, an inoperable vehicle may not remain on the premises of an auto repair business or storage business in excess of 60 days. 
(d)  Evidence. A vehicle will be in violation of this Section if it is in a state of evident disuse, neglect, or abandonment. Evidence may include, but is not limited to, factors such as: Vehicle being wrecked, inoperative as evidenced by vegetation underneath as high as the vehicle body or frame, refuse or debris collected underneath or the vehicle being used solely for storage purposes, if it is partially dismantled, having no engine, transmission, or other major and visible sections, having major and visible parts which are dismantled, having no valid license tag, or being in any physical state rendering it inoperable or unsightly to the neighborhood. If the primary apparent evidence of neglect or abandonment is the lack of a valid tag or vegetation growing under vehicle, then the inspector shall use his training and experience to determine whether, under the totality of the circumstances, the vehicle is in a state of evident disuse, neglect, or abandonment. A vehicle will be considered abandoned or derelict if it is an evident state of extended disuse or neglect. 
(e)  Interpretation of this requirement. Nothing in this Section shall be construed as permitting the disassembling, tearing down or scrapping of a vehicle, or to permit one vehicle to be scavenged or stripped for sections for use on another vehicle. Additionally, nothing in this Section shall be construed as permitting the violation of other Code provisions, including, but not limited to, outside storage requirements, junkyard provisions, and lot cleaning standards. 
(f)  Responsibility for compliance. The owner, agent and/or tenant of the property on which the violation occurs and the owner of the disabled vehicle shall be jointly and individually responsible for compliance with the requirements of this Section. 
(g)  Enforcement. When a disabled or abandoned vehicle is found to be in violation of this Section: 
(1)  The Code Enforcement Officer shall place a written notice on the vehicle indicating that it is in violation of this Section and that it must be removed within ten calendar days or it will be subject to removal by the City. The Code Inspector shall make every reasonable attempt to ascertain the owner of the vehicle and the owner of the property and shall notify such owner(s) with a written notice delivered by mail or personal service at their current address, last known address, or the address appearing on the certificate of title for the vehicle. 
(2)  Within the ten calendar-day period specified in the notice, the owner of the vehicle or the owner of the property, or an authorized agent may appeal, in writing, to the administrative official selected or appointed by the City Manager to administer code enforcement in the City. 
(3)  The property or vehicle owner(s) may appeal, in writing, the administrative official's final decision to the Code Enforcement Board for determination as to whether the abandoned or derelict vehicle is subject to removal. 
(4)  If no written appeal is made and the disabled vehicle remains in violation after the ten calendar-day period, the administrative official shall call such vehicle to be removed immediately to a storage facility approved by the City and thereafter disposed of in compliance with applicable State law or City ordinance. 
(5)  The authorization in this Section for the towing of abandoned and disabled vehicles shall not be construed so as to negate the authority of the Code Enforcement Board to hear and adjudicate appropriate cases. 
(h)  Vehicles on public property. Notwithstanding any of the foregoing, all vehicles which are located on public property shall be towed and disposed of in accordance with the notice and sale requirements of F.S. ch. 705, as revised in the 1987 legislative session. To the extent that this Section conflicts with any portion of F.S. ch. 705, the latter shall control as to any vehicles located on public property. 
(Code 1982, § 71.009; Ord. No. 779, § III, 11-1-93; Ord. No. 12-1378, § 1, 9-24-12) 
Cross reference- Unclaimed property, § 54-26 et seq.; solid waste, ch. 70. 
Secs. 82-14-82-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-36. - Duties of Police Department. 
    It shall be the duty of the Police Chief, with such aid as may be rendered by other members of the Police Department, to enforce the provisions of this Chapter and the state vehicle laws applicable to parking in the City, to make arrests for parking violations, to assist in the prosecution of persons charged with such violations, to investigate accidents, to cooperate with other officials of the City in the administration of this Chapter, to develop ways and means to improve parking conditions, and to carry out those duties specially imposed by this Chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 70.03) 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, Ch. 54. 
Sec. 82-37. - Liability of City officers and employees. 
    Any officer or employee charged with the enforcement of this Chapter, acting for the City Commission in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally, and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any officer or employee because of an act performed by him or her in the enforcement of any provision of this Chapter shall be defended by the City or its representatives until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Code 1982, § 71.005) 
Sec. 82-38. - Funding. 
    The City Commission is authorized to appropriate and expend such funds as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this Chapter. Nothing contained in this Section shall require the City Commission to appropriate or expend any funds to carry out the purpose of this Chapter. The authority granted in this Section is permissive, and shall not be construed to impose an obligation on the City Engineer or the City to take any specific action relative to traffic control or to remove any hazards or obstructions under Article VI of this Chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 71.006) 
Sec. 82-39. - Powers of City Engineer and Police Chief regarding traffic control and engineering. 
(a)  The City Engineer shall be in charge of traffic engineering and shall exercise specific powers and duties delegated to him with respect to traffic engineering as provided in this Chapter. 
(b)  It shall be the general function of the City Engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions, to plan the most efficient operation of traffic on the streets and highways of the City, to cooperate with state, county and municipal officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and functions imposed by ordinances of the City. 
(c)  The City Engineer and Police Chief are hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the City, subject to the approval of the City Manager and City Commission, and to make temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulations shall remain in effect for more than 90 days. Repeat temporary or experimental regulation projects shall not be implemented within 90 days of initial temporary or experimental use except following a public hearing before the City Commission. 
(d)  The City Engineer and Police Chief may test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(e)  The City Engineer and Police Chief, subject to the approval of the City Manager and City Commission, are hereby authorized, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, to prohibit, regulate or limit stopping, standing or parking of vehicles at all times or during specified hours. 
(Code 1982, § 71.007; Ord. No. 662, § I, 7-16-90) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-81 et seq.; law enforcement, Ch. 54. 
Sec. 82-40. - Appeal of decisions of City Engineer. 
(a)  Appeals to the City Commission may be taken by any person aggrieved, or by any officer, board or department of the City affected, by any decision of the City Engineer under this Chapter. 
(b)  All appeals, except those taken under Article VI of this Chapter, shall be taken within 30 days after the decision is made, by filing a notice of appeal in the office of the City Engineer specifying the grounds thereof. 
(c)  Appeals filed from decisions made by the City Engineer under Article VI of this Chapter shall be taken within ten days of receipt of the notice required thereunder by filing a notice of appeal in the office of the City Engineer. 
(d)  It is the intent of this Chapter that questions of interpretation and enforcement shall first be presented to the City Engineer, and that questions shall be presented to the City Commission only on appeal from the decision of the City Engineer. 
(Code 1982, § 71.004) 
Sec. 82-41. - Official forms. 
    The City Commission shall adopt by resolution such forms as may be necessary for administration of this Chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 71.008) 
Secs. 82-42-82-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITATIONS AND OTHER NOTICES; PAYMENT OF FINES 

Sec. 82-51. - Traffic citations generally. 
    Citations for violations of this Chapter, with the exception of parking citations, shall be issued in accordance with the requirements of F.S. ch. 316 or its successor. 
(Code 1982, § 71.100) 
State Law reference- Traffic citations, F.S. § 316.650. 
Sec. 82-52. - Purpose of Division. 
    The purpose of this Division is to assist the county court and the county traffic and ordinance violations bureau and to empower authorized City employees to issue summons for violations of this Code relating to parking. 
(Code 1982, § 71.115) 
Sec. 82-53. - Citation forms. 
    Serially numbered forms as provided by the Police Chief shall be used for notifying violators to appear in answer to charges of violating any ordinance of the City. All forms shall be receipted and accounted for by the Police Chief or other person acting for him or her. The Police Chief or other person acting for him or her shall each month report to the City Manager the number of arrests made and the number of citations issued by the Police Department and its inspecting officers during that month. 
(Code 1982, § 71.119) 
Sec. 82-54. - Use of sworn complaints as evidence. 
    Whenever any complaint charging a violation of any City law is sworn to by a police officer or other competent person, the complaint shall be accepted as conclusive evidence of the facts alleged therein, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, in all cases where the defendant fails to appear at the time and place required by the warrant issued thereunder, or as may be ordered by the county court. 
(Code 1982, § 71.120) 
Sec. 82-55. - Citation procedure. 
    Except when authorized or required to immediately take a person arrested for a violation of a City law or City traffic ordinance, or the traffic offense exempted in F.S. § 318.17, into custody, a police officer, upon charging a person for violation of the state traffic law or of a City law or City traffic ordinance, shall take the violator's name, address and license number, and issue to him, in writing, a citation provided by the Police Chief, requiring him to answer the charge at a time and place fixed. In cases of traffic infractions, the violator shall be required to respond as required by F.S. ch. 318. The officer shall issue a copy of the citation to the person charged, and shall submit the original and all copies of the citation to the records unit of the Police Department. 
(Code 1982, § 71.121; Ord. 17-1453, § III, 2-13-17) 
Sec. 82-56. - Payment of fine. 
(a)  Any person charged with a traffic offense or infraction for which payment of a fine and civil penalty may be made to the county traffic and ordinance violations bureau shall have the option of paying the fine and civil penalty within the time specified in the citation or notice of arrest at the bureau, upon entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere and upon waiving appearance in court. 
(b)  The payment of a fine and civil penalty to the bureau shall be deemed an acknowledgement of violation of the designated ordinance, and the bureau, upon accepting the prescribed fine, shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging payment. Should payment of the fine be made by mail and by check, the canceled check may serve as a receipt, provided a receipt is not specifically requested by the payee. 
(Code 1982, § 71.117) 
Sec. 82-57. - Issuance of summons. 
    Inspecting officers specifically empowered by the City Manager shall have the power to serve a summons upon the person charged with an alleged violation under this Chapter, or to post the notice at a place of violation. This power shall be confined to the violations designated by the county judge and the laws of the state. The inspecting officers shall not be authorized to arrest or otherwise take a violator into custody, except when done by a police officer with a warrant of arrest duly executed. 
(Code 1982, § 71.118) 
Sec. 82-58. - Failure to obey notice or summons. 
    It is a violation of this Division for any person to violate his written promise to appear given to an officer upon an arrest for any traffic violation, regardless of the disposition of the charge on which he was originally arrested. A driver of a motor vehicle who wilfully neglects to answer to the charges set forth in a written notice affixed to the motor vehicle by a police officer shall be held to have violated this Division. 
(Code 1982, § 71.122) 
Sec. 82-59. - Alteration or destruction of notices. 
(a)  The notices referred to in this Division shall remain the property of the City before and after the serving, delivery or affixing thereof, and shall be considered an integral part of the Police Department and of the county court. All persons receiving any notice in writing, whether by personal service or by affixing it to a motor vehicle, are required to preserve the notice and to bring and present it to the county traffic and ordinance violations bureau when answering the charge set forth in the notice. 
(b)  No recipient of a notice or other person shall wilfully throw away, alter, mar, mutilate, destroy or discard the written notice of the City described in Section 82-58. 
(c)  No person finding affixed to any vehicle the written notice of the City described in Section 82-58, whether he be the owner, operator, driver or passenger of the vehicle to which the notice is affixed, shall wilfully throw away, alter, mar, mutilate, destroy or discard such notice. 
(d)  No person not being the owner, having charge of, operating or driving a vehicle to which may be found affixed the written notice described in Section 82-58 shall wilfully remove, take away, throw away, mar, alter, mutilate, destroy or discard the written notice so affixed, nor shall any person receive any notice from another for the purpose of so mutilating or destroying it or for the purpose of constituting himself the agent of the recipient for any purpose other than the proper and lawful adjustment at the traffic and ordinance violations bureau of the charge contained in the notice. 
(Code 1982, § 71.123) 
Sec. 82-60. - Issuance of arrest warrant. 
(a)  If any person summoned by a notice of arrest affixed on a motor vehicle does not respond within the period specified in the notice, the county traffic and ordinance violations bureau shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the notice was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that he will be held responsible for the appearance of the offender. If the letter is disregarded within the period specified in the letter, a complaint will be filed and a warrant of arrest issued. 
(b)  If any person fails to comply with a notice, as provided in Subsection (a) of this Section, or fails to make an appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the traffic and ordinance violations bureau, the bureau shall forthwith file a complaint against that person and secure a warrant for his arrest. The provisions of F.S. § 318.15 shall be followed where appropriate. 
(Code 1982, § 71.116) 
Secs. 82-61-82-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT OF PARKING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 82-71. - Issuance of citations. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked, stopped or standing in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by state law or regulation of the City in the incorporated areas of the City, the Police Department, finding the vehicle, shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to the vehicle a parking citation or summons in writing for the driver to answer the charge against him within 14 business days, during the hours and at a place specified in the citation or summons. 
(b)  Each day that a parking violation occurs or continues will constitute a separate offense for which a parking citation may be issued. 
(c)  Citations issued in a form approved by the Chief of Police pursuant to Section 82-53 for parking violations may be issued by police officers, or any other person successfully completing the applicable state requirements, as designated by the City Manager and approved by the Chief of Police. 
(Code 1982, § 71.105; Ord. 17-1453, § IV, 2-13-17) 
Sec. 82-72. - Payment of fines; failure to respond to citation. 
(a)  The operator or registered owner of a vehicle receiving a parking citation for a parking violation shall, within 14 business days, pay the fines as prescribed in this chapter or request a hearing before a judge of the county court. Any person electing to appear before the designated judge shall be deemed to have waived his right to pay the civil penalty. The judge, after a hearing, shall make a determination as to whether a violation has been committed. If the commission of violation has been proven, the judge may impose a fine not to exceed $100.00 plus court costs. 
(b)  Failure of the owner or operator of the vehicle to make payment of the fine within 14 business days from the date the parking citation was issued shall render such owner or operator subject to maximum prosecution under state law at the discretion of the court and a late charge of $10.00 ("initial late charge") unless such person timely requests a hearing. Failure to make payment of the fine within 30 days shall subject such owner or operator to an additional late charge of $10.00 ("additional late charge"). In addition, a notice of summons may be sent, by certified mail, to the owner or operator of the vehicle which was cited, informing such owner of the parking citation, the failure to comply therewith, the applicable late charges, or require a mandatory court appearance. 
(c)  Any person who fails to respond to the original parking citation within the time specified on such notice shall be deemed to have waived the right to contest the merits of such parking violation. 
(d)  The City is hereby authorized, in its discretion, to provide the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles with a listing of persons who have three or more outstanding parking citations. Such provision may be made in accordance with the provisions of F.S. §§ 316.1967(6). If a person's name appears on the list described herein, a license plate or revalidation sticker may not be issued until that person's name no longer appears on the list or until the person presents a receipt from the City or the clerk of court showing that the outstanding fines have been paid. 
(Code 1982, § 71.106; Ord. 17-1453, § V, 2-13-17) 
Sec. 82-73. - Presumptions regarding violations. 
(a)  In any prosecution charging a violation of any statute or ordinance governing the parking, stopping or standing of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked, stopped or standing in violation of the statute or ordinance, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of that parking, stopping or standing, the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked, stopped or stood the vehicle at the point where and for the time during which the violation occurred, and shall be sufficient to invoke the penalties set out in this Chapter. 
(b)  At the trial of any case involving an alleged violation of any statute or ordinance governing the parking, stopping or standing of a vehicle in which the owner of the vehicle is being tried under this Chapter, it shall be sufficient evidence to establish the name of the registered owner of the vehicle if a police officer shall state on oath that he has made inquiry of the state department of highway safety and motor vehicles, through standard law enforcement channels, and has been advised by it of the identity of the registered owner at the time of the alleged offense. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the rebuttability of the presumption provided for in Subsections (a) and (b) of this Section, the registered owner of a vehicle when the vehicle is parked, stopped or standing in violation of any state statute or City ordinance is hereby declared to be directly responsible to the City for payment of the fine for the vehicle being so parked or left stopped or standing. For purposes of this Section, the term "registered owner" means the person who is lawfully registered with the state department of highway safety and motor vehicles as provided by state law on the day the violation occurs. 
(d)  The presumption stated in Subsection (c) of this Section shall apply only when the procedures prescribed in Sections 82-71 and 82-72 have been followed. 
(Code 1982, § 71.107) 
Sec. 82-74. - Issuance of arrest warrant. 
    If any person fails to comply with a summons given to the person or attached to a vehicle pursuant to this Division, or fails to make appearance pursuant to the summons from the county court directing an appearance as the court determines, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail that is required within the time permitted by statute or ordinance, the Police Department of the City shall forthwith apply for a warrant for his arrest. 
(Code 1982, § 71.108) 
Sec. 82-75. - Impoundment. 
(a)  When any vehicle is left parked, stopped or standing in violation of any statute of the state or ordinance of the City on any publicly owned property, including streets, highways, roads, alleys, parking lots or any other premises of the City, county or state, the Police Department or any police officer is authorized to have the vehicle impounded in accordance with the tow car franchise agreement. 
(b)  Removal of vehicles parked on private property will be the responsibility of the property owner. The City Police Department will assist in determining whether the vehicle has been reported stolen. 
(c)  Members of the Police Department shall be vested with the authority and it shall be their duty to impound any unoccupied vehicle parked in violation of any of the parking regulations of the City where the vehicle impedes traffic, creates a traffic hazard, or appears to be abandoned, and to release the vehicle to the duly identified owner thereof, subject to the payment of a fine, if any, and the storage, towing and other impounding charges. The Police Department shall exercise due diligence to identify and notify the owner. 
(Code 1982, § 71.109) 
Sec. 82-76. - Violations presided over by a hearing officer. 
(a)  All violations of this Article shall be referred to a hearing officer designated to preside over civil traffic infractions in the County. 
(b)  Each violation will be adjudicated in accordance with the provisions of the Charter or Code of the City of Casselberry, Florida. 
(c)  Upon a written request of defendant, filed prior to the scheduled hearing on the civil traffic infraction, the parking infraction case shall be assigned to a County Judge regularly assigned to hear traffic matters. 
(Ord. No. 96-855, §§ I-III, 1-15-96) 
Secs. 82-77-82-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 82-96. - Specifications. 
    All traffic control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as approved by the state department of transportation. All signs and signals required under this Chapter for a particular purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the City. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this Chapter shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1982, § 71.017) 
Sec. 82-97. - Installation of multiway stop signs. 
(a)  Arterial and collector roads. 
(1)  Multiway stop signs on arterial and collector roads shall be installed in accordance with the state department of transportation publication titled "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices." 
(2)  The multiway stop installation is useful as a safety measure at some locations. It should ordinarily be used only where the volume of traffic on the intersection roads is approximately equal. A traffic control signal is more satisfactory for an intersection with a heavy volume of traffic. 
(3)  Multiway stop signs shall not be installed unless one or more of the following conditions are met: 
a.  Where traffic signals are warranted and urgently needed, the multiway stop is an interim measure that can be installed quickly to control traffic while arrangements are being made for the signal installation. 
b.  Multiway stop signs may be installed where an accident problem exists, as indicated by the occurrence of five or more reported accidents of a type susceptible of correction by a multiway stop installation in a 12-month period. Such accidents include right and left turn collisions, as well as right-angle collisions. 
(4)  Minimum traffic volumes are as follows: 
a.  The total vehicular volume entering the intersection from all approaches must average at least 500 vehicles per hour for any eight hours of an average day; and 
b.  The combined vehicular and pedestrian volume from the minor street or highway must average at least 200 units per hour for the same eight hours, with an average delay to minor-street vehicular traffic of at least 30 seconds per vehicle during the maximum hour. 
When the 85-percentile approach speed of the major-street traffic exceeds 40 miles per hour, the minimum vehicular volume warrant is 70 percent of the requirements set out in Subsections a. and b. of this Subsection. 
(b)  Local feeder roads. Signs may be installed for local feeder roads as follows: 
(1)  At an intersection that is primary to the area. 
(2)  Where there is a 60-40 percent volume split for a four-way intersection. 
(3)  Where there is a 75-25 percent volume split for a three-way intersection. 
(4)  Where there are three or more correctable accidents in one year. 
Other parameters such as pedestrians, site visibility, etc., should also be considered prior to arriving at a final decision pertaining to the installation of a multiway stop. 
(c)  Use generally. Engineering judgment should be carefully exercised in applying these guidelines to avoid the excessive use of this highly restrictive control. In addition, all existing multiway stop controlled intersections should be periodically reviewed to determine if another type of control would be more appropriate. 
(Code 1982, § 71.033; Ord. No. 662, § IV, 7-16-90) 
Sec. 82-98. - Public hearing. 
    Permanent alterations in traffic flows which impede or impair free pedestrian or vehicular movements or access within the City shall only be implemented following a public hearing before the City Commission. 
(Code 1982, § 71.033; Ord. No. 662, § V, 7-16-90) 
Secs. 82-99-82-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking of buses and taxicabs, § 82-207. 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places, F.S. § 316.1945. 

Sec. 82-121. - Responsibility of vehicle owner. 
    No person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or be parked in any street, avenue or alley in the City in violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter regulating the standing or parking of a vehicle. 
(Code 1982, § 71.074) 
Sec. 82-122. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than 12 feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1982, § 71.060) 
Sec. 82-123. - Parking in alleys. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than 12 feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1982, § 71.061) 
Sec. 82-124. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any right-of-way for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying the vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Maintenance or repair of the vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(3)  Selling merchandise or services. 
(Code 1982, § 71.062) 
Sec. 82-125. - Standing or parking on one-way roadway. 
    If a highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the lefthand side of the one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit standing or parking. 
(Code 1982, § 71.063) 
Sec. 82-126. - Parking near mailbox. 
    No person shall park a vehicle in such a manner as to interfere with or obstruct a mailbox. All state and federal regulations regarding mailbox placement and mail delivery shall apply. 
(Code 1982, § 71.064) 
Sec. 82-127. - Prohibited parking in residential districts.
