_____
(c)  Septic tank exception to sewer system development charges. All properties in the service area which are served by septic tank service on May 26, 1994, shall retain the privilege to pay the one-time charge per sewer unit served of $450.00 per ERU (in-City) or $563.00 per ERU (outside-City) at any time within one year from the date that sewer service is available at the site as verified and recorded in the office of the City Department of Public Works in lieu of the required sewer system development charges. All affected property owners will be notified when sewer becomes available and as to the date of beginning of the one-year period. Those exercising this privilege shall pay regular sewer availability charges and commodity charges upon the next regular billing cycle after application, and thereafter. 
(d)  Additional costs: 
(1)  In City. All costs germane to the construction, installation and maintenance of the sewer facility from the customer's building to the customer's property line shall be paid by the property owner. 
(2)  Outside City-Contiguous. If the property is contiguous to the City limits, the applicant shall annex the property into the City. The property owner shall then be responsible for those cost as "in-City," above. 
(3)  Outside City-Not contiguous. All costs germane to the construction, installation and maintenance of the sewer facility from the customer's building to the customer's property line shall be paid by the property owner. The affected property owner shall also pay for all costs germane to the construction, installation and maintenance of the extension of the sewer facility from the customer's property line to the then existing public sewer, the costs shall be added to the fees identified in Subsections (a) and (b) of this Section. 
(Code 1982, §§ 50.12(C), 50.23; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 718, § III, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 94-799, § VI, 5-16-94; Ord. No. 95-831, § I, 7-17-95; Ord. No. 96-854, § I, 1-15-96; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 05-1171, § 1, 9-26-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 12-1382, § 1, 11-13-12; Ord. No. 13-1392, § 1, 7-8-13; Ord. No. 14-1403, § 2, 2-10-14; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B, 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-69. - Application for service. 
(a)  Generally; fee. All applications for utility service must be made in writing at the office of the Public Works Department and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $30.00 for initiation of utility service. The owner or authorized occupant of the premises proposed for utility service must sign the application for utility service. 
(b)  Application to constitute contract; withdrawal. The application for utility service becomes a binding contract upon both the owner or occupant and the City. Prior to the installation of the service connections, the owner or occupant may cancel or withdraw the application upon his written order, subject to the restrictions contained in this Article. 
(c)  Annexation agreement. If application is made for City sewer service to property located outside the City limits that is contiguous to the existing City limits, the owner of the property shall simultaneously annex the property into the City as a prerequisite to the provision of sewer service to the property. If application is made for City sewer service to property located outside the City limits that is not contiguous to the existing City limits, the owner of the property shall simultaneously execute an agreement to annex the property into the City when the property becomes contiguous to the City limits. 
(Code 1982, § 50.24(A)-(C); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 718, § IV, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Sec. 86-70. - Deposit. 
(a)  Required; amount. 
(1)  The following deposit shall be required at the time of each new sewer installation or from each new owner or occupant of a sewer unit served: 
Meter Size 
 (inches) Minimum 
Deposit 5/8 × 3/4 $   120.00 1    160.00 11/2    240.00 2    480.00 3    960.00 4    1,440.00 6  2,400.00  
The Director of Finance or his or her designee may, at his sole discretion, prescribe an additional deposit for two-inch or larger meters based on unusual anticipated sewer use. 
(2)  As an alternative to any of the deposits required in Subsection (a)(1) of this Section, three times the estimated monthly bill shall be paid, whichever required amount is greater. 
(3)  In the alternative, as to the above-required deposits, an applicant for a 5/8 - × 3/4-inch meter may furnish a letter of credit reference from a previous utility company showing a history of nondelinquent payments for the latest 12-month period, and an applicant for a one-inch or larger meter may furnish a bank letter of credit in a form acceptable to the City Attorney. Customers subsequently delinquent in the payment of their sewer bill shall be reassessed the deposit required by subsections 86-70(a)(1), (2), and (4) plus all delinquent charges. 
(4)  After initiation of the sewer service, if the average monthly usage increases by more than 25 percent over prior usage, the Director of Finance or his or her designee may reassess the deposit required of the owner or occupant of a sewer unit in accordance with Subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this Section. 
(b)  Refunds. Deposits required by this Section shall constitute a guarantee to the City that all sums of money due by virtue of the furnishing of sewer service to the person making the deposit will be fully paid. Upon the payment of all such sums, the City shall, upon the disconnection of sewer service, refund and return to the person making such deposit the amount of the deposit or the net balance thereof after deducting those sums due the City. The customer shall be paid as required by state law. If the user maintains a good and timely payment record of the user's utility bills for a minimum period of two years, the Director of Finance shall refund the sewer deposit. Customers subsequently delinquent in the payment of their utility bill shall be reassessed the deposit required by Subsection (a) of this Section, plus all delinquent charges. 
(c)  Waiver. If a customer is presently being provided service by the City, and, after review of the previous 12 months' payment records, the customer has not been delinquent, the deposit to initiate utility service at a new address on the utility system will be waived. Customers subsequently delinquent in the payment of their sewer bill shall be reassessed the deposit required by subsections (a)(1), (2) and (4) of this Section, plus all delinquent charges. 
(d)  Special fund. All deposits made under the provisions of this Section shall be deposited in the City's Pooled Cash interest bearing account with the deposits being segregated in a separate general ledger account and interest earned being apportioned to the separate general ledger account based on average daily balance per month. 
(e)  Interest. Customer meter deposits shall accrue interest commencing on the first day following the month of initial deposit. No interest shall be paid if a customer closes or finalizes his account at any time within six months from the date of interest accrual. Total accrued interest shall be credited to the account of the customer when a customer closes or finalizes his account at any time after the expiration of six months from the date of interest accrual. All bills shall be finalized at the end of each month. Accrued interest shall be credited to the accounts of all eligible customers once each year during October, and shall not exceed the undistributed accrued interest actually paid by the City's depository. 
(Code 1982, § 50.24(D)-(H); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 718, § IV, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 764, § II, 7-7-93; Ord. No. 01-1038, § I, 10-8-01; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-71. - Changes to variable rate flow charge; optional unit charge for certain properties. 
(a)  In order to ensure that the City derives sufficient revenues to offset future increases in operation and maintenance costs (nondebt service costs) of service from the South Seminole and North Orange County Wastewater Transmission Authority and sewage treatment at the Iron Bridge facility, an adjustment to the variable rate flow charge will be made as described in this Section. 
(b)  The base sewer variable rate flow charge is established by this Article. Any subsequent change upward or downward from this base sewer variable rate flow charge as required to accommodate Orlando's Iron Bridge charges and South Seminole and North Orange County Wastewater Transmission Authority charges will be reflected in a proportionate change in the base variable rate flow charge for each 1,000 gallons above zero. The Director of Public Works and the City Manager shall be responsible to expeditiously compute and establish the necessary adjustment and notify the City Commission of the adjustment. The adjustment shall take effect 60 days from the date the City Commission is notified of the change. 
(Code 1982, § 50.12(A), (B); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
_____

_____
Sec. 86-73. - Metering device required. 
    Users who do not have a metered municipal supply of water on the effective date of the ordinance from which this Article is derived shall be required to install a metering device approved by the City and pay necessary installation fees and the appropriate user rates. 
(Code 1982, § 50.14; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-74. - Irrigation meter. 
    A customer who consumes significant amounts of potable water that is not returned to the sewer system (i.e., used for irrigation) may apply for a separate additional irrigation meter and pay necessary installation fees and rates and charges applicable thereto. 
(Code 1982, § 50.15; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-75. - Determination of flow for non-metered water users. 
(a)  Any owner or occupant of a lot, parcel of land or building which discharges sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, water or liquid wastes into the City system, directly or indirectly, who is not a metered customer of water supplied by the City shall pay appropriate user rates for all wastes entering the City system. 
(b)  If the waste entering the system is not measured by a meter or is measured by a meter not acceptable to the City, then the amount of water entering the system shall be determined or measured by the City so as to apply appropriate user rates, or the owner or party in possession of the property, at his expense, may install and maintain meters, weirs, volumetric measuring devices or other adequate and approved measurement apparatus acceptable to the City for the determination of sewage discharge into the City system. 
(Code 1982, § 50.16; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-76. - Determination of flow for partially metered water users. 
(a)  Any owner or occupant of a lot, parcel of land or building which discharges sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, water or liquid wastes into the City system, directly or indirectly, who is a metered customer of water supplied by the City, and in addition uses water from another source, a part of which or all of which is discharged into the City system, shall pay appropriate user rates for all wastes entering the City system. 
(b)  That portion of the waste entering the system that is not measured by a meter or is measured by a meter not acceptable to the City shall be determined or measured by the City so as to apply appropriate user rates, or the owner or party in possession of the property, at his expense, may install and maintain meters, weirs, volumetric measuring devices or other adequate and approved measurement apparatus acceptable to the City for the determination of sewage discharge into the City system. 
(Code 1982, § 50.17; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-77. - Adjustment of flow charge when portion of water used does not enter sewer system. 
(a)  For any owner or occupant of a lot, parcel of land or building which discharges sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, water or liquid wastes into the City system, directly or indirectly, using water in excess of 10,000 gallons per month, if it can be shown to the satisfaction of the City that a portion of the measured water, after calculating the appropriate return factor utilized in establishing the variable rate flow charge set out in this Article, does not enter the sanitary sewer system, then the owner, occupant or other interested party, at his expense, shall install and maintain meters, weirs, volumetric measuring devices or other adequate and approved measurement apparatus acceptable to the City for the determination of sewage discharge. 
(b)  Deficiencies in amounts of waste entering the sanitary sewer system shall require the equitable adjustment by the City of the variable rate flow charge of the customer. 
(Code 1982, § 50.18; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-78. - Adjustment of flow charge for mass quantity water uses. 
    The City may, in its discretion, make equitable adjustments in the variable rate flow charge when the metered water supply is used for fire protection and other mass quantity uses. 
(Code 1982, § 50.19; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-79. - Charges for service rendered to City. 
    The City and its several departments and divisions shall pay rates and charges for sewer service rendered to the City in harmony with those rates and charges established in this Article. 
(Code 1982, § 50.20; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-80. - Sampling and analysis of high strength waste. 
(a)  In order that rates and charges may equitably reflect the services received, the City shall base its sewer service charges not only on the parameters otherwise enumerated in this Division, but also on the strength and character of the sewage and waste transported or disposed of. 
(b)  When the City, in its discretion, determines that a user may be discharging a waste of higher strength than specified in Section 86-82, or is otherwise discharging substances above limits specified in this Article, it shall require the owner or other user to measure and determine the strength and content of all sewage and waste discharged, either directly or indirectly, into the City's sewer system, in such manner and by such method as shall be deemed necessary and practical in light of all conditions and attending circumstances of each case, in order to determine conformance with this Article and the proper user charge. 
(c)  The owner or other user shall establish a central sampling point, which shall be available to the City at all times. All sampling shall be done by the City or its approved designee using approved methods. All measurements and tests shall be paid for by the user. If the results of the tests are questionable or challenged, then two or more additional samples and tests shall be taken at intervals specified by the City or its approved designee. 
(d)  Samples shall be analyzed in accordance with procedures set forth in 40 CFR 136 and Chapter 62-160, F.A.C., as may be amended from time to time. 
(e)  If the test results confirm a sewage discharge other than domestic, the user shall pay for all additional samplings and tests and shall pay that surcharge established by the City. If the discharge is shown to be domestic in nature, then the City shall pay for all samplings and tests, from initial to final. 
(Code 1982, § 50.21; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-81. - Surcharge for high strength waste. 
(a)  The City Commission is authorized to prohibit the discharge of wastes into the City's sewer system which, in its discretion, are deemed harmful or otherwise undesirable. The City of Orlando, owner of the Iron Bridge plant which provides sewage treatment service to the City, has the authority to pass on a surcharge to the City for treating any sewage which exceeds the average domestic strength as described in this Article. The City will likewise pass on the surcharge to the contributing source. 
(b)  The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand or suspended solids greater than 300 parts per million respectively by weight, or containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in sections 86-111 and 86-112, shall be subject to the review and approval of the City. 
(c)  Where necessary, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand and the suspended solids to the maximum limits provided for in sections 86-111 and 86-112. Plans, specifications and other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the City, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approval is obtained in writing. 
_____
(d)  Extra charges based on the strength of the sewage and liquid wastes shall be made on the following basis: 
(1)  High strength BOD. The surcharge for high strength BOD in dollars shall be computed by multiplying the total milligrams per liter of BOD above 300 milligrams per liter times the metered water used during the billing period, in millions of gallons, times a treatment surcharge factor. The surcharge factor shall be derived annually from the following formula: 
BOD surcharge factor = Cost of treatment per million gallons / 300 
where cost of treatment per million gallons equals operational costs of the City's sewage treatment plant and the Iron Bridge treatment plant costs for the preceding fiscal year (including pro rata administrative costs) divided by the total sewage flow through all plants in millions of gallons, and 300 equals the maximum normal BOD content expressed in milligrams per liter. 
(2)  High strength TSS. The surcharge for high strength TSS in dollars shall be computed by multiplying the total milligrams per liter of TSS above 300 milligrams per liter times the metered water used during the billing period, in millions of gallons, times a treatment surcharge factor. The surcharge factor shall be derived annually from the following formula: 
TSS surcharge factor = Cost of treatment per million gallons / 300 
where cost of treatment per million gallons equals operational costs of the City's sewage treatment plant and the Iron Bridge treatment plant costs for the preceding fiscal year (including pro rata administrative costs) divided by the total sewage flow through all plants in millions of gallons, and 300 equals the maximum normal TSS content expressed in milligrams per liter. 
_____
(4)  Excess nitrogen. There shall be an additional charge of $0.02 per pound of nitrogen in excess of a concentration of three milligrams per liter in the liquid waste being discharged into the system. 
(5)  Excess phosphorus. There shall be an additional charge of $0.06 per pound of phosphorus in excess of a concentration of ten milligrams per liter in the liquid waste being discharged into the system. 
(Code 1982, § 50.22; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-82. - Billing; payment of charges; termination of service. 
(a)  Sewer bills shall be rendered monthly and shall be included with the water, garbage and utility tax bill, but each charge shall be shown as a separate item on the bill. The sewer bill is due and payable when rendered. If payment is not received by the City in full prior to the due date of the customer's next monthly bill, the unpaid amount is to be considered in arrears and delinquent. If there is an arrearage amount due when the next monthly bill is printed, a late fee will be assessed at the rate of 11/2 percent per month on the arrearage amount, or $5.00, whichever amount is greater. The words "second notice" will appear on the monthly bill along with the late fee charges. When this occurs, the arrearage, late fee and current charges must be paid in full by the due date noted on the "second notice" bill or all utility services will be discontinued the day after the due date. 
(b)  If a consumer receives both water and sewer service, nonpayment of either the water or sewer bill shall constitute a delinquency under this Section and authorize abatement of service by the City. 
(c)  The Director of Public Works shall impose a shutoff fee in the sum of $30.00 on all sewer service accounts which have been shut off pursuant to subsections (a) and (b) of this Section. Where service has been disconnected, service will not resume until the amount due, which includes the arrearage, late fee, current charges and the sum of $30.00, representing a shutoff fee, has been paid to the City. 
(d)  Voluntary shutoff or termination and all deposits, terms of deposits, charges and conditions germane thereto can be arranged in advance with the Director of Public Works or his or her staff. 
(Code 1982, § 50.25; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 718, § V, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 736, § I, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 03-1083, § 1, 6-9-03; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Sec. 86-83. - Review of rates and charges. 
    In order that the rates and charges for sewer services may remain fair and equitable and be in proportion to the cost of providing services to the various users, the City shall cause a study to be made every three to five years from the effective date of the ordinance from which this Article is derived. Such study shall include but shall not be limited to an analysis of the costs associated with the treatment of excessive strength effluent from industrial users, the volume and delivery flow rate characteristics attributed to the various users or user classes, the financial position of the sewage systems, and the adequacy of all revenues to provide reasonable funds for required retirement of debt and debt service, operation and maintenance, replacements and capital improvements to the sewer system. The studies shall be conducted by a firm of certified public accountants or a firm of consulting engineers, which firms shall have experience in conducting such studies. 
(Code 1982, § 50.26; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 718, § VI, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 764, § IV, 7-7-93; Res. No. 94-845, § I, 6-20-94; Ord. No. 02-1050, § 1, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Sec. 86-84. - Accounting procedures and funds. 
(a)  Separate accounting procedures and funds shall be established for the collection, investment and disbursement of revenues generated and costs associated with the sewer service provided under this Article. 
(b)  A minimum amount of the sewer revenues as required by bond covenants shall be retained in the renewal, replacement and betterment fund to be used as needed during the service life of the sewage system for renewal, replacement and betterment of sewage system equipment and collection facilities as needed to provide and maintain a complete and operable system capable of maintaining the standards for which it was designed. This amount shall be revised annually to reflect current renewal, replacement and betterment requirements. 
(Code 1982, § 50.27; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-85. - Changes to renewal, replacement and betterment allowance. 
    Replacement shall be recalculated each year by reviewing the records maintained for equipment, structures and other properties. If the previous year's replacement value is determined to be adequate based on the previous year's operating records, it shall remain the same. If it is anticipated that the replacement item will cost more than anticipated at the end of its service life, or if its service life will be shorter than previously estimated, the renewal, replacement and betterment allowance shall be increased. If it is anticipated that the item's replacement cost will be less than anticipated, or if the service life is deemed longer, the renewal, replacement and betterment allowance shall be decreased. 
(Code 1982, § 50.28; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-86. - Right of City to prohibit discharge of harmful wastes or limit connections to system. 
(a)  The City is hereby authorized to prohibit dumping of wastes into the City's sewer system which, in its discretion, are harmful to the operation of the sewage works. The City may require effective pretreatment methods of wastes to reduce the harmful characteristics of the waste in a fashion satisfactory to the City. 
(b)  The City reserves the right to limit connections to its system should insufficient capacity be available in the system. 
(Code 1982, § 50.29; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Secs. 86-87-86-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Roadway and utility construction, Ch. 68. 

Sec. 86-96. - Application for service; permit. 
(a)  Application for service. 
(1)  Written application for sanitary sewer service within the service area shall be made to the City at least ten working days before the service is desired. 
(2)  All costs, charges, fees and deposits incident thereto shall be paid with the application, or as specified by agreement, pursuant to Section 86-3. The application shall be on forms furnished by the City and shall constitute an agreement by the applicant with the City to abide by the provisions of this Article and such applicable rules of the City in regard to the use of its sewer system as may from time to time be operative and effective. Applications for service by firms, partnerships, associations and corporations shall be tendered only by heir duly authorized agents, and the official title of those parties shall be affixed to the applications. 
(3)  If any person shall fail, neglect or refuse to make application to connect to the sanitary sewer system as prescribed in this Section, after 60 days' notice by mail or publication that such sewer system is available, the City shall charge the same rates as would be in effect as if the connection had been made, and the City may, in its discretion, connect any such person's plumbing to the sanitary sewer system and charge the entire cost of the connection to the property so connected. These costs shall include the stabilization fee which is applicable to that structure at the time of connection to the public sewer. 
(b)  Permit required; cancellation of permits. 
(1)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the City Public Works Department. 
(2)  Any person who shall neglect, refuse or fail to correct any defect in workmanship to the City's satisfaction following a ten-day notice by the City to make such correction shall be notified of cancellation of all current permits. 
(3)  A permit for a building sewer and connection shall not be construed to be a permit or approval to do excavations in any public or private street, parkway, alley, sidewalk, terrace or curb. Approval of any such excavation must be obtained from the appropriate regulatory agency. No excavation shall be started until all permits have been received by the applicant. 
(c)  Responsibilities of owner. All costs of labor and materials for the construction, installation and maintenance of the building sewer from the building drain to the connection to the public sewer system shall be borne by the owner, tenant or occupant requesting such construction, installation and connection. All such construction, installation, connection and maintenance shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the City building code and other applicable ordinances. 
(d)  Responsibilities of City. The City shall be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the public sewer and for providing service to receive the approved sewage discharge from the building sewers. 
(e)  Contractor's license required. Before a permit shall be issued, a person must first secure a license as provided in this Section. 
(f)  Issuance of permit; bond. Any competent person who qualifies by furnishing the City satisfactory proof that he is a licensed plumber on contract by either the state or county, and providing a bond of an amount determined by the City in favor of the City, written on proper bond forms, may be issued a construction permit. The bond shall be issued in accordance with F.S. § 255.05, and shall cover all permits and work done during the life of the bond. 
(Code 1982, § 50.42(A); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 14-1403, § 3, 2-10-14) 
Sec. 86-97. - Separate building sewer required for every building; exceptions. 
(a)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except, where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(b)  Other exceptions may be made for multi-family, apartment and commercial enterprises. The resulting network of building sewers shall be considered as one sewer, and shall be the sole responsibility of the owner. The total number of units and the size of the building sewer shall be as determined by the Director. Existing multiple services on the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this Article is derived are excepted from the provisions of this Section. Other exceptions will be allowed only by special permission granted by the Director. 
(Code 1982, § 50.42(B)(1), (2); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-98. - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers, or portions thereof, may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test supervised by the City, at the expense of owner, to meet all requirements of this Article. 
(Code 1982, § 50.42(B)(3); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 86-99. - Construction standards. 
    All construction materials or methods utilized for connection or transmission to a public sewer shall be in accordance with the City's standard sewer construction specifications or the provisions of this Article, whichever is more stringent and deemed appropriate by the City. 
(1)  Pipes and fittings. The building sewer shall be constructed of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastic pipe and fittings, meeting the requirements of ASTM D-3034, Schedule 40, with joints meeting the requirements of ASTM D-1869. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the pipe shall be laid on a suitable improved bed or cradle as approved by the City. All joints shall be made in strict accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 
(2)  Minimum size and slope. The size of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the City, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-half inch per foot (two percent grade). The minimum slope for larger size pipe shall be per City requirements. 
(3)  Elevation; cover; cleanouts. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation well below the floor. In all cases, the building sewer shall be suitably protected against damage by a sufficient earthen cover or other protective means, or special pipe shall be used. The building sewer shall be laid at a uniform grade and in straight alignment, as far as possible. Changes in grade or alignment shall be made only at manholes and fittings, as approved by the City. A cleanout shall be provided five feet from the structure on a building sewer at the right-of-way line, and at other locations, such as at fittings or at changes in grade or alignment, where determined necessary by the Director. The building sewer shall have a minimum of one foot of cover at the property line, with a minimum of 11/2 feet of cover in between. Any special conditions which may require a variance shall be approved by the Director. 
(4)  Lack of gravity flow. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved methods and discharged to the building sewer. 
(5)  Excavations. 
a.  All excavations required for the installation of the building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the City. Pipe laying and backfilling shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specifications (designation CO12), except that no backfill shall be placed and work shall not be concluded until the work has been inspected by the City. 
b.  All excavations for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. All work shall meet applicable OSHA requirements for safety. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the City. 
(Code 1982, § 50.42(C); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-100. - Connections. 
(a)  Location. 
(1)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch designated for that property, if the branch is available at a suitable location. 
(2)  The location and the existence of "Y" branches for building sewers are not the responsibility of the City. 
(3)  The cost of locating and connecting to or installing a "Y" branch shall be borne by the owner of the property. 
(4)  If the public sewer does not have a properly located "Y" branch available, a "Y" branch shall be installed in the public sewer, or the connection shall be made with a saddle of an approved type at a location approved by the City. 
(b)  Unlawful connections. It shall be unlawful for any person to connect to any sewer service, or cut in, interconnect or tap or make any alteration in any main or collection pipe of the City sewer system, or permit any connection or tapping to be made to the City sewer system on his premises or the premises occupied by him, or knowingly to use the City sewer service for connections in violation of any of the provisions of this Article or any rules or regulations adopted by the City Commission with respect thereto. 
(c)  Inspection. 
(1)  No sewer service shall be connected until the plumbing and connections incident thereto shall have been inspected and approved by the Director. 
(2)  The applicant for the building sewer shall notify the City at least one working day in advance of when the building sewer will be ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the Director. 
(d)  Connection of sources of surface runoff or groundwater. No person shall make connections of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1982, § 50.42(D); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-101. - Maintenance; removal of obstructions. 
(a)  Building sewer. The building sewer, from the building drain to the property line adjacent to the public sewer, shall be maintained by the owner, at no expense to the City. 
(b)  Public sewers. 
(1)  All expenses incurred because of repairs, including obstructions, to public sewers within the public right-of-way shall be borne by the City. 
(2)  The property owner shall furnish to the Director, upon request, a receipt for payment to a licensed plumber, who will certify that the plumber has cleaned the building lateral to or beyond the property line and that the obstruction cannot be removed. With this evidence in hand, the City will endeavor to remove the obstruction within the area of City responsibility. 
(3)  When special circumstances indicate some owner responsibility, the Director may require the owner to participate in the cost of repairs within the public right-of-way. Such participation shall be subject to review by the City Manager. 
(4)  All work performed by either the City or by an authorized contractor of the property owner shall comply with all City requirements. 
(5)  Obstruction inspection procedures shall proceed as follows: 
a.  The City shall perform an upstream manhole inspection. 
b.  If the public sewer is flowing freely, the property owner or occupant shall furnish to the City a receipt from a licensed plumber for lateral clearance within the private property and confirmation of continuing obstruction. 
c.  The City shall then remove the obstruction within the public right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 50.42(E); Ord. No. 674, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-102. - Oil and grease prevention program. 
(a)  Purpose and Intent. The purpose of this Section is to provide for the implementation of the Oil & Grease Prevention Program. The objective of the Oil & Grease Prevention Program is to minimize the introduction of fat-soluble wastes to the collection system. For the latest updates in the City's Oil & Grease Prevention Program, refer to the current edition of City of Casselberry Oil/Grease Program Manual. 
(b)  Prevention Program-General Criteria. 
(1)  The discharge by a user to the POTW of certain liquids or wastes may be prohibited or limited by the provisions of this Article. 
(2)  Wastes which contain oil or grease may be discharged to the POTW in accordance with the conditions set forth in this Article. 
(3)  Wastes containing food-related oil and grease shall be directed to the oil and grease pretreatment device. 
(4)  Wastes containing residual petroleum based oil and grease shall be directed to the oil/water pretreatment device. 
(5)  Sanitary facilities and other similar fixtures shall not be discharged to the oil and grease or the oil/water pretreatment devices. 
(6)  Liquid wastes shall be discharged to the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device through the inlet pipe only in accordance with the design/operating specifications of the device. 
(7)  Oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be installed in a location which provides easy access at all times for inspections, cleaning and proper maintenance, including pumping. Oil and grease pretreatment devices shall not be located in or near any part of a structure where food handling is done. The Public Works Director or assignee shall approve the location of the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment devices prior to installation. 
(8)  Establishments (users) that prepare, process or serve food or food products shall have an oil and grease pretreatment device. Establishments that have the potential to discharge wastes containing residual petroleum based oil and grease, such as commercial laundries, car washes and automotive related facilities, shall have an oil/water separator. Other nonresidential users such as multiple family homes and/or apartment complex may be required by the Director to install an oil and grease or an oil/water pretreatment device, as appropriate, for the proper handling of wastes containing oil and grease exceeding 100 mg/l by weight. 
(9)  Oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be installed at the user's expense. Proper operation, maintenance and repair shall be done solely at the user's expense. 
(c)  Design. 
(1)  Oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be designed and constructed in accordance with this Article, the City's Engineering Standard Manual, the City's Oil/Grease Program Manual (latest edition) other applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. The Director or assignee shall approve design and construction. 
(2)  Oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall have a minimum of two compartments and shall be capable of separation and retention of oil and grease and storage of settleable solids. 
(3)  The design of oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be based on peak flow and when applicable, capable of treating emulsions. Oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be sized to allow efficient removal (retention) of the oils and grease from the user's discharge to the POTW. 
(4)  Alternative oil and grease removal technologies shall be subject to written approval by the Director and shall be based on demonstrated (proven) removal efficiencies. 
(5)  An adequate number of inspection and monitoring points, such as a manhole, shall be provided. Covers shall have a gas-tight fit. Where additional weight loads may exist, the oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be designed, constructed and installed for adequate load bearing capacity. 
(6)  New Facilities. On or after the effective date of this Article, facilities likely to discharge oil or grease, which are newly proposed or constructed, or existing facilities which shall be expanded or renovated to include a food service facility where such facilities did not previously exist, shall be required to install an approved, properly operated and maintained oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment devices. Sizing calculations shall be in accordance with the formulas listed in the City's Oil/Grease Program Manual (latest edition). Oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment devices shall be installed and approved for operation prior to the opening or reopening of said facilities. 
(7)  Existing Facilities. 
a.  On or after the effective date of this Article, existing food service or automotive related facilities shall be required to install an approved properly operated and maintained oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device when any of the following conditions exist: 
1.  The facilities are found by the Director to be contributing oils and grease in quantities sufficient to cause line stoppages or necessitate increased maintenance on the collection system. 
2.  Remodeling of the food preparation or kitchen waste plumbing facilities, which are subject to a permit issued by the building department. 
3.  Remodeling of an automotive related enterprise, commercial laundry or other users that potentially may contribute wastes with petroleum based oils and greases. 
4.  Multiple homes such as condominium and/or apartment complex. 
5.  The compliance date under this Subsection (c) shall be determined by the Director. 
b.  On or after the effective date of this Article, existing food service facilities that already have an under-the-sink oil and grease pretreatment device installed shall be evaluated by the City to determine whether the device meets the current requirements of Chapter 10 of the Florida Building Code-Plumbing as reiterated in the City's Oil/Grease Program Manual. 
(8)  Extensions. Any requests for extensions to these required installation dates must be made in writing to the Director, at least 15 days in advance of the compliance date. The written request shall include the reasons for the user's failure or inability to comply with the compliance date set forth, the work accomplished, the additional time needed to complete the remaining work, and the steps to be taken to avoid future delays. 
(d)  Maintenance. 
(1)  Cleaning and maintenance shall be the responsibility of the user. Cleaning shall include the complete removal of all contents, including floating materials, wastewater, and bottom sludge solids. 
(2)  Decanting or discharging of removed waste back into the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment devices from which the waste was removed for the purpose of reducing the volume to be disposed of is prohibited. 
(3)  Oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be pumped out completely a minimum of once every three months, or more frequently as needed to prevent carry-over of oil and grease into the collection system, unless it can be demonstrated satisfactorily to the Director that the pumping frequency can be extended past the three-month period. Refer to the City's Oil/Grease Program Manual. 
(4)  Under-the-sink grease traps shall be pumped out completely a minimum of once a week, or more frequently as needed, to prevent carryover of oil and grease into the collection system. 
(5)  Pumping frequency shall be determined by the Director based on flows, quantity of oil and grease in the discharge, volume of business, hours of operations and seasonal variations. The user shall be responsible for maintaining the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device in such a condition for efficient operation. Wastes removed from each oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device shall be disposed of at a facility permitted to receive such wastes, in accordance with the provisions of this Article. In no way shall the pumpage be returned to any private or public portion of the collection system or the treatment plants, without prior written approval from the Director. 
(6)  Additives placed into the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device, or building discharge line system on a constant, regular or scheduled basis shall be approved by the Director in writing in advance. Such additives shall include, but not be limited to, emulsifiers, enzymes, commercially available bacteria or other additives designed to absorb, purge, consume, treat or otherwise eliminate grease and oils. The use of additives in no way shall be considered as a substitution for the maintenance procedures required herein. 
(7)  Flushing the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device with water having a temperature in excess of 140°F shall be strictly prohibited. 
(e)  User Identification. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any facility producing oils and grease to discharge waste into the collection system without authorization from the Director. Authorization shall be given in the form of an oil and grease discharge permit. Application for a permit shall be made to the Director. If, after examining the information contained in the oil and grease discharge permit application, it is determined by the Director that the proposed facility does not conflict with the provisions of the Article, a permit shall be issued allowing the discharge of such wastes into the collection system. Each oil and grease discharge permit shall be issued for a time not longer than two years from the date of the permit. The user shall apply for permit reissuance a minimum of 60 days prior to the expiration of the user's existing permit. The terms and conditions of the permit may be subject to modification by the City during the term of the permit as limitations or requirements as identified in this Article are modified or other just causes exist. The user shall be informed of any proposed changes in the issued permit at least 60 days prior to the effective date of the change(s). Any changes or new conditions in the permit shall include a reasonable schedule for compliance. 
(2)  As a condition precedent to the granting of an oil and grease discharge permit, the recipient under this Section shall agree to hold harmless the City and the City's employees from any liabilities arising from the permit holder's operations under this permit. 
(3)  A fee for oil and grease discharge permit shall be set by the City. The fee shall be established to insure full cost recovery and shall include but not be limited to the cost of field, administrative, engineering and clerical expenses involved. The permit fee shall be paid in accordance to the schedule set forth in the City's Oil/Grease Program Manual, current edition. 
(f)  Administrative Procedures. 
(1)  Pumpage from oil and grease and oil/water pretreatment devices shall be tracked by a manifest, which confirms pumping, hauling and disposal of waste. This manifest shall contain the following information: 
Generator 
Information: Transporter 
Information:   
Name _____ Company 
Name _____ Address _____ Address _____ Telephone 
Number _____ Telephone 
Number _____ Volume Pumped _____ Volume Pumped _____ Date and time of 
pumping _____ Date and time of 
pumping _____ Name and Signature of 
generator _____ Driver Name and 
Signature _____ Verifying generator 
information 
and service _____ Verifying transporter 
Information and 
service _____  
Destination Disposal Site/Facility Information 
Company Name/ 
Permit Number(s) _____ 
Contact Person(s) _____ 
Address _____ 
Telephone Number _____ 
Location of Disposal 
Site/Facility _____ 
Volume Treated _____ 
Date and Time 
of Delivery _____ 
Driver Name, Signature 
and Vehicle No. _____ 
Name and Signature of 
operator verifying _____ 
Disposal site/ 
facility information _____ 
(2)  A log shall be maintained of pumping activities for the previous 12 months. The log shall be posted in a conspicuous location for ready and immediate access by City personnel. The log shall include the date, time, volume pumped, hauler's name and license number and hauler's signature. The log shall be kept on file at the user's facility for a minimum of three years. The user shall report pumping activities within 48 hours to the Director on the form so designated by the City for such purposes. A copy of the form shall be kept in a file at the user's facility for a minimum of three years. The user shall maintain a file on site of the records for the facility's oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment devices. The file contents shall include the record (as-built) drawings, record of inspections, receipts, log of pumping activities, log of maintenance activities, hauler information, disposal information and monitoring data. The file shall be available at all times for inspection and review by City personnel. 
(3)  The Director may require the user to provide, operate and maintain, at the user's expense, appropriate monitoring facilities, such as a manhole, that are safe and accessible at all times, for observation, inspection, sample collection and flow measurement of the user's discharge to the POTW. 
(g)  Enforcement. 
(1)  A Notice of Violation shall be issued to a user for failure to: 
a.  Pay program fees; 
b.  Report pumping activities; 
c.  Properly maintain (clean-out or pump) the pretreatment device in accordance with the provisions of the oil and grease discharge certificate; 
d.  Maintain and post the log of pumping activities; 
e.  Maintain a file of records on site at all times; 
f.  Provide logs, files, records or access for inspection or monitoring activities; and 
g.  Obtain or renew the oil and grease discharge permits. 
(2)  The City may serve any user a written notice stating the nature of violation. The user shall have 72 hours to complete corrective action and submit evidence of compliance to the Director. 
(3)  If a user violates or continues to violate the provisions set forth in this section or fails to initiate/complete corrective action in response to a Notice of Violation, then the Director may pursue one or more of the following options: 
a.  Pump the oil and grease or oil/water pretreatment device and place the appropriate charge on the user's monthly sewer bill; 
b.  Collect a sample and assess the appropriate surcharge(s) for compatible wastes in accordance with the provisions of this Article; 
c.  Impose an administrative penalty; 
d.  Assess a reasonable fee for additional inspection, sample collection and laboratory analyses; and 
e.  Terminate water and sewer service. 
(4)  Progressive enforcement action shall be pursued against users with multiple violations of the provision of this Section. 
(5)  The user must pay all outstanding fees, penalties and other utility charges prior to reinstatement of water and sewer service. 
(h)  Surcharge Program. 
(1)  General Criteria. 
a.  Significant commercial users, as defined in this Article, shall be subject to a surcharge on discharges to the POTW. 
b.  A surcharge may be assessed for any discharge of abnormally high strength compatible wastes as defined herein. 
c.  The surcharge in dollars shall be computed by multiplying the difference in the concentration in mg/l above the defined limitations for each applicable constituent times the conversion factor of 8.34 times the potable water consumption or metered sewer flow during the billing period in millions of gallons (MG) times the respective treatment surcharge factor. 
d.  The surcharge factor shall be derived each year using the following formula and shall be set forth in the schedule of fees: 
Surcharge factor = Total Cost of  Treatment ($)  Maximum 
Constituent 
loading (lbs.)  
Where: 
Total cost of treatment is the total operational costs including prorated administrative costs for the POTW during the preceding fiscal year. 
Maximum normal constituent loading is the product of the constituent limit for each compatible waste times a conversion factor of 8.34 times the total wastewater flow for the POTW. 
Surcharge factor shall be expressed in dollars per pound. 
e.  The Surcharge shall be calculated as the product of the current surcharge factor times the difference of the constituent concentration and the maximum allowable limit for the compatible waste constituent in mg/l times the conversion factor of 8.34 times the total flow in million of gallons during the billing cycle. 
(i)  Flow Determination. 
(1)  The flow volume for determination of the surcharge shall be based on one of the following: 
a.  Metered water consumption as shown in the records of meter reading made by the utility authority; 
b.  Flow monitoring devices, which measure the actual volume of wastewater, discharged to the POTW and as approved by the Director or designee. 
c.  Flow monitoring devices for other water supplies proceeded from other sources besides the utility authority; or 
d.  Flow monitoring devices other than those for the utility authority shall be provided, installed, calibrated and maintained at the users expense and in accordance with the plans that were approved by the Director or designee. Flow monitoring devices shall be calibrated at least annually. 
(j)  Constituent Concentration. The concentration of constituents in the users discharge to the POTW shall be determined by samples collected and analyzed by authorized City personnel. Samples shall be collected in accordance with EPA protocols or Standard Methods and in such manner to be representative of the actual discharge to the collection system. Samples shall be analyzed in accordance with procedures set forth in 40 CFR 136 and Chapter 62-160, F.A.C., as may be amended from time to time. The surcharge shall be based on the determination of the constituent concentration by the Director or designee. 
(k)  Monitoring. 
(1)  Authorized City Personnel will collect samples routinely. 
a.  Samples will be collected routinely of discharges from users that are known to be or suspected of containing abnormal high strength compatible wastes. 
b.  Samples may be collected manually or using automatic sampling equipment. Grab samples may be taken manually. Composite samples may be retrieved with automatic sampling equipment or performed manually with aliquots of grab samples. 
c.  To the extent possible, samples will be collected to obtain a representative characterization of the users discharge. Samples may be flow or time proportional. 
d.  Users shall install and maintain an appropriate monitoring facility including, but not limited to, a control manhole and suitable automatic-sampling equipment. Monitoring sites and facilities shall be accessible to City personnel. 
e.  The costs of sample analyses performed by a certified commercial laboratory shall be assessed directly to the user. 
f.  The user may request that the sample analyses be performed by an independent, certified commercial laboratory. The costs for such analyses shall be borne by the user. 
g.  The charges for sample collection and analysis (laboratory work) shall be those rates as described in the schedule of costs (fees) for the certified commercial laboratory current under contract with the City as described in the City's Oil/Grease Program Manual. 
h.  The costs of sample collection and analysis may be assessed daily by the Director or assignee if such monitoring activities indicate that the wastes are unacceptable or detrimental to the POTW. 
i.  Significant commercial users may be assessed the costs for sample collection and laboratory analyses, not to exceed one monitoring activity per billing period. Charges for additional sample collection and laboratory analyses may be assessed on a daily basis as long as the results show that the user is discharging unacceptable wastes to the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01; Ord. No. 03-1108-A, § 1, 12-8-03) 
Sec. 86-103. - Groundwater remediation and miscellaneous discharges. 
(a)  Groundwater Remediation Discharges. 
(1)  Purpose. 
a.  The purpose of this Section is to provide for the discharge of treated groundwater from remediation sites by users to the collection system without causing pass through, upset or interference at the WRF's. 
(2)  General Criteria. 
a.  The discharge by a user to the POTW of certain liquids or wastes may be prohibited or limited by the provisions set forth in this Article or by decision of the Director. 
b.  Groundwater from remediation sites shall be pretreated prior to discharge to the POTW. 
c.  A groundwater remediation facility that discharges to the City shall be classified as a significant industrial user. The user shall submit an industrial wastewater discharge permit application to the Director. The Director may require complete characterization of the groundwater prior to and following treatment (remediation). 
d.  The Director may impose limitations and monitoring requirements for the treated discharge to the POTW in accordance with the provisions of this Article; and standards set forth in Chapter 62-550, F.A.C. 
e.  The user shall not discharge untreated or treated groundwater to the POTW without written approval of the Director or an industrial wastewater discharge permit. 
f.  A flow-monitoring device shall be installed on the discharge line in accordance with the plans approved by the Director and the manufacturers recommendations. The flow monitoring shall be provided, installed, calibrated and maintained at the user's expense. The flow measuring devices shall be calibrated quarterly. 
g.  The user shall provide a monitoring point at its expense for the calibration of sampler and field data (physical parameters). 
h.  Groundwater treatment systems shall be designed and operated in accordance with the best available technology and as approved by the Director. 
i.  Pursuant to the provisions of the industrial user discharge permit, the Director shall require the discharge to the collection system to be monitored on a regular basis for the determination of compliance with the limits set forth in this Article. 
(b)  Miscellaneous Discharges. 
(1)  Purpose. 
a.  The purpose of this Section is to provide for the discharge of other types of discharges to the POTW, including, but not limited to, uncontaminated groundwater, roof drainage, cooling water, unpolluted process water and miscellaneous pumpage. 
(2)  General Criteria. 
a.  The user shall notify the Director in writing prior to the discharge of miscellaneous types of flows. 
b.  The user may be required to submit an industrial wastewater permit application to the Director. 
c.  The Director may impose restrictions, prohibitions or other provisions on the discharge in accordance with this Article. 
d.  The Director may limit the volume of and duration of the discharge to the POTW. The user shall be responsible for measurement of the flows to the POTW at their expense. The flow-monitoring device shall be provided, installed and maintained in accordance with the guidelines set forth by the Director. 
e.  The user shall not discharge these types of flow without prior written notice from the Director or issuance of a permit. 
(c)  Medical Waste. 
(1)  Hospitals, clinics, medical/dental practitioners offices, convalescent and nursing homes, medical/dental laboratories and funeral homes shall dispose of medical waste, pathological waste, laboratory waste, contaminated medical waste and waste from expired humans (corpses) in accordance with the latest edition of guidelines that are published by EPA, the Center for Disease Control (CDC), the Public Health Department, other appropriate Federal and State agency or the City's Pretreatment Program which ever may be the more stringent. 
(2)  Toxic, biological or contaminated wastes, which are not addressed by the aforementioned guidelines, shall not be discharged to the City's wastewater collection system without written permission from the Director. 
(3)  Hospitals, clinics, medical/dental practitioner offices, convalescent and nursing homes, medical/dental laboratories and funeral homes shall prepare and maintain a Biomedical Waste Plan for review of the Director. 
(4)  Enforcement actions shall proceed in accordance with the provisions set forth in this Chapter. 
(d)  Sand and Grit Interceptors. 
(1)  Purpose. 
a.  The purpose of this Section is to minimize the introduction of sand and grit into the collection system. 
(2)  General Criteria. 
a.  The discharge by a user of the POTW of liquids containing certain constituents may be prohibited or limited pursuant to the provisions of this Article. 
b.  Wastes containing excessive amounts of sand and grit shall be directed to the interceptor (trap). 
c.  Sand and grit interceptors (traps) shall be provided at the user's expense. The interceptor shall be installed, operated and maintained in accordance with the plans approved by the Director and the manufacturer's recommendations. 
d.  Sand and grit interceptors shall be designed and installed to accommodate the anticipated range of flows. 
e.  Sand and grit interceptors shall be installed for easy access for cleaning and inspection. Sand and grit interceptors shall be serviced and emptied of their contents on a regularly scheduled basis to maintain efficient operation at all times. 
f.  Wastes removed from the sand and grit interceptors shall not be discharged into the POTW. The user shall maintain a log of cleaning activities and a file on site of the records and documents related to the sand and grit interceptor. Record/documents retained in the file should include as-built drawings, manufacturers instructions, log of cleaning activities, receipts, hauler information, site inspection reports and monitoring data. 
Failure to comply with the provisions set forth herein can result in implementation of enforcement procedures in this Article. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Secs. 86-104-86-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PRETREATMENT PROGRAM 

Sec. 86-111. - Prohibited discharge standards. 
(a)  Use of storm sewers and sanitary sewers. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff (including runoff from downspouts), subsurface drainage (including drainage from foundation drains), swimming pool drainage, condensate, deionized water, noncontact cooling water or any pollutant or wastewater to any sanitary sewer. Likewise, the discharge of sanitary sewer or other wastes into any storm sewer is prohibited. 
(b)  General prohibitions. No person shall introduce into a WWF any pollutant, which causes pass through or interference. These general prohibitions and the specific prohibitions in (c) below apply to each industrial user introducing pollutants into a WWF whether or not the industrial user is subject to other pretreatment standards, or any national, State or local pretreatment requirements. 
(c)  Specific Prohibited discharges. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer: 
(1)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant; 
(2)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works; 
(3)  Solids or viscous substances in quantities or of a size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or interference as defined in Section 86-27(a) (96), such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastic, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper, dishes, cups, milk containers and the like. Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants, released in a discharge at a flow rate or pollutant concentration which will cause interference with the WWF; 
(4)  Heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the WWF resulting in interference, but in no case heat in such quantities that result in the discharge from treatment plant having a temperature that exceeds 40°C (104°F); 
(5)  Wastewater causing any single reading on an explosion hazard meter equal to or greater than five percent at the point of discharge into the POTW, or at any point in the POTW as calibrated using propane for 100 percent of the meter; 
(6)  Any liquids or gases which, by reason of their nature or quantity, may cause fire or explosion, or be injurious in any other way to the sewers, the treatment works structures, or the operation of the treatment works, or cause the effluent from the treatment works to violate applicable effluent standards, including but not limited to waste streams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit or 60 degrees Celsius using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21; 
(7)  Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the WWF in a quantity that will cause acute worker health and safety problems; 
(8)  Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the Control Authority. 
(9)  Any substance which may cause the POTW's effluent, or any other product of the POTW, such as residues, sludge's or scum's, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse, or which may interfere with the reclamation process where the POTW is pursuing a reuse and reclamation program. In no case shall a substance discharged to the POTW cause the POTW to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed under Section 405 of the Act, or any criteria, guidelines or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used; 
(10)  Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, solids, or other wastewater which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or a hazard to life, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance or repair; 
(11)  Wastewater which imparts color which cannot be removed by the POTW treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, which consequently imparts color to the treatment plant's effluent, thereby violating the City's NPDES permit; 
(12)  Wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes except in compliance with applicable State or Federal regulations; 
(13)  Sludges, screenings, or other residues from the pretreatment of industrial wastes; 
(14)  Medical biological wastes, or biohazard except as specifically authorized by the Director in a wastewater discharge permit; 
(15)  Detergents, surface-active agents, or other substances which may cause excessive foaming in the POTW; 
(16)  Fats, oils, or grease of animal or vegetable origin in concentrations greater than 100 mg/l.; or 
(17)  Pollutants, substances, or wastewater prohibited by this Section shall not be processed or stored in such a manner that they could be discharged to the POTW. 
(d)  Local Pollutants Limits. The following local pollutants limits shall not be exceeded: 
Contaminant Maximum 
Concentration (mg/l) Antimony 1.25 Arsenic (total) 0.25 Barium (total) 4.5 Beryllium 0.25 BOD 500 Boron* 2.5 Cadmium (total) 0.20 Chlorides 225 Chromium (total) 0.5 Cobalt 0.65 Copper (total) 0.66 Cyanide 0.35 Lead (total) 0.25 Lithium 0.5 Manganese (total) 2.5 Mercury (total) 0.005 Molybdenum 0.30 Nickel (total) 1.1 pH Less than 5.5 or greater than 9.5 units Phenols (total) 3.0 Selenium (total) 0.2 Silver 0.12/BMP Sodium 300 Zinc (total) 1.4  
* The pollutant limits set out in this Subsection are established to protect against pass-through and interference and apply at the point where the wastewater is discharged to the POTW. All concentrations for metallic substances are for "total" metal unless indicated otherwise. 
(1)  The pollutant limits set out in this Subsection may be adjusted and additional pollutant limits added from time to time based on treatment plant monitoring, water quality requirements, field investigation of industrial users, and/or any other factors which the Director deems of significance with respect to the proper and safe operation of the POTW. The Director may impose mass limitations in addition to, or in place of, the concentration based limitations above. 
(2)  The installation of a garbage disposal into a commercial food facility is prohibited by the City of Casselberry. 
(3)  Any waters or waste containing phenols or other taste or odor producing substances in such concentration exceeding limits which be established by the Director as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal or other public agencies having jurisdiction over such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(3)  Stormwater, surface water, ground water, artesian well water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, swimming pool drainage, condensate, deionized water, noncontact cooling water, treated hazardous waste and unpolluted wastewater, unless specifically authorized by the Director. 
(4)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids, such as but not limited to fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime residues, or of dissolved solids, such as but not limited to sodium chloride and sodium sulfate. 
b.  Carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD), chemical oxygen demand (COD), or chlorine demanding compounds in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the wastewater treatment works; or 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the wastewater treatment works. 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting slug discharges as defined herein. 
(e)  Dilution. No user shall ever increase the use of process water, or in any way attempt to dilute a discharge, as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with a discharge limitation unless expressly authorized by an applicable pretreatment standard or requirement. The Director may impose mass limitations on users who are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in other cases when the imposition of mass limitations is appropriate. 
(f)  Additional requirements for industrial users. Industrial users shall observe and comply with any and all present and future regional, state and local laws, rules, regulations, requirements, ordinances, orders, mandatory guidelines and procedures, which apply or pertain to the collection, treatment and disposal of wastewater. 
(g)  Conflicting requirements; right of City to revise discharge limitations. State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those in this Article. The City reserves the right to establish by ordinance or through permit conditions more stringent limitations, requirements or time periods on discharges to the wastewater disposal system if deemed necessary to comply with the objectives stated in this Article. The revisions to discharge limitations in this Article or in individual permits will be initiated by the Director when necessary. Affected parties will be duly notified and will have the opportunity to comment on the revisions prior to their adoption or incorporation. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-112. - Applicability of federal categorical pretreatment standards. 
(a)  Compliance with national categorical pretreatment standards. The national categorical pretreatment standards specify quantities or concentrations of pollutants or pollutant properties, which may be discharged into the POTW. All industrial users subject to a national categorical pretreatment standard shall comply with all requirements of such standard, which includes any monitoring or reporting requirements, and shall also comply with any additional or more stringent limitations contained in this Article. 
(b)  Upon the promulgation of the federal categorical pretreatment standard for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed under this Article for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed under this Article. The Director shall notify all affected users of the applicable reporting requirements. 
(c)  Where the City's wastewater treatment system achieves consistent removal of pollutants limited by federal pretreatment standards, the City may apply to the Approval Authority for removal credits in accordance with 62-625.420, F.A.C. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-113. - Maintenance of internal plumbing system and building sewer. 
(a)  All building sewers connected to the municipal wastewater and sewage system shall have an internal plumbing system, which meets or exceeds the standards of the Standard Plumbing Code or any other regulation adopted by the City. 
(b)  The owner of the property served by the public sewer shall be responsible for the proper operation and maintenance of the building sewer, specifically, all plumbing from the public sewer into and including the building drain. 
(c)  The City shall have the right to inspect the building sewer and to cause discontinuance of water and/or sewer service to any property where the plumbing is not maintained in a sanitary and effective operating condition or if the public sewer facilities may be harmed thereby. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
DIVISION 6. - INDUSTRIAL WASTEWATER DISCHARGE PERMIT 

Sec. 86-114. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-115. - Pretreatment facilities. 
(a)  If pretreatment is required through the issuance of an industrial wastewater discharge permit as provided in Division 6 of this Article, users of the POTW shall design, construct, operate and maintain such wastewater pretreatment facilities whenever necessary to reduce, modify or eliminate the user's wastewater discharge to achieve compliance with the limitations in wastewater strength set forth in Section 86-111, to meet applicable national categorical pretreatment standards, or to meet any other wastewater condition or limitation contained in the user's permit. If required by the City, plans, specifications and operating procedures for such wastewater pretreatment facilities shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer, and shall be submitted to the Director for review. Prior to beginning construction of the pretreatment facility, the user shall submit a set of final construction plans and specifications to the Director. Prior to beginning construction, the user shall also secure such building, plumbing or other permits as may be required by City ordinance. A compliance schedule and reporting procedures will be established in the industrial wastewater discharge permit in accordance with Section 86-131(g). The user shall construct the pretreatment facility within the time provided in the user's wastewater discharge permit. Following completion of construction, the user shall provide the Director with as-built drawings. Neither the filing of the plans nor the issuance of a permit shall be construed to indicate that the City in any way vouches for or warrants the performance capabilities of any facilities constructed pursuant to such plans, specifications or data. Subsequent alterations or additions to such pretreatment or flow-control facilities shall not be made without prior notice to the City. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-116. - Control manhole. 
(a)  Required for certain users (requiring pretreatment before discharging to the City's WWF). The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control structure or manhole, together with necessary meters and other appurtenances, in the building sewer, to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. 
(b)  Location; approval of plans. The structures, manholes and appurtenances shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Director. 
(c)  Payment of costs; maintenance. The structures, manholes and appurtenances shall be installed by the owner, at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(d)  Notice to install. The owner shall install the structures, manholes and appurtenances within 30 days from the date the lateral connection is made to the sewer, or, if no structure, manhole or appurtenance was required at the time the building sewer was installed, the owner shall install the structure, manhole or appurtenance within 30 days of written notice by the City as to the need and requirement for them by the City. 
(e)  Installation by City. 
(1)  If the manhole is not installed within the time provided in this Section, the City shall have the right to enter into a contract for installation of the manhole at the owner's expense, and the cost of installing the manhole, together with the administrative cost to the City necessary to process the installation of the manhole, shall be chargeable to the owner. 
(2)  If not paid within 30 days from the date installation is completed, the unpaid costs, together with lawful interest thereon, shall be a lien upon the property wherein the user is situated. The City shall be entitled to institute foreclosure proceedings for the collection of the unpaid costs and interest thereon. Such proceedings shall be conducted in accordance with law. The City shall be entitled to collect reasonable attorney's fees from the owner for services rendered by the City's attorneys in the institution and prosecution of the foreclosure proceedings.
