(3)  Liens created under this Section shall, upon the request of the user or owner of the property affected, and upon payment of all installation and administrative costs and lawful interest thereon, be released by a certificate signed by the Mayor or the City Clerk and bearing the seal of the City. The issuance of such certificate shall constitute prima facie evidence of the existence or nonexistence of any such unpaid costs, and shall, in the absence of fraud perpetrated by the party requesting it, be binding upon the City as to the existence or nonexistence of any lien created under this Section. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-16-01) 
Sec. 86-117. - Tests and analyses. 
(a)  All tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in sections 86-111, 86-112 and 86-116 shall be performed by a certified laboratory in accordance with the techniques prescribed in 40 CFR 136, entitled "Guidelines Establishing Test Procedures for Analysis of Pollutants," as published in the October 16, 1973, Federal Register, or a method approved by the EPA and the City, and shall be determined at the control structure provided for in Section 86-116, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. 
(b)  If no special structure has been required, the control structure shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected; provided that the City shall be permitted to take samples within the premises of the user, including samples from lagoons, ponds and other places. 
(c)  Any user of the sewage system, which has been found to be discharging pollutants, which exceed those mentioned in Subsection (a) of this Section, shall be charged with the cost of testing and analysis. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-118. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-119. - Industrial waste surcharges. 
(a)  Such producers of industrial waste or other mixtures as indicated in this Article, for which the cost of treatment is greater than the normal fees and charges paid by such a producer, shall pay to the City a sewer service surcharge. 
(b)  The sewer service surcharge shall be determined by sampling and testing or contract. In either case, payments shall be based upon current surcharge rates as defined in the City's user charge system. 
(c)  The individual user shall, on a regular basis, sample and have analyzed by a certified testing laboratory the flow of industrial waste or other mixtures as indicated in Division 6 of this Article to determine the quantity and quality of effluent under average conditions, and a surcharge shall be charged and billed to the producer of excess wastes on a quarterly basis. 
(1)  Three-month periods shall begin as contractually arranged between the City and the industrial user. 
(2)  Periods of less than three months will be billed for on a prorated basis. 
(3)  The City shall sample industrial effluent at its discretion. 
(d)  In cases where the contract method is used, billing by the City shall be made as provided in Subsection (c) of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-120-86-130. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-131. - Acceptance of hazardous wastes; user classes; permit fee. 
(a)  If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Section 86-111, and which in the judgment of the Director of Public Works may have a deleterious effect on the public sewer system, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise may create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the Director may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition prior to discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; or 
(4)  Require payment pursuant to the provisions of this Article to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
(b)  The following must appear in the permit application: 
(1)  Notification procedures, including those for immediately notifying the Director and a list of contact persons and telephone numbers for those responsible to monitor the permit. 
(2)  Procedures to prevent adverse impacts from any accidental or sludge discharge. Such procedures shall include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Maintenance of storage areas. 
b.  Handling and transfer of materials. 
c.  Loading and unloading operations. 
d.  Control of plan site runoff. 
e.  Worker training. 
f.  Building of containment structures or equipment. 
g.  Measures for containing toxic organic pollutants, including solvents. 
h.  Measures and equipment for emergency response. 
(3)  Description of employee training programs to prevent accidental or sludge discharges and how to handle such episodic occurrences. 
(c)  The class descriptions and permitting fee shall be as follows: 
Class Description (1) Class One Categorical Industrial Users shall obtain a "Discharge Permit". Inspections site will be made by the City to assure compliance with local and federal regulations. Refer to Section 86-27(a)(24) for definition and examples. (2) Class Two Significant Industrial Users- Users shall obtain a "Discharge Permit" and periodic site visit will be made by the City to assure compliance with local and federal regulations. Refer to Section 86-27 (a)(193) for definition and examples. (3) Class Three Significant Commercial User, users shall obtain a "Discharge Permit" and periodic site visit will be made by the City to assure compliance with local and federal regulations. Refer to Section 86-27(a)(192) for definition and examples. (4) Class Four Oil and Grease Discharger -User shall obtain an "Oil and Grease Discharge Permit" and periodic site visit will be made by the City to assure compliance with local and federal regulations. Refer to Section 86-27(a)(121) for definition and examples.  
(d)  Any user or industry storing hazardous or toxic chemicals on the site shall submit a spill containment plan to the City. 
(e)  All Classes shall be assessed a permit fee. The Director will assign cost of the permit on a case-by-case basis. The minimum amount for each permit will be $50.00. This fee will be adjusted according to the complexity of the application. 
(f)  If the Director permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the Director and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the permit holder, at his expense, as required by this Article. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-132. - Application and issuance; conditions. 
(a)  Permit required. All industries whose discharge could render them a significant industrial user or whose discharge otherwise may have a deleterious impact on the public sewer system, as determined by the Director, shall obtain a permit prior to discharge of industrial wastewaters. 
(b)  Existing dischargers. All dischargers of industrial wastewater into the City's sewer system prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this Article is derived are hereby granted temporary authority to continue to discharge industrial wastewaters in compliance with the City's codes, regulations and policies. This temporary authority shall expire 90 days after the date of notification by the Director of the requirement for a discharger to make application for an industrial wastewater discharge permit. If, prior to the expiration date, the discharger has filed for an industrial wastewater discharge permit pursuant to subsections (a) and (d) of this Section, then its temporary authority to discharge will continue. In such case, this temporary authority shall expire on the date the industrial wastewater discharge permit is issued or denied. Any person discharging pursuant to the temporary authority provided in this Subsection is subject to all provisions of this Article, and such authority may be suspended or revoked in accordance with the terms and procedures set forth in this Article. 
(c)  Compliance with conditions. No permit holder shall discharge industrial wastewaters in excess of the quantity, rate of discharge or quality conditions specified in the permit. Any person desiring to modify his discharge in a manner, which would violate conditions of his permit, shall apply for an amended permit. 
(d)  Application. Existing and proposed new industrial users seeking a permit shall complete and file with the City an application in the form prescribed by the City. Proposed new industrial users shall file their applications at least 90 days prior to their discharging to the POTW. The applicant shall submit, where appropriate: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number and location, if different from the address, of the applicant, the name of the owner of the premises from which industrial wastes are intended to be discharged, and the name of a local representative duly authorized to act on behalf of the company. 
(2)  The SIC number according to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Bureau of the Budget, 1972, as amended or as amended in the future. 
(3)  Average daily and three-minute peak wastewater flow rates, including daily, monthly and seasonal variations, if any. 
(4)  A schedule of all industrial process waste flows produced before and after pretreatment, if any, at the premises, including daily volume and wastewater constituents and characteristics as determined by representative samples and analyses done by a qualified laboratory acceptable to the City and in accordance with standard methods. 
(5)  Estimated time and duration of discharge within a 20 percent tolerance. 
(6)  Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans and details to show all sewers, sewer connections and appurtenances by size, location and elevation and all points of discharge. 
(7)  A description of each product produced, by type, amount, process and rate of production. 
(8)  A description of the type and amount of raw materials processed, including average and maximum per day. 
(9)  The number and type of employees, and hours of operation of the plant and proposed or actual hours of operation of the pretreatment system. 
(10)  Any other information as may be deemed by the City to be necessary to evaluate the permit application. 
(11)  Permit fees as determined by the Director upon recommendation of City Commission. 
(e)  Application signatories and certification. All wastewater discharge permit applications and user reports must be signed by an authorized representative of the user and contain the following certification statement: 
"I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations." 
(f)  Issuance. 
(1)  The Director will act only on applications that are accompanied by a report, which contains all the information required in Subsection (d) of this Section. Persons who have filed incomplete applications will be notified by the Director that the application is deficient and notified of the nature of such deficiency, and will be given 30 days to correct the deficiency. Upon receipt of complete applications, the Director shall review and evaluate the applications and shall propose such special permit conditions as he deems advisable. All industrial wastewater discharge permits shall be expressly subject to all the provisions of this Article and all other applicable ordinances, laws and regulations. 
(2)  Upon completion of his evaluation, the Director shall notify the applicant of any special conditions, which he proposes to be included in the permit. The applicant shall have 30 days from and after the date of the recommendations of the Director for special permit conditions to review the conditions and file written objections with the Director regarding any such special permit conditions. The Director, but shall not be required to, schedule a meeting with the applicant's authorized representative within 15 days following receipt of the applicant's objections, and attempt to resolve disputed issues concerning special permit conditions. If the applicant files no objection to special permit conditions proposed by the Director, or if a subsequent agreement is reached concerning such conditions, the Director shall issue an industrial wastewater discharge permit to the applicant with such special conditions incorporated therein. 
(3)  Issuance of a permit shall not relieve the discharger from complying with all applicable laws, regulations and ordinances promulgated by other government authority, nor shall the issuance of a permit by construed as a representation by the City that the discharge permitted therein complies with all of such laws, regulations and ordinances. Permits are issued solely to govern the discharge of wastewater into the public sewer system and the applicable receiving waters, are between the discharger and the City, and shall not be construed to benefit any third party. 
(g)  Permit requirements and restrictions. The requirements and restrictions in permits shall be uniformly enforced by the City, and will include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  A statement that indicates wastewater permit duration (which in no event shall exceed five years). 
(2)  A statement that the wastewater discharge permit is non-transferable without prior notification to the City in accordance with Section 86-132 and provisions for furnishing the new owner or operator with a copy of the existing wastewater discharge permit. 
(3)  The maximum permissible concentration of wastewater constituents based on applicable pretreatment standards or local limits which ever is the most stringent. 
(4)  Limits on the rate and time of discharge, or requirements for flow regulation and equalization. 
(5)  Self-monitoring, sampling, reporting, notification, and record-keeping requirements. These requirements should include an identification of pollutants to be monitored, sampling, location, sampling frequency, and sample type based on Federal, State or local law. 
(6)  Pretreatment of industrial wastewater before discharge. 
(7)  Compliance schedules, including requirements for periodic compliance reports, which shall be submitted a minimum of twice per year on categorical industries. 
(8)  Specifications for self-monitoring programs, which may include sampling locations, frequency and method of sampling, flow metering, number, types and standards for tests and reporting schedule. 
(9)  Prohibition of discharge of certain wastewater constituents. 
(10)  Requirements for submission of periodic discharge reports, to include information concerning volume, rate of flow, constituent concentrations, peak flow rates, hours of operation, number of employees or other information. 
(11)  Requirements for maintaining and retaining plant records relating to wastewater discharge as specified by the City, and affording the City access thereto. 
(12)  Requirements for notification of the City for any new introduction of wastewater constituents or any substantial change in the volume or character of the wastewater constituents being introduced into the wastewater treatment system. 
(13)  Requirements for notification of slug or accidental discharges. 
(14)  Statement of applicable civil and criminal penalties for violation of pretreatment standards and requirements, and any applicable compliance schedule. Such schedule may not extend the time of compliance beyond that required by applicable Federal, State or local law. 
(15)  A statement of the confidentiality of this Code. 
(16)  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the City to ensure compliance with this Article. 
(17)  Prohibition of use of dilution as a substitute for treatment. 
(h)  The City may require that any or all of the pretreatment requirements or restrictions be provided by the user, at his expense. 
(i)  Duration. Permits shall be issued for any specified period of time, not to exceed five years. 
(j)  Modification. The terms and conditions of any permit may be subject to modification and change by the City during the life of the permit to accommodate changed conditions and as local, state, regional and federal laws, rules and regulations and case decisions are modified or amended. Permit holders shall be informed of any proposed changes in their respective permits at least 60 days prior to the effective date of change, and shall be allowed a comment period relating to any of the proposed changes in their permits within the first 30 days after issuance of such proposed change by the City. The City shall allow a discharger a reasonable period of time to comply with any changes in the permit required by the City, unless otherwise required by emergency or governmental regulations. The permit holder may petition the City for modification of permit based on changed conditions. The Director shall review such petition with such supporting data as he deems necessary and take appropriate action. 
(k)  Multiple connections; transfer. A separate permit shall be required for each wastewater connection discharging directly or indirectly into the sewer system. For each discharger having multiple connections at a single plant or facility, a single permit shall be required, which may set forth specific effluent limitations and conditions for discharge from each separate connection. Wastewater discharge permits are issued to a specific user for a specific operation. A wastewater discharge permit shall not be assigned or transferred or sold to a new owner or new user, or used for different premises, unless approved by the Director, and any such attempted assignment, transfer or sale shall be void and of no affect. 
(l)  Renewal. The industrial user will be required to apply for permit renewal a minimum of 180 days prior to the expiration of the user's existing permit. Any modification request must be accompanied by supporting data and will be reviewed in accordance with this Article. 
(m)  Appeals. The Director shall provide public notice of the issuance of a wastewater discharge permit. Any person, including the user, may petition the Director to reconsider the terms of a wastewater discharge permit within 30 days of notice of its issuance. 
(1)  Failure to submit a timely petition for review shall be deemed to be a waiver of the administrative appeal. 
(2)  In its petition, the appealing party must indicate the wastewater discharge permit provisions objected to, the reasons for this objection, and the alternative condition, if any, it seeks to place in the wastewater discharge permit. 
(3)  The effectiveness of the wastewater discharge permit shall not be stayed pending the appeal. 
(4)  If the Director fails to act within 30 days, a request for reconsideration shall be deemed to be denied. Decisions not to reconsider a wastewater discharge permit, not to issue a wastewater discharge permit, or not to modify a wastewater discharge permit shall be considered final administrative actions for purposes of judicial review. 
(5)  Aggrieved parties seeking judicial review of the final administrative wastewater discharge permit decision must do so by filing a complaint with the Eighteenth Judicial Circuit Court in and for Seminole County within 30 days of final administrative action on the petition for review. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-133. - Spill containment plan; notification of discharge. 
(a)  Each industrial user shall be required to establish a spill containment plan. The plan shall contain the following elements: 
(1)  Protection from accidental discharges. Each user shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this Article. Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the owner's or user's own cost and expense. Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the City for review, and shall be approved by the City before construction of the facility. All existing users shall complete such a plan by the date specified by the industrial wastewater discharge permit. No new user who begins discharge to the POTW after the effective date of the ordinance from which this Article is derived shall be permitted to introduce pollutants into the system until accidental discharge procedures have been approved. 
(2)  Telephone notification. Any person causing or suffering any discharge, whether accidental or not, which presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health and welfare of persons or to the environment, or which is likely to cause interference with the POTW, shall notify the Director immediately by telephone. In the absence or unavailability of the Director, notification shall be given to the City employee then in charge of the treatment works. 
(3)  Written report; control of discharge during restoration of treatment facility. Within five days following such occurrence, the user shall provide the Director with a detailed written report describing the cause of the dangerous discharge and measure to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage or other liability which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, fish kills or any other damage to person or property, no shall such notification relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties or other liability which may be imposed by this Article or other applicable law. Furthermore, the industrial user shall control its production, or all its discharges, to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with all applicable City, state and federal regulations upon reduction, loss or failure of its treatment facility and until the facility is completely restored or an alternative and equally effective method of pretreatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility is reduced, lost or fails. 
(4)  Notice to employees. A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of a dangerous discharge. Employers shall ensure that all employees who may cause or suffer such a dangerous discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-134. - Confidentiality of information. 
(a)  Information and data on a user obtained from reports, surveys, wastewater discharge permit applications, wastewater discharge permits, and monitoring programs, and from the Director's inspection and sampling activities, shall be available to the public without restriction, unless the user specifically requests, and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Director that the release of such information would divulge information, processes, or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets under applicable State law. Any such request must be asserted at the time of submission of the information or data. When requested and demonstrated by the user furnishing a report that such information should be held confidential, the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public, but shall be made available immediately upon request to governmental agencies for uses related to the NPDES program or pretreatment program, and in enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics and other "effluent data" as defined by 40 CFR 2.302 will not be recognized as confidential information and will be available to the public without restriction. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-135. - Sampling fees. 
(a)  Annual operation costs of the City's POTW for activities required under this Division shall be recovered, at the City's option, through fees charged to the industries and users. Each user may be billed for each scheduled, unscheduled or demand monitoring visit performed. The billing may include direct costs incurred by the City, or its authorized agent, in sampling, inspecting and laboratory analyses, adjusted to reflect administrative, legal and other indirect costs incurred by activities that may be required under this Division. All self-monitoring costs incurred by any user, including but not limited to the cost of sampling, analysis and reporting, shall be borne by the user. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-136. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-137. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-138. - Reports. 
(a)  Industrial users subject to categorical pretreatment standards (categorical industrial users) and industrial users not covered by categorical pretreatment standards (noncategorical industrial users) shall submit to the Control Authority such reports as are necessary to assess and assure compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements, including but not limited to baseline monitoring reports (BMRs), 90-day compliance reports, and periodic compliance reports required under 62-625.600, as it may be from time-to-time amended. 
(b)  All reports submitted by an industrial user pursuant to its permit shall be certified: 
(1)  By a responsible corporate officer, if the industrial user submitting the reports required by Subsection (a) of this Section is a corporation. For the purpose of this Subsection, a responsible corporate officer means (i) a president, secretary, treasurer, or vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation, or (ii) the manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than 250 persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding $25,000,000.00, if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
(2)  By a general partner or proprietor if the industrial user submitting the reports required by Subsection (a) is a partnership or sole proprietorship, respectively. 
(3)  By a duly authorized representative of the individual designated in Subsection (b)(1) or (b)(2) of this Section if: 
a.  The authorization is made in writing by the individual described in Subsection (b)(1) or (b)(2) of this Section; 
b.  The authorization specifies either an individual or a position having responsibility for the overall operation of the facility from which the industrial discharge originates, such as the position of plant manager, operator of a well, or well field superintendent, or a position of equivalent responsibility, or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company; and 
c.  The written authorization is submitted to the Control Authority. 
(4)  If an authorization under Subsection (b)(3) of this Section is no longer accurate because a different individual or position has responsibility for the overall operation of the facility, or overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, a new authorization satisfying the requirements of Subsection (b)(3) of this Section must be submitted to the Control Authority prior to or together with any reports to be signed by an authorized representative. 
a.  Such certification shall read as follows: 
"I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete, I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations." 
(c)  Baseline Monitoring Reports. 
(1)  Within either 180 days after the effective date of a categorical pretreatment standard, or the final administrative decision on a category determination, whichever is later, existing categorical users currently discharging to or scheduled to discharge to the POTW shall submit to the Director a report which contains the information listed in paragraph (2), below. At least 90 days prior to commencement of their discharge, new sources, and sources that become categorical users subsequent to the promulgation of an applicable categorical standard, shall submit to the Director a report which contains the information listed in paragraph (2), below. A new source shall report the method of pretreatment it intends to use to meet applicable categorical standards. A new source also shall give estimates of its anticipated flow and quantity of pollutants to be discharged. 
(2)  Users described above shall submit the information set forth below: 
a.  Identifying Information. The name and address of the facility, including the name of the operator and owner. 
b.  Environmental Permits. A list of any environmental control permits held by or for the facility. 
c.  Description of Operations. A brief description of the nature, average rate of production, and standard industrial classifications of the operation(s) carried out by such user. This description should include a schematic process diagram, which indicates points of discharge to the POTW from the regulated processes. 
d.  Flow Measurement. Information showing the measured average daily and maximum daily flow, in gallons per day, to the POTW from regulated process streams and other streams, as necessary, to allow use of the combined wastestream formula. 
e.  Measurement of Pollutants. 
1.  The categorical pretreatment standards applicable to each regulated process. 
2.  The results of sampling and analysis identifying the nature and concentration, and/or mass, where required by the standard or by the Director, of regulated pollutants in the discharge from each regulated process. Instantaneous, daily maximum and long-term average concentrations, or mass, where required, shall be reported. The sample shall be representative of daily operations and shall be analyzed in accordance with procedures set out in this Article. 
Sampling must be performed in accordance with procedures set out in this Article. 
f.  Certification. A statement, reviewed by the user's authorized representative and certified by a qualified professional, indicating whether pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis, and, if not, whether additional operation and maintenance (O&M) and/or additional pretreatment is required to meet the pretreatment standards and requirements. 
g.  Compliance Schedule. If additional pretreatment and/or O&M will be required to meet the pretreatment standards, the shortest schedule by which the user will provide such additional pretreatment and/or O&M. The completion date in this schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. A compliance schedule pursuant to this Section must meet the requirements set out in Section 86-138 of this Article. 
h.  Signature and Certification. All baseline-monitoring reports must be signed and certified in accordance with this Article. 
i.  All users not required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit shall provide appropriate reports to the Director as the Director may require. 
(d)  Compliance Schedule Progress Reports. 
(1)  The following conditions shall apply to the compliance schedule required by Section 86-138; 
(2)  The schedule shall contain progress increments in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet the applicable pretreatment standards (such events include, but are not limited to, hiring an engineer, completing preliminary and final plans, executing contracts for major components, commencing and completing construction, and beginning and conducting routine operation); 
(3)  No increment referred to above shall exceed nine months; 
(4)  The user shall submit a progress report to the Director no later than 14 days following each date in the schedule and the final date of compliance including, as a minimum, whether or not it complied with the increment of progress, the reason for any delay, and, if appropriate, the steps being taken by the user to return to the established schedule; and 
(5)  In no event shall more than nine months elapse between such progress reports to the Director. 
(e)  Reports on Compliance with Categorical Pretreatment Standard Deadline. 
(1)  Within 90 days following the date for final compliance with applicable categorical pretreatment standards, or in the case of a new source following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the POTW, any user subject to such pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit to the Director a report containing the information described in Section 86-138 of this Article. For users subject to equivalent mass or concentration limits established in accordance with the procedures in 62-625.410, F.A.C., this report shall contain a reasonable measure of the user's long-term production rate. For all other users subject to categorical pretreatment standards expressed in terms of allowable pollutant discharge per unit of production (or other measure of operation), this report shall include the user's actual production during the appropriate sampling period. All compliance reports must be signed and certified in accordance with this Article. 
(f)  Periodic Compliance Reports. 
(1)  All significant industrial users shall, at a frequency determined by the Director but in no case less than twice per year (in June and December), submit a report indicating the nature and concentration of pollutants in the discharge which are limited by pretreatment standards and the measured or estimated average and maximum daily flows for the reporting period. All periodic compliance reports must be signed and certified in accordance with this Article. 
(2)  All wastewater samples must be representative of the user's discharge. Wastewater monitoring and flow measurement facilities shall be properly operated, kept clean, and maintained in good working order at all times. The failure of a user to keep its monitoring facility in good working order shall not be grounds for the user to claim that sample results are unrepresentative of its discharge. 
(3)  If a user subject to the reporting requirement in this Section monitors any pollutant more frequently than required by the Director, using the procedures prescribed in Section 86-141, the results of this monitoring shall be included in the report. 
(g)  Reports of Changed Conditions. 
(1)  Each user must notify the Director of any planned significant changes to the user's operations or system, which might alter the nature, quality, or volume of its wastewater at least 30 days before the change. 
(2)  The Director may require the user to submit such information as may be deemed necessary to evaluate the changed condition, including the submission of a wastewater discharge permit application. 
(3)  The Director may issue a wastewater discharge permit or modify an existing wastewater discharge permit in response to changed conditions or anticipated changed conditions. 
(4)  For purposes of this requirement, significant changes include, but are not limited to, flow increases of 20 percent or greater, and the discharge of any previously unreported pollutants. 
(h)  Reports of Potential Problems. 
(1)  In the case of any discharge, including, but not limited to, accidental discharges, discharges of a nonroutine, episodic nature, a noncustomary batch discharge, or a slug load, that may cause potential problems for the POTW, the user shall immediately telephone and notify the Director of the incident. This notification shall include the location of the discharge, type of waste, concentration and volume, if known, and corrective actions taken by the user. 
(2)  Within five days following such discharge, the user shall, unless waived by the Director, submit a detailed written report describing the cause(s) of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage, or other liability, which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, natural resources, or any other damage to person or property; nor shall such notification relieve the user of any fines, penalties, or other liability which may be imposed pursuant to this Article. 
(3)  A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place-advising employees whom to call in the event of a discharge described in Subsection (1), above. Employers shall ensure that all employees, who may cause such a discharge to occur, are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-139. - Notice of violation/repeat sampling and reporting. 
(a)  If sampling performed by a user indicates a violation the user must notify the POTW within 24 hours of becoming aware of the violation. The user shall also repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results of the repeat analysis to the Director within 30 days after becoming aware of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-140. - Notification of the discharge of hazardous waste. 
(a)  Any user who commences the discharge of hazardous waste shall notify the Director, the EPA Regional Waste Management Division Director, and State hazardous waste authorities, in writing, of any discharge into the POTW of a substance which, if otherwise disposed of, would be a hazardous waste under 40 CFR Part 261. Such notification must include the name of the hazardous waste as set forth in 40 CFR Part 261, the EPA hazardous waste number, and the type of discharge (continuous, batch or other). If the user discharges more than 100 kilograms of such waste per calendar month to the POTW, the notification also shall contain the following information to the extent such information is known and readily available to the user: an identification of the hazardous constituents contained in the wastes, an estimation of the mass and concentration of such constituents in the waste stream discharged during that calendar month, and an estimation of the mass of constituents in the waste stream expected to be discharged during the following 12 months. All notifications must take place no later than 180 days after the discharge commences. Any notification under this paragraph need be submitted only once for each hazardous waste discharged. However, notifications of changed conditions must be submitted under Section 86-132. The notification requirement in this Section does not apply to pollutants already reported by users subject to categorical pretreatment standards under the self-monitoring requirements of Sections 86-138 and 86-133. 
(b)  Dischargers are exempt from the requirements of paragraph (a), above, during a calendar month in which they discharge no more than 15 kilograms of hazardous wastes, unless the wastes are acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e). Discharge of more than 15 kilograms of nonacute hazardous wastes in a calendar month, or of any quantity of acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e), requires a one-time notification. Subsequent months during which the user discharges more than such quantities of any hazardous waste do not require additional notification. 
(c)  In the case of any new regulations under Section 3001 of RCRA identifying additional characteristics of hazardous waste or listing any additional substance as a hazardous waste, the user must notify the Director, the EPA Regional Waste Management Waste Division Director, and State hazardous waste authorities of the discharge of such substance within 90 days of the effective date of such regulations. 
(d)  In the case of any notification made under this Section, the user shall certify that it has a program in place to reduce the volume and toxicity of hazardous wastes generated to the degree it has determined to be economically practical. 
(e)  This provision does not create a right to discharge any substance not otherwise permitted to be discharged by this Article, a permit issued thereunder, or any applicable Federal or State law. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § I, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-141. - Analytical requirements. 
(a)  All pollutant analyses, including sampling techniques, to be submitted as part of a wastewater discharge permit application or report shall be performed in accordance with the techniques prescribed in Chapter 62-160 F.A.C., unless otherwise specified in an applicable categorical pretreatment standard. If Chapter 62-160 F.A.C. does not contain sampling or analytical techniques for the pollutant in question, sampling and analyses must be performed in accordance with procedures approved by FDEP Standard Operating Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-142. - Sample collection. 
(a)  Except as indicated in Subsection (b) below, the user must collect wastewater samples using flow proportional composite collection techniques. In the event flow proportional sampling is infeasible, the Director may authorize the use of time proportional sampling or a minimum of four grab samples where the user demonstrates that this will provide a representative sample of the effluent being discharged. In addition, grab samples may be required to show compliance with instantaneous discharge limits. 
(b)  Samples for oil and grease, temperature, pH, cyanide, phenols, sulfides, and volatile organic compounds must be obtained using grab collection techniques. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-143. - Timing. 
(a)  Written reports will be deemed to have been submitted on the date postmarked. For reports which are not mailed, postage prepaid, into a mail facility serviced by the United States Postal Service, the date of receipt of report shall govern. Data contained in the report must be from samples taken during the period covered by the report in accordance with 62-625 600(6)(c), F.A.C. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 86-144. - Record keeping. 
(a)  Users subject to the reporting requirements of this Article shall retain, and make available for inspection and copying, all records of information obtained pursuant to any monitoring activities required by this Article and any additional records of information obtained pursuant to monitoring activities undertaken by the user independent of such requirements. Records shall include the date, exact place, method, and time of sampling, and the name of the person(s) taking the samples; the dates analyses were performed; who performed the analyses; the analytical techniques or methods used; and the results of such analyses. These records shall remain available for a period of at least three years. This period shall be automatically extended for the duration of any litigation concerning the user or the City, or where the user has been specifically notified of a longer retention period by the Director. 
(Ord. No. 01-1042, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Secs. 86-145-86-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Drinking water to be provided at public places, § 50-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial includes classical commercial properties and establishments served by the municipal water system. 
    Equivalent residential unit and ERU mean equal to the average daily flow of a single-family residence, which is 250 gpd for water service. 
    Multifamily means a multiple dwelling unit of two or more units, served by one meter common to the complex, served by the municipal water system. 
    Residential includes the classical individually metered single-family residential dwelling, but also includes any dwelling unit which is individually metered, irrespective of the fact that it may be included within a multiple-unit complex, served by the municipal water system. 
(Code 1982, § 51.01; Ord. No. 719, § II, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 2 (Att. A), 10-30-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-162. - Connection with public system. 
(a)  Required. The owner of each lot, parcel or piece of land located within the municipal limits of the City, upon which any building, structure or trailer is to be installed as a dwelling for human habitation or for residential, commercial or other uses, shall cause the premises to be connected to the public water distribution system of the City. 
(b)  Time limit; exceptions. The connection of structures for residential, commercial or other uses shall be accomplished within 90 days after written notification from the Director of Public Works. However, no connection shall be required where: 
(1)  The water distribution system or water lines of the City are more than 100 feet from a lot, parcel or piece of land located within the City, and the City does not elect to extend the service to within 100 feet of any portion of the parcel to be served. 
(2)  A person would be required to traverse the private property of another in order to make the connection to the City water distribution system. 
(c)  Reimbursement of water benefit fees. 
(1)  The City agrees to contract to reimburse an applicant for extension lines for connection to the water distribution system at a rate of 40 percent of all water benefit fees paid to the City by intermediate applicants until the original applicant is reimbursed in that amount established by, and in accordance with, the contract executed prior to the installation of all intermediate lines. The reimbursement shall be payable only during the 60-month period following the installation. 
(2)  The City shall retain 60 percent of the water benefit fees collected and disburse to the original applicant 40 percent of the water benefit fees collected from intervening owners, agents, tenants or consumers. 
(3)  The City guarantees reimbursement only as intermediate properties are developed and water benefit fees are actually received by the City. All agreements for reimbursement of original water benefit fees will run for a period not to exceed 60 months from the date of initial payment, and such fees shall not bear interest. 
(Code 1982, § 51.51; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 2 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-163. - Interruption of service. 
(a)  Neither the City nor its Public Works Department guarantees an uninterrupted water supply or water at any particular pressure for any purpose. The City reserves and shall have the right to shut off water in its mains at any time for the purpose of making repairs or extensions or for other purposes incidental to a public water supply, and will not be responsible for any damage resulting from a consumer leaving a faucet open or otherwise caused by low pressure. 
(b)  The Public Works Department shall have the right to turn off water service for the protection of the City or the consumer in cases where a private water system has been installed, or where a building has burned or been razed, or where the consumer has been found to be using water illegally, and to assess the applicable fees for restoration of service. 
(Code 1982, § 51.52) 
Sec. 86-164. - Use of water from private wells. 
    The use of water from privately owned wells for household, domestic, food processing, food handling, restaurant, dairying or bottling purposes or activities is hereby prohibited and declared to be unlawful whenever and wherever water produced by the Public Works Department of the City is available for use for these purposes. The provisions of this Section shall not be construed as preventing or prohibiting the use of water from privately owned wells for sprinkling, irrigation, air conditioning and fire prevention purposes or activities. 
(Code 1982, § 51.53) 
Sec. 86-165. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-166. - Use of curb stops; right of City to shut off water. 
(a)  The curb stop on any and all service connections within the City shall not be used or manipulated by the owner, or the employee or agent of the owner, for purposes connected with turning on or shutting off the water supply. Any turning on or shutting off procedure by the owner shall be accomplished with a separate stopcock located on the owner's side of the service curb stop. All turning on or shutting off procedures of the water supply at the curb stop shall be accomplished exclusively by representatives of the Public Works Department and may result in a disconnection or connection charge of $25.00 except when the shutoff is done at the request or for the convenience of the City. 
(b)  A violation of Subsection (a) of this Section by the owner or any employee or agent of the owner or consumer shall subject the owner or consumer to a penalty of $15.00 for the first offense and up to $25.00 per offense for all subsequent offenses. Each day an offense occurs shall constitute a separate offense. For repeated offenses, the City may discontinue utility service and shut off the water supply to the premises if the Public Works Department determines that the owner or consumer is, in fact, in violation of Subsection (a) of this Section. Before a determination is promulgated by the Public Works Department, the Department shall conduct a hearing on the alleged violations and give the owner or consumer ten days' notice prior to the hearing. If the Public Works Department determines that the owner or consumer has violated Subsection (a) of this Section, then the water service shall be discontinued until the owner or consumer is capable of providing the Public Works Department with assurances that such violations will not be repeated. 
(c)  All requests of the owner or consumer for shutoff or turn-on of the water supply shall be made directly to the Customer Services Division and may result in a disconnection charge or reconnection charge of $25.00 for requests during normal business hours, Monday-Thursday (excluding City recognized legal holidays), 7:00 a.m.-6:00 p.m., or $40.00 for requests after business hours. 
(d)  In case of accident, breakdown or shortage of water supply, or for any cause beyond its control, or because of any act of commission or omission on the part of the City or its agents, or in the case of repairs, renewals or replacements of service, the City reserves the right to shut off the water supply to any consumer served by the City, without notice. This interruption in service shall not cause the City to be responsible for any damages, actions, claims of actions or consequences resulting from such shutoff. Reasonable efforts shall be made to communicate with affected customers without unnecessary delay. 
(e)  The City reserves at all times the right to shut off water supply service wherever and whenever reasonably justifiable, with or without notice, so as to protect the entire utility supply system under its control or, in case of emergencies, to preserve necessary pressure or volume for fire flows. Nothing in this Article shall be construed to require the City to give notice of the shutoff procedure. 
(f)  The discontinuance of water service through exercise of the shutoff procedure to any premises served by the City system shall not entitle the owner or consumer to an abatement or deduction in water service charges, nor shall it accelerate a refund of charges paid in advance during the shutoff period unless the shutoff period exceeds 20 consecutive days. 
(Code 1982, § 51.46; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-167. - Prevention of waste and repair of leaks. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner, agent, tenant or consumer using the City water system to exercise diligence to prevent the waste of water and to repair all leaks on his premises without unreasonable delay. The willful waste of water or failure to repair leakage without unreasonable delay or the extravagant and wasteful use of City water by any owner, agent, tenant or consumer may be cause for the City to discontinue service after a 72-hour notice if the notice is not adhered to. 
(b)  When the water supply to any premises has been shut off because of leakage, neglect or waste as provided in this Section, water service shall not be reinstated until all causes for termination have been remedied by the owner to the satisfaction of the Public Works Department. 
(Code 1982, § 51.47) 
Sec. 86-168. - Use of water during fires. 
    All consumers using the City water system shall immediately abate sprinkling of their premises upon knowledge or notice of a fire in the vicinity of their premises so that maximum pressure may be available to fight the fire. Sprinkling may be used by an owner, agent, tenant or consumer for the protection of his premises against fire in close proximity to his property. 
(Code 1982, § 51.48) 
Sec. 86-169. - Public fire hydrants. 
(a)  Installation. All fire hydrants within the City water system shall be installed by the Public Works Department in accordance with agreements entered into between the owner, agent, tenant or consumers and the City, except when installed as part of an approved development project. 
(b)  Use. 
(1)  All fire hydrants or fireplugs shall be exclusively used for fire protection. Fire hydrants or fireplugs shall not be used for sprinkling, sewer flushing, filling, watering or other purposes, except by City authorities, without a written permit from the Director of Public Works, upon consultation with the Fire Department. This permit shall be exhibited by authorized permittees when requested by City authorities. 
(2)  All permits issued by the Director of Public Works for use of fire hydrants or fireplugs for purposes other than the extinguishment of fire or wetting down of surrounding properties during a fire to prevent damage to life and property shall be revocable at the pleasure or discretion of the Director of Public Works at any time following a 24-hour notice. 
(c)  Request for additional hydrants. An owner, agent, tenant or consumer may submit a written request for additional fire hydrants from the City system subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The owner, agent, tenant or consumer shall pay for the installation of the fire hydrant or fireplug. 
(2)  The owner, agent, tenant or consumer shall pay the required annual fee to the City for rental of the fire hydrant or fireplug if the hydrant or fireplug is located on private property and is privately owned. 
(d)  Charge to City and county. The City shall pay to the Public Works Department a minimum charge of $50.00 per year for each fire hydrant located within the City right-of-way or on other City property connected to the water system inside the City limits, and in no event shall the minimum yearly charge be less than the actual cost of water consumed. The county shall pay to the Public Works Department a minimum charge of $75.00 per year for each fire hydrant connected outside the City limits and located within a county right-of-way or other public property, and in no event shall the minimum yearly charge be less than the actual cost of water consumed. 
(Code 1982, § 51.49; Ord. No. 16-1422, § 22, 5-9-16) 
Sec. 86-170. - Extension of system outside City limits. 
(a)  All extensions of the water distribution system of the City which extend beyond the municipal limits of the City shall be subject to the following extension policy: 
(1)  The applicant for water distribution service outside the municipal limits of the City shall furnish and install, at his expense, an adequate water distribution system with necessary appurtenances thereto in accordance with a written utility commitment agreement, to be executed by the City and the contractor, when the City Commission makes the determination that such a commitment is in the best interests of the City. 
(2)  The contractor shall furnish the City with plans and specifications prepared by a registered professional engineer outlining the proposed utility facilities and any other data that shall be required by the Director of Public Works. These plans and specifications shall be approved by the state board of health, the City Engineer and the Director of Public Works. 
(b)  All contracts for the installation of extraterritorial distribution systems shall be approved by the City before the installation is commenced. 
(Code 1982, § 51.50) 
Sec. 86-171. - Emergency restrictions on water use. 
(a)  Purpose; applicability. 
(1)  The purpose of this Section is to control and restrict the use of water furnished by the City or any other supplier of water for irrigation, lawn or plant sprinkling, washing automobiles and filling swimming pools on Monday through Friday of each week during the hours of 4:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m., inclusive, and to control and restrict the use of water during the continuous period from 12:01 a.m. Saturday until 11:59 p.m. of the following Sunday. The use of spray irrigation systems shall be prohibited between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. seven days each week. 
(2)  This Section shall not restrict the use of wells or irrigation systems owned and operated by citizens on their private premises, but shall apply only to water furnished to citizens by the City or any other supplier of water. Commercial carwash establishments shall also be excluded from the intent of this Section. 
(3)  The provisions of this Section shall be implemented from time to time during periods of water crises and emergencies by the City Manager, as chief executive officer of the City, and the Police Chief. The Director of Public Works shall issue timely notice during periods when consumption control is necessary. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or consume water for irrigation, lawn or plant sprinkling, washing automobiles or filling swimming pools at any time during the term of applicability of this Section on Monday through Friday during the hours from 4:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m., inclusive, and during the continuous period from 12:01 a.m. Saturday until 11:59 p.m. of the following Sunday. The use of spray irrigation systems shall be prohibited between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. seven days each week. This control of water consumption shall apply to water furnished to persons within the definition declared by the City, and shall be implemented from time to time pursuant to Subsection (a)(3) of this Section. 
(Code 1982, § 51.45) 
Sec. 86-172. - Public notice of potential lead contamination. 
(a)  The City's public water system shall identify and provide notice to persons that may be affected by lead contamination of their drinking water where such contamination results from either or both of the following: 
(1)  The lead content in the construction materials of the public water distribution system. 
(2)  Corrosivity of the water supply sufficient to cause leaching of the lead. 
The notice shall be provided in such manner and form as may be reasonably required by the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Notice under this Section shall be provided notwithstanding the absence of a violation of any national drinking water standard 
(b)  Notice under this Section shall provide a clear and readily understandable explanation of: 
(1)  The potential sources of lead in the drinking water; 
(2)  The potential adverse health effects; 
(3)  Reasonable available methods of mitigating known or potential lead content in drinking water; 
(4)  Any steps the system is taking to mitigate lead content in the drinking water; and 
(5)  The necessity for seeking alternative water supplies, if any. 
(c)  Other notices shall be provided by the City in such manner and form as may be reasonably required by federal or state environmental agencies. 
(Code 1982, § 51.65) 
Secs. 86-173-86-185. - Reserved. 
_____
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 86-186. - System development charge, tapping fees, and meter installation charge. 
(a)  Generally. There are hereby established uniform charges for the initial construction and expansion of major main lines and water supply treatment plants and plant capacity, water storage, and master pumping facilities, fire flow and pressure capacities, and other necessary water production and transmission facilities inside and outside the corporate limits of the City which shall be paid for by the user prior to hookup or as specified by agreement, pursuant to Section 86-3, for the maximum present and future performance of the waterworks system as additional connection are completed. 
(1)  Water system development charge. A one-time charge of $2.40 per gallon of capacity shall be charged to customers within the City in accordance with the following schedule: 
Description ERU (gpd) Water System Development Charge [*] Residential: Single-family 250 $600.00/unit Multi-family 188 451.00/unit Commercial / Non-Residential: 5/8" x 3/4" Meter 250 $600.00/meter 1" Meter 625 1,500.00/meter 1 1/2" Meter 1,250 3,000.00/meter 2" Meter 2,000 4,800.00/meter 3" Meter 3,750 9,000.00/meter 4" Meter 6,250 15,000.00/meter 6" Meter 12,500 30,000.00/meter 8" Meter 20,000 48,000.00/meter 10" Meter 31,250 75,000.00/meter [*] Amounts based on an adopted fee of $2.40 per gallon of capacity calculated on an average daily flow basis effective January 1, 2018.  
Notes: 
1.  One ERU factor is equivalent to 250 gallons per day calculated on an average daily flow basis. 
2.  The fees shown above reflect the minimum system development charges to be applied per unit or per meter size; however, the City may elect to charge a system development charge equal to the greater of: 1) the minimum fee per unit or meter size; or 2) an alternative method based on the total equivalent residential unit (ERU) value determined by multiplying the number of fixture units, as published in the Southern Standard Plumbing Code, by 25, and then dividing that numerator by 250 (gallons per day per ERU), then multiplying by $600.00. 
Total ERU Value = Number of fixture units x 25 / 250 
For example, the Southern Standard Plumbing Code indicates that a kitchen sink has a fixture unit value of 2. To determine the total fee, take the 2, multiply by 25, then divide by 250, then multiply by $600.00: 
2 x 25 / 250 × $600 = $120.00 
3.  For industrial facilities or other facilities where the schedule or formula set out in this Subsection is not applicable, the equivalent ERUs and flows shall be evaluated on an individual basis to determine the water system development charges. 
_____ 
(2)  Tapping fees, water. All costs germane to the installation from the customer's meter (water) to the existing main lines shall be paid by the owner for all meters greater than two inches in size. The property owner will be required to employ a qualified contractor to install a tap greater than two inches in size, and must seek City approval prior to the tap. For meters smaller than two inches, the following tapping fee schedules shall be applicable:

In addition, the share of costs associated with required expansions, extensions or upgrades to the existing public water distribution system to serve the customer shall be evaluated on an individual basis and shall be added to the fees identified in this Subsection.

A communication will be sent to each potential customer at least six months prior to the date established for completion of design, giving the potential customer 90 days to submit written application for reclaimed water service.

Sec. 86-187. - Deposit. 
(a)  Required; amount. 
(1)  The following deposits shall be required at the time of new installation or from each new owner or occupant of every water unit served: 
Meter Size (inches) Minimum 
Deposit 5/8 × 3/4 $60.00 1 81.00 11/2 120.00 2 240.00 3 420.00 4 660.00 6 1,080.00  
The Director of Finance or his or her designee may, at his sole discretion, prescribe an additional deposit for two-inch or larger meters based on unusual anticipated consumption. 
(2)  As an alternative to any of the deposits required in Subsection (a)(1) of this Section, three times the estimated monthly bill shall be paid, whichever amount is greater. 
(3)  In the alternative, as to the above-required deposits, an applicant for a ? × 3/4 inch meter may furnish a letter of credit reference from a previous utility company showing a history of nondelinquent payments for the latest 12-month period, and an applicant for a one inch or larger meter may furnish a bank letter of credit in a form acceptable to the City Attorney. Customers subsequently delinquent in the payment of their utility bill shall be reassessed the deposit required by subsections 86-187(a)(1), (2) and (4) plus all delinquent charges. 
(4)  After initiation of the water service, if the average monthly usage increases by more than 25 percent over prior usage, the Director of Finance or his or her designee may reassess the deposit required by the owner or occupant in accordance with Subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this Section. 
(b)  Refunds. Meter deposits required by this Section shall constitute a guarantee to the City that all sums of money due by virtue of the furnishing of water service to the person making the deposit will be fully paid. Upon the payment of all such sums, the City shall, upon the disconnection of water service, refund and return to the person making such deposit the amount of the deposit or the net balance thereof after deducting any sums that may be due the City. The customer shall be paid as required by state law. If the user maintains a good and timely payment record of his utility bills for a minimum period of two years, the Director of Finance shall refund the deposit. Users subsequently delinquent in the payment of their utility bill shall be reassessed the deposit required by Subsection (a) of this Section, plus all delinquent charges. 
(c)  Waiver. If a customer is presently being provided service by the City, and, after review of the previous 12 months' payment records, the customer has not been delinquent, the deposit to initiate utility service at a new address on the utility system will be waived. Customers subsequently delinquent in the payment of their utility bill shall be reassessed the deposit required by Subsection (a)(1), (2) and (4) of this Section, plus all delinquent charges. 
(d)  Special fund. All deposits made under the provisions of this Section shall be deposited in a fund known as the customers' meter deposits fund. Such funds shall be kept in an interest-bearing account separate from all other funds of the City. 
(e)  Interest. Customer meter deposits shall accrue interest commencing on the first day following the month of initial deposit. No interest shall be paid if a customer closes or finalizes his account at any time within six months from the date of interest accrual. Total accrued interest shall be credited to the account of the customer when a customer closes or finalizes his or her account at any time after the expiration of six months from the date of interest accrual. All bills shall be finalized at the end of each month. Accrued interest shall be credited to the accounts of all eligible customers once each year during October, and shall not exceed the undistributed accrued interest actually paid by the City's depository. 
(Code 1982, § 51.04; Ord. No. 719, § V, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 763, § II, 7-7-93; Ord. No. 02-1050, § 1, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17)) 
Sec. 86-188. - Fire protection fee. 
(a)  There is hereby established a uniform charge for new water service installations for internal fire protection purposes only, as follows: 
(1)  Installation charge. The charge for the installation of the line shall be the actual cost of installation, including installation of the fire line meter, for all meter sizes. 
(2)  Line size charge. The line size annual charge shall be as follows: 
Line Size 
(inches) Annual Charge 4 and below $200.00 Greater than 4 and up to and including 6  480.00 Greater than 6  760.00  
(b)  It shall be unlawful to use a fire line for domestic or commercial purposes without written authority from the Director of Public Works and the Fire Chief. Violators shall be punished in accordance with the general punishment provisions of the City. 
(c)  All private fire hydrants located on the private premises shall pay an annual hydrant fee of $100.00. 
(Code 1982, § 51.05; Ord. No. 00-984, § I, 5-1-00; Ord. No. 02-1056, § 6, 7-22-02; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
_____

No. 12-1383, § 1, 1-14-13; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
_____
Sec. 86-190. - Review of rates and charges. 
    In order that the rates and charges for utility services may remain fair and equitable and be in proportion to the cost of providing services to the various users, the City shall cause a study to be made every three to five years from the effective date of the ordinance from which this Article is derived. Such study shall include but shall not be limited to an analysis of the costs associated with the volume, and delivery flow rate characteristics attributed to the various users or user classes, the financial position of the water and reclaimed water systems, and the adequacy of all revenues to provide reasonable funds for required retirement of debt and debt service, operation, and maintenance, replacements and capital improvements to the water and reclaimed water systems. The studies shall be conducted by a firm of certified public accountants or a firm of consulting engineers, which firms shall have experience in conducting such studies. 
(Code 1982, § 51.06; Ord. No. 719, § VI, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 763, § IV, 7-7-93; Ord. No. 1050, § 1, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 02-1056, § 5, 7-22-02; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Sec. 86-191. - Billing; payment of charges; termination of service. 
(a)  Water bills shall be rendered monthly and shall be included with the sewer, garbage and utility tax bill, but each charge shall be shown as a separate item on the bill. The water bill is due and payable when rendered. If payment is not received by the City in full prior to the due date of the customer's next monthly bill, the unpaid amount is to be considered in arrears and delinquent. If there is an arrearage amount due when the next monthly bill is printed, a late fee will be assessed at the rate of 11/2 percent per month on the arrearage amount, or $5.00, whichever amount is greater. The words "Second Notice" will appear on the monthly bill along with the late fee charges. When this occurs, the arrearage, late fee and current charges must be paid in full by the due date noted on the "second notice" bill or all utility services will be discontinued the day after the due date. 
(b)  The Director of Finance shall impose a shutoff fee in the sum of $30.00 on all water or reclaimed water service accounts which have been shut off pursuant to Subsection (a) of this Section. Where service has been disconnected, service will not resume until the total amount due, which includes the arrearage, late fee, current charges, the sum of $30.00 representing a shutoff fee, and a reconnect fee of $40.00 has been paid to the City. 
(c)  The Director of Finance is authorized to impose a delinquency charge of $30.00 on all water service accounts delinquent for over 20 calendar days and is hereby authorized to discontinue utility service to such delinquent accounts after notice. 
(d)  Voluntary shutoff or termination and all deposits, refunds of deposits, charges and conditions germane thereto can be arranged in advance with the Director of Finance or his or her staff. 
(e)  The Director of Finance is authorized to impose a service charge of $25.00 for each trip to perform a field service requested by the customer other than (a) to initiate or relocate service (covered by other charges), (b) for a customer-requested re-read (covered pursuant to Section 86-226), and (c) to turn off/turn on for leak repair (courtesy of the city). The customer will only be charged a fee if the reason for the call is related to the equipment located on the customer's property, from the meter to the customer's home or building. The customer must be notified in advance of this potential charge. 
(Code 1982, § 51.07; Ord. No. 719, § VII, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 736, § II, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 03-1083, § 2, 6-9-03; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-192. - Adjustment of bills. 
(a)  No abatements or deductions on water consumption charges based on meter readings will be allowed and refunded except for errors on the part of the City. When charges are based on inaccuracy in meter registration, or in the event of error by the City in making a charge, abatement or deduction will be considered if the abatement or adjustment is presented in writing within 30 days after the date of rendition of the disputed bill. 
(b)  Under no circumstances will abatements, allowances, deductions or refunds be made on water supply service accounts because of water used, lost or wasted through, carelessness, neglect or otherwise after the water has passed through the customer's meter, except for cases of excessive leakage where documentation is presented in writing within 30 days of the date of the bill verifying the correction of the excessive leakage. Documentation shall be in the form of a completed Adjustment Request Form with plumber receipts providing the location of leak or statement by the owner regarding repairs completed by the owner with receipts for materials. Upon detection of excessive water usage, the City will notify the owner of the excessive amount of water used and the City will allow the owner/tenant 72 hours to correct the matter. If the excessive water usage is not corrected within 72 hours, service will be interrupted. The water bill shall be decreased such that the charge for the excess gallons will equal the actual cost of production of the water. Actual cost of production as used herein is defined as the energy cost for the withdrawal from the well and the cost of chemical treatment. Adjustments to the water bill as provided herein shall be approved by the Public Works Director. 
(Code 1982, § 51.08; Ord. No. 03-1076, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 86-193. - Delinquent accounts. 
    All water service accounts which are delinquent shall result in the discontinuance of water, sewer and garbage service to the customer after a "second notice" bill has been sent to the customer as provided in sections 86-82(a) and 86-191. Where service has been disconnected, service will not resume until the total amount of the delinquent account, the shutoff fee, late fee, and reconnect fee has been paid to the City. 
(Code 1982, § 51.09; Ord. No. 719, § VIII, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 736, § III, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Secs. 86-194-86-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE CONTRACT 

Sec. 86-206. - Application for service. 
(a)  Generally; fee. All applications for utility service must be made in writing at the office of the Public Works Department and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $30.00 for initiation of utility services. The owner or authorized occupant of the premises proposed for utility service must sign the application for utility service. 
(b)  Application to constitute contract; withdrawal. The application for utility service becomes a binding contract upon both the owner or occupant and the City. Prior to the installation of the service connections, the owner or occupant may cancel or withdraw the application upon his written order, subject to the restrictions contained in this Article. 
(c)  Annexation agreement. If application is made for City water service to property located outside the City limits that is contiguous to the existing City limits, the owner of the property shall simultaneously annex the property into the City as a prerequisite to the provision of water service to the property. If application is made for City water service to property located outside the City limits that is not contiguous to the existing City limits, the owner of the property shall simultaneously execute an agreement to annex the property into the City when the property becomes contiguous to the City limits. 
(Code 1982, § 51.15; Ord. No. 719, § X, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Sec. 86-207. - Term; renewal. 
    All contracts for water supply service shall expire at the end of the next succeeding calendar month from the date of written application. All contracts shall be automatically renewed without notice from either party, from month to month, unless five days' notice is given in writing and all charges are paid in full. Payment of charges at any interval or period other than monthly shall not be construed as altering the period of the contract or its renewal under this Section. 
(Code 1982, § 51.16) 
Sec. 86-208. - Change in ownership of premises. 
(a)  Notification of City. In the event of any change in ownership or occupancy of any premises connected to the City water system, theCity shall be immediately notified of the change. Notice shall include the name of the new owner or occupant, if known. In the absence of application for service by the new owner or occupant, the use of the City service may, at the option of the City, be taken and construed as acceptance by the new owner or occupant of all contract obligations of the preceding owner or occupant with the City, including payment for unpaid services. 
(b)  Responsibility for payment of charges.
