(1)  If any owner fails to notify the City in writing of the change in ownership or occupancy of any premises for water supply service, the owner shall continue to be liable to the City for all rates and charges accrued and accruing for the service until either the termination of the contract period, at which time he may notify the City of his desire to cancel, or until the City has, of its own volition, canceled the contract with the owner. 
(2)  This Section shall not preclude the City from also demanding from the new owner or occupant the payment for all or any charges which shall, at the time of the demand, be unpaid or unsecured, without regard to whether the charges accrued prior or subsequent to the change in ownership or occupancy. Upon failure of the new owner to comply with this demand within 72 hours after written notice thereof, the City shall have the right to shut off the water supply and discontinue the service. 
(3)  In no case of change of ownership shall the preceding owner be released from any contractual obligations with the City until the expiration of the contract, except at the option of the City. 
(Code 1982, § 51.17) 
Sec. 86-209. - Commencement of service. 
(a)  When application for water supply service is made, the service, together with the charges and rates therefor, shall begin on the date of the completion of the service connection by the City, unless the owner states in writing in the application that the service connection shall be shut off immediately upon its installation. In that event, the connection shall then be shut off and shall thereafter be turned on by the City only upon written request of the owner; further, the charges and rates for water supply service shall commence on the date of turn-on in accordance with this Article as though the turn-on request had been an original application. 
(b)  Where there has been a change in ownership prior to a turn-on of the service connection, the new owner shall sign the application for water supply upon the regular form before actual turn-on, and make the necessary deposits, unless the previous owner has requested in writing that the service, including deposit, be transferred to the new owner. 
(Code 1982, § 51.18) 
Sec. 86-210. - Cancellation. 
    All contracts for City water service shall be subject to cancellation of service and discontinued by the City for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  If there has been any misrepresentation or concealment in the application as to the premises or fixtures to be furnished by the City water supply service or the use to be made of the service. 
(2)  If there has been any waste or excessive use of water through improper or defective pipes and fixtures or appliances, or in any other manner. 
(3)  If the customer has refused or neglected to make any advance payment, if such payment is required by the City, or refused or neglected to comply with any requirement of the City as to meter or service connection maintenance, alteration or renewal. 
(4)  If the water supply service has been used in connection with or for the benefit of any premises or purpose other than that stated in the application. 
(5)  If there has been any interference or tampering, whether by act of commission or omission, with the meter measuring the water supply, the seals of any meter, any meter box or vault, service pipes, valves or any seals thereon, the curb stop, any appliance of the City, or any appliance of the owner which was or is required by the City for controlling or regulating the water supply service. For the purpose of this Section, an interference or tampering with any appliance used in connection with or for controlling or regulating the water supply service to any premises shall be construed and taken to be the act of the owners or consumers using the water service at the premises. 
(6)  If written notification is provided to the Customer Service Division indicating that the consumer will not temporarily need the water supply system, and desires the service to be reconnected at a future date. 
(7)  If there has been a violation of any ordinance of the City related to use of the water supply service. 
(8)  If there has been a change in ownership or occupancy of the premises, but no application from the new owners or occupants has been made and approved by the City. 
(9)  If the contract has been in any way terminated by actions of the owner or occupant. 
(10)  If any owner or consumer refuses or neglects the payment of a bill, account or charge at a previous or current address within the City. 
(Code 1982, § 51.19) 
Secs. 86-211-86-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - METERS 

Sec. 86-221. - Metered service required. 
(a)  All City water customers shall be required to have metered service and such fire protection service as shall be required in this Article, and to pay for the amount of water consumed in accordance with rates established in Division 2 of this Article. No two or more consumers in separate buildings or dwellings shall be permitted to use the same meter, and no free water shall be furnished to any consumer. 
(b)  Where the owner of a building containing more than one store, dwelling or unit desires that separate meters be installed for each separate store, dwelling or unit, the additional meters shall be installed upon the payment in advance by the owner of the charge for additional meters, plus an additional water use or sewer use system development charge, if required. 
(Code 1982, § 51.25; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 2 (Att. A), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-222. - Temporary service. 
(a)  Contractors and other persons will be supplied with water for temporary use according to the regular service charge provided for water supply. They will be required to deposit $60.00 for each temporary service, plus the meter charge, if a meter has not been previously installed. The deposit shall be held by the City as a guarantee for payment for service and the return of all equipment in satisfactory condition to the City Public Works Department. A minimum charge of $30.00 will be made for connecting the meter, and a minimum charge of $30.00 will be made for disconnecting the meter as requested. Upon payment of all charges for water used, the City, through its duly authorized agent, is authorized to refund the amount of deposit made by the applicant for the service. 
(b)  Contractors or any other consumers desiring water for temporary use will not be allowed to use water from unmetered fire hydrants, except upon direct written approval from the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1982, § 51.26; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-223. - Use of water from fire hydrants; traveling meters. 
    Contractors desiring to take water from fire hydrants shall deposit a $1200.00 hydrant meter deposit. This meter shall be placed on a hydrant or the owner's vehicle for the exclusive use of the party making application. A backflow prevention device is included and will be issued with the hydrant meter. The meter shall be read monthly and/or at the time of job completion and the party billed for water consumed. Costs for any damages, loss or theft of the equipment will be withheld from the deposit to repair or replace the rented hydrant meter and backflow prevention device. 
(Code 1982, § 51.27; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-224. - Installation and repair. 
(a)  All meters shall be furnished and installed by the City upon the application of any owner or responsible party paying the water benefit charge, plus the required meter deposit and charge where applicable. All meters so furnished and installed shall remain the property of the City and subject to the absolute and exclusive control of the City. 
(b)  The owner shall provide and maintain a location for the meter which is acceptable to the City. When any meter has been placed, its position shall not be changed except by the City. If any owner makes or wishes to have made any alteration to his premises which, in the discretion of the Public Works Department, requires a change in the location or position of the meter or meter box, the change in location or position shall be made by the Public Works Department at the expense of the owner. 
(c)  Repairs, renewals and replacements of all water meters and meter boxes shall be made by the City, at its expense, where the repairs, renewals and replacements are due to ordinary wear and tear. 
(Code 1982, § 51.28) 
Sec. 86-225. - Meter reading. 
(a)  Water meters are to be read at regular intervals. If the meter is in good working order since the last reading, bills are rendered in accordance with that reading. The City reserves the right, for any reason deemed by it to be sufficient, to read any meter and render any bills therefor quarterly, bimonthly, monthly or at more frequent intervals. All readings of meters shall be taken, as near as practicable, on the same calendar day of the month. 
(b)  Customer service for seven days or less prior to a regularly scheduled consumption reading will be billed for with the next regular billing cycle, at which time the customer shall pay for total volume consumed, but not less than one monthly minimum charge. 
(c)  The quantity of water recorded by the meter shall be conclusive as to consumption on both the owner and the City, except when the meter is found to be inaccurate or inoperative. If it is determined that the meter has become inoperative, the City shall bill the user in an amount equal to the average consumption billed for in the three previous months. 
(Code 1982, § 51.29) 
Sec. 86-226. - Testing. 
(a)  All water meters shall be carefully tested before they are installed, and after their installation they shall be tested as frequently as circumstances warrant, but normally not less than once every six years. The City reserves the right to remove and test any meter at any time. If at any time a meter is found to be more than two percent inaccurate, the City shall substitute another meter of the same size in its place, either permanently or temporarily, or repair the inaccurate meter. In the event of such a test result, the City further reserves the right to make an adjustment to the last bill rendered, based on the last reading of the meter, in accordance with the results of the test. 
(b)  Should the owner at any time question the accuracy of the meter on his service, the City shall, upon his written application, accompanied by the payment of a fee of $50.00 for each meter in question, remove the meter and test it in the presence of the owner or his authorized agent if the test is desired by the owner. If the test shows the meter has been over-registering by more than two percent, the $50.00 paid shall be returned to the owner and a corrected bill based on an average reading shall be rendered to the customer for the billing period in question. The adjustment shall be reflected and become due and owing when the City submits its next regular bill to the customer. If the test shows the meter is not over-registering by more than two percent, the $50.00 paid by the owner shall be retained by the City. In addition, if the test shows that the meter has been under-registering by more than two percent, the $50.00 paid by the owner shall be retained by the City and the next bill rendered shall be based on the next current reading. 
(Code 1982, § 51.30; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-227. - Meter tampering, broken seal and illegal tap/connection. 
(a)  The owner or consumer, or his agent, at every location, shall pay to the City the sum of $250.00 the first time the seal on any water meter is found broken or removed. The City reserves the right to affix the seal at any time, and, upon the second occurrence, the owner or consumer, or his agent, at every location, shall pay to the City the sum of $500.00. The City may shut off the water supply and discontinue its service. The owner or consumer shall be given one week's written notice prior to the shut off. 
(b)  If the Director of Finance determines that the breakage or removal was a direct result of the intentional or negligent acts of the owner or consumer, the City shall shut off the water supply and discontinue its service until the owner or consumer is capable of providing the Director of Finance with adequate assurances that the breakage or removal will not be repeated. The City may charge an additional deposit prior to turning on the water if the Director of Finance determines that the deposit is necessary in order to ensure that breakage or removal will not be repeated. 
(Code 1982, § 51.31; Ord. No. 05-1168, § 1, 7-25-05; Ord. No. 09-1277, § 1, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 3 (Att. B), 10-30-17) 
Secs. 86-228-86-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INSTALLATION OF SERVICE EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 86-241. - Laying of service pipes. 
    The City shall lay the utility service pipe for water service to the property line of the contracting owner, provided the property lines correspond with lines dedicated and recorded in the subdivision plat. The City will not service lots or portions of lots that have not been subdivided in accordance with City requirements. 
(Code 1982, § 51.35) 
Sec. 86-242. - Size of service installation. 
(a)  If water service supplying improvements on property within the City is found to be insufficient because of additions to buildings or increases in the number of fixtures, the City will install the larger tap and service upon payment by the owner of the required connection charge for the increased size in service. No credit will be allowed for service in a place which is found to be insufficient in size. The owner will be required to install a gate valve on the service installation between the building and the meter box so that the utility supply may be interrupted by the owner or the City in case of a break or needed repair within the building or structure. 
(b)  The City reserves at all times the option to designate and prescribe the required size of the service connection, either upon the original connection installation or upon any renewal or replacement of the existing connection. Where the size required for existing service is other than that applied for by the owner or is other than the installation in existence, the City shall designate and prescribe the required size of service, and the owner shall be bound by that designation. 
(c)  For premises other than single-family residential units, the owner is responsible for informing the Public Works Department of the total number of gallons per minute at peak flow required to service his structure or development. 
(Code 1982, § 51.36) 
Sec. 86-243. - Replacement of defective or obsolete equipment. 
    The City may, from time to time, determine that certain water service apparatus or equipment previously approved by the City is defective or obsolete. If the City determines that the apparatus or equipment has become obsolete or defective, the owner shall install on his service connection a tank, checkvalve, cock or gate valve, pressure regulator or other appliances, apparatus or equipment of a design approved by the City. Following the required installation, the owner may not change, alter, substitute or make an addition to that installation. If the owner fails to comply with the requirements of the City, upon 30 days' written notice to the owner, the City may cancel its utility contract and discontinue service. 
(Code 1982, § 51.37) 
Secs. 86-244-86-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PRIVATE FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 42. 

Sec. 86-256. - Installation charge; annual charge. 
    The cost of installation of private fire protection service shall be paid by the owner at the actual cost of material and labor when installed by the City. This charge shall be payable prior to installation. In addition, there shall be an annual charge as stated in Section 86-188. 
(Code 1982, § 51.40) 
Sec. 86-257. - Conditions of service contract. 
    The City shall install fire line water connections up to the property line upon the signing by the owners of a contract containing the following conditions: 
(1)  This connection is to be used for fire protection only, and, because of the danger of pollution, shall have no connection with any other source of supply. 
(2)  The owner shall not draw any water through this connection for any purpose except for the extinguishment of fires or for the periodic test of the fire system, which shall be made in the presence of the Director of Public Works or his representatives, or by members of the Fire Department, who shall immediately notify the Director of Public Works. All valves or hose connections shall be sealed by the Public Works Department. 
(3)  Any authorized representative of the City shall have free access to the buildings from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, for the purpose of inspecting all equipment of the City. 
(4)  Upon violation by the owner of any of the provisions of this Section, the City may discontinue water supply service if the Public Works Department determines that a violation of this Section has in fact occurred. Prior to making such a determination, the Public Works Department shall conduct a hearing in order to make an accurate determination. The owner shall be given three days' notice prior to the hearing. 
(5)  The City reserves the right to shut off the supply in case of accident, alterations, extensions, connections or repairs of the system. The City agrees to give notice when feasible. 
(6)  The City does not guarantee specific pressures in the pipe or in the mains supplying water, and the City shall not be held liable for loss or damage to an owner or occupant for the inefficiency or failure of the supply of water for any cause whatever. 
(7)  When fire line valves or connections are used, the owner shall immediately notify the City, and the City shall forthwith reseal the used valves or connections. 
(Code 1982, § 51.41; Ord. No. 16-1422, § 23, 5-9-16) 
Secs. 86-258-86-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 86-266. - Cross connection control manual. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted a cross connection control program for the City, and in connection therewith, there is hereby adopted a cross connection control manual. One copy of the manual is on file in the office of the City Clerk for public use, inspection and examination. Compliance with the manual and the cross connection program contained therein is hereby required. 
(b)  The manual shall be periodically reviewed by the Public Works Department of the City to ensure compliance with applicable statutes, rules and regulations of the state and the United States. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(1), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-267. - Property access for cross connection control. 
    Duly authorized employees of the City bearing proper credentials and identification, with the consent of the owner/occupant, shall be permitted to enter any building, structure or property served by a connection to the public potable water supply system of the City for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems on such property. Consent to such access shall be obtained from a person 15 years of age or older in control thereof. If such consent is refused, the City may obtain an inspection warrant pursuant to F.S. § 933.21. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(2), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-268. - Discontinued service. 
    No water service connection shall be installed or maintained by the City unless the consumer is in compliance with the requirements of the cross connection control manual. Service of water to any premises shall be disconnected if a backflow prevention device is not installed, tested and maintained or if an unprotected cross connection exists on the premises. Notice shall be given to the consumer prior to discontinuing service except where, in the judgment of the Director of Public Works or his or her designee, the threat to public health is such that action must be taken immediately. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(3), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-269. - Protection of public potable water supply labeling. 
    The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public potable water supply shall be protected from present or future possible contamination as specified by the cross connection control manual and by federal, state and City building, plumbing and water regulations or codes. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled "water unsafe for drinking" or "nonpotable water" in a conspicuous manner. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(4), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-270. - Expenses and records. 
    The consumer shall bear all expenses of installing, testing and maintaining the protection devices required by the cross connection control manual to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis. Installation, testing and maintenance of protective devices shall be conducted by certified personnel approved by the City's Public Works Department. The consumer shall notify the City's Public Works Department at least 48 hours in advance, in writing, when the tests are to be undertaken so that a representative is present as a witness if the City so desires. The consumer shall keep records on his testing, maintenance and repair activities related to cross connection control and shall make these records available upon request. Copies of all testing, maintenance and repair records shall be sent to the City's Public Works Department immediately after the work is performed. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(5), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-271. - Supplemental codes and rules. 
    The cross connection control manual does not supersede the plumbing code of the City, the building code of the City, the state safe drinking water act, the federal safe drinking water acts and amendments, state drinking water regulations or any other City, state or federal statute, ordinance, rule or regulation applicable to public water supply systems, but is supplementary to them. When conflicts exist between the manual and such other codes and rules, the more restrictive provisions shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(6), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-272. - Public employees. 
    No provisions of this Division designating the duties of any City officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty for failure to perform such duty. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(8), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-273. - Areas embraced. 
    All territory within the City and the Counties of Seminole and Orange served by the City potable water system shall be governed by this Division to the extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(9), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 86-274. - Violation; liability. 
    Any person, customer or consumer found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this Division shall be punishable in accordance with Section 1-13. In addition, such person, customer or consumer shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this Division shall occur shall be deemed separate and additional violations. Any person, customer or consumer in violation of any of the provisions of this Division shall become liable to the City for any expense, loss or damage incurred by the City by reason of such violation, including attorneys' fees and court costs. In addition to any penalty provided by law for the violation of any of the provisions of this Division, the City may bring suit in the appropriate court to enjoin, restrain or otherwise prevent the violation of any of the provisions of this Division. 
(Ord. No. 756, § 1(7), 2-15-93) 
DIVISION 8. - RECLAIMED WATER USE 

Sec. 86-275. - Expansion. 
    The City's existing water and sewer and sewer utility facilities expanded to include all City reclaimed water facilities, and operational responsibilities. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 1, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-276. - Definitions. 
    Except where specific definitions are used within a specific Section of this Division for the purpose of that Section, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivation shall have the meanings provided herein. The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive: 
    Backflow prevention device shall mean either a dual check device composed of two single independently active check valves, as described in the American Water Works Association Standard C506-78(R83), and the American Society of Sanitary Engineering Standard 1024, and/or a reduced pressure principle device, as described in the American Water Works Association Standard C506-78(R83), and/or the American Society of Sanitary Engineering Standard 1013. 
    Charges are those monthly charges set by the City Commission from time to time for costs of providing service. 
    City refers to the City of Casselberry. 
    City Commission shall mean the City Commission of the City of Casselberry. 
    City Manager shall mean the City Manager of the City of Casselberry. 
    Cross-connection refers to any physical connection or arrangement which would allow the movement of contaminants or fluids between any nonpotable water system, such as the reclaimed water system, and a potable water system. 
    Customer shall mean any person receiving service or making application for service. 
    DEP shall refer to Florida Department of Environmental Protection, or its successor in function. 
    Department shall mean the Public Works Department of the City of Casselberry, or its successor department. 
    Developer shall mean any person, firm, association, syndicate, partnership, or corporation or any combination thereof, who are actually involved in the development of lands. 
    Development shall mean a material change thereon in the use or character of the land including, but not limited to, the substantial alteration on the land or the placement of any structure. 
    Director shall mean the Director of the Department of Public Works of the City of Casselberry, or successor in responsibility and title. 
    Discontinuation of service shall mean cessation of a service by physical separation from the City's service lines. 
    Irrigation system shall mean an in-ground system of pipes, appurtenances, and irrigation heads. 
    PE shall mean polyethylene. 
    Public eating, drinking, or bathing facility shall mean water fountains, picnic tables, swimming pools, spas, and food service facilities, including tables and beverage counters, that are open to, and provide service for, the public. 
    PVC shall mean polyvinyl chloride. 
    Reclaimed water reuse system shall mean those reclaimed watermains, storage pumps, valves and appurtenances, installed in public rights-of-way or utility easements, and are used to distribute reclaimed water. 
    Reclaimed water shall mean highly treated effluent from the City's Wastewater Treatment Plant, not for human consumption, supplied through the reclaimed water distribution system which meets or exceeds requirements for public access as set forth by DEP or its successor in function. 
    Service valve shall mean the manually operated valve which controls total reclaimed water flow to the customer's property located at the point where the reclaimed service line crosses the property line. 
    Tract shall mean all lots or portions thereof serviced by a specific connection, regardless of what portion of the lot or lots are being irrigated. 
    Well shall mean any excavation that is drilled, cored, bored, washed, driven, dug, jetted, or otherwise constructed when the intended use of such excavation is for the location, acquisition, development, or artificial recharge of groundwater. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 2, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-277. - Routing and construction. 
(a)  The City will establish a route and install a reclaimed water system based on the most cost effective method utilizing facilities in existence at the present time. All expansion will be based on as-needed basis cost factors, and on the number of applications received from residents wishing to connect to the reclaimed water system. 
(b)  Developers of properties which contain or abut such routes (planned or installed) shall install reclaimed water systems in an approved easement to be dedicated to the City upon completion. All reclaimed water systems shall be designed by a State-registered engineer and in accordance with the regulations of the City and the DEP. 
(c)  The City will exclusively operate and maintain the reclaimed water distribution system. A developer shall design and install reclaimed water irrigation systems to maintain common areas, model homes, or lots. All such reclaimed water irrigation systems shall be operated and maintained by the developer, property owner or homeowners association. No new potable water irrigation meters will be installed within an area serviced by a reclaimed water system except those used for irrigating vegetable gardens. Each potable water irrigation system shall be equipped with an approved cross-connection control device. 
(d)  All irrigation systems that are connected to reclaimed water lines shall be either inground systems or by the use of a special hose coupling, as approved by the Department, without overspray to adjacent properties, sidewalks, and streets. Standard style and hose bib connections to the reclaimed water system are prohibited. The use of reclaimed water is for irrigation purposes only. It is unlawful to make connections from the reclaimed water system to any building or other conflicting source of water supply. Inspections of all irrigation systems installed will be made by department personnel prior to connection to the reclaimed water system. 
(e)  No property shall be served by both a reclaimed water irrigation meter and another irrigation source (i.e. a potable water irrigation meter, irrigation well, either potable or nonpotable lake source), except for commercial properties with approved backflow preventers, where preapproved by the Public Works Director. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 3, 2-21-94; Ord. No. 17-1455, § I, 5-8-17) 
Sec. 86-278. - Promulgation and enforcement of reclaimed water service procedures and regulations. 
(a)  The City Manager shall have the power to promulgate procedures and regulations with respect to the following matters, which procedures and regulations shall become effective upon adoption of a resolution by the City Commission approving same. 
(1)  Application procedures, forms, requirements, and allowable uses other than irrigation. All uses must be in accordance with applicable DEP Regulations. 
(2)  Installation requirements including specification of acceptable materials, devices and regulations to prevent backflow or cross-connections with other systems. 
(3)  Procedures for enforcement of the ordinances and regulations pertaining to reclaimed water, including procedures for inspection of the customer's system. 
(4)  Procedures for the orderly expansion of the reclaimed water system. 
(5)  Procedures and regulations for the efficient operation of the reclaimed water system. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Director may, when necessary for the efficient operation of the reclaimed water system or for the health or safety of the general public or the customer, establish regulations regarding the following matters which regulations shall become effective at the time of promulgation without the need for City Commission approval, and regarding: 
(1)  The time(s) of day or night during which the reclaimed water may be used by customers. 
(2)  The time(s) or day(s) of the week during which the reclaimed water may be used by customers. 
(3)  The maximum rate of use of the reclaimed water. 
(c)  No persons shall construct, operate, maintain or allow to remain present on property owned or controlled by him, any device or system which is connected to or which controls a device or system connected to the City's reclaimed water system which is not in compliance with all provisions of DEP regulation and this Code. Reclaimed water shall not be directed, conveyed or piped into any residence or building used as a dwelling unit. The person who owns or controls the property upon which such a noncomplying device or system is found shall be liable to the City for all costs associated with the securing and/or removal of the noncomplying device. 
(d)  Any customer whose reclaimed water system is in violation of any City ordinance, regulation or procedure shall be subject to immediate discontinuance of reclaimed water service. The City shall disconnect reclaimed water service to any user because of tampering with any service, plumbing cross-connections with another water source, nonpayment of bills, or for any other reason which is deemed by the Department to be detrimental to the system. The City shall disconnect service until the condition is corrected and all related costs are paid to the City. Costs payable shall include delinquent billings, disconnection and reconnection charges, and payment for all damages to the system. Should service be turned on without authorization, the Department shall terminate the service and the violator shall be subject to the City's general penalty provision for code violations. Such termination of service shall not relieve any person of liability for civil actions or from prosecution for criminal or municipal ordinance violation. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 4, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-279. - Reclaimed water system charges and fees. 
(a)  Charges and fees. Reclaimed water system development charges and fees shall be established by the Commission in accordance with Section 86-186. 
(b)  As an incentive to customers within an area of planned reuse expansion, and to allow the City to make as many taps as possible during construction, all taps for three-quarter-inch or one-inch service will be made without charge, a reclaimed water meter will be furnished and installed without charge, and a backflow prevention device for the potable service will be installed at the cost of the device to those customers applying for service during the design period. All existing potable irrigation meter systems may be transferred to the reclaimed water system without any charges during the design period upon request of the homeowner. After construction has started, all normal fees will be charged. 
(c)  A customer whose service has been terminated may resume reclaimed water service after paying any past due amounts and a reconnection fee. 
(d)  Where service has been terminated for a violation of an ordinance or regulation regarding reclaimed water, such service shall not be reconnected until the Director receives adequate assurance and guarantees that such a violation will not recur. 
(e)  Fees for reclaimed water service shall be applied to the customer's monthly water bill. Payment shall be made in accordance with this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 5, 2-21-94; Ord. No. 14-1409, § 2, 9-22-14; Ord. No. 17-1469, § 2 (Att. A), 10-30-17) 
Sec. 86-280. - Public easement requirements. 
    No facilities will be installed under the provisions outlined herein nor accepted by the City for maintenance unless installed in a dedicated public right-of-way or dedicated public easement. New easements shall be adequately sized and subject to approval of the Director so as to accommodate construction and maintenance of any reclaimed system component. No obstruction shall be designed, planned, built, or otherwise created within the limits of any easement or right-of-way without written permission from the Director. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 6, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.1. - Ownership. 
    All reclaimed water facilities and appurtenances within dedicated public easements, when constructed or accepted by the City, shall become and remain the property of the City. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 7, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.2. - Right to refuse service. 
    The City shall have the right, at all times, to refuse to extend service should the use be detrimental to the system, inadequate supply of reclaimed water, lack of payment of required service charge or, for any other reason which, in the judgment of the Director, will cause a decrement to the system. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 8, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-208.3. - Service interruption. 
    The City reserves the right to temporarily discontinue service to any portion of, or the entire, reclaimed water system as deemed necessary by the Director. The Director shall have the authority to establish schedules to control the use of the water reuse system in order to reduce maximum pressure demands on the system and to regulate usage of reused water to balance with supply and storage availability. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 9, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.4. - Cross-connection control. 
    Prior to connecting a use to the reclaimed water system, the public potable water supply shall be protected by installation of an approved cross-connection control assembly in accordance with Article III, Division 7 of this Chapter. See also Section 86-279(c). 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 10, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.5. - Unauthorized work on reclaimed water system. 
(a)  No person, unless expressly authorized by the Director or his designee, shall tamper with, work on, or in any way alter or damage any City reclaimed water facility. Tampering or work shall include, but is not limited to, opening or closing of valves, or causing of any water to flow from the system. No unauthorized person shall cut into or make any connection with the system. The offending person shall be liable for the cost of all charges attributable to the correction of such tampering, including legal expenses, but payment of or correction of such damage shall not relieve the offending person from civil or criminal penalties the City or a court of law may impose for a violation of City ordinance. 
(b)  The service valve located between the reclaimed water customer's irrigation system and the City's distribution system may be operated by the customer only when his or her private valve, required on the customer's premises, requires repair. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 11, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.6. - Unauthorized use. 
    No person shall allow any reclaimed water to be consumed by any human being or animal. Additionally, no person shall use reclaimed water for any purpose which would knowingly endanger the health of any person, animal or plant. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 12, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.7. - Inspection. 
(a)  To insure that all provisions of the City ordinances, regulations and procedures are being observed, the City reserves the right and privilege of inspecting, removing and/or securing any or all devices installed by the customer which connect to or control the reclaimed water. 
(1)  Inspections without cause to believe that an ordinance or regulation is being violated shall be at reasonable times and shall not exceed a reasonable frequency. 
(2)  Inspections where there is reasonable cause to believe that an ordinance or regulation is being violated shall be at such times and shall occur with such frequency as is necessary to establish that an ordinance or regulation is or is not being violated. 
(b)  Each customer of reclaimed water shall, by application, give written consent to entry upon his or her premises, and thereby waives any other written notice for such inspection. Failure of the City to obtain such a written waiver shall not affect the right of the City to proceed pursuant to Subsection (a) of this Section. 
(c)  Refusing to permit an authorized City agent or employee to enter onto the premises for the purpose of inspecting the customer's reclaimed water system pursuant to this Section shall constitute a violation of this Section and shall be grounds for immediate discontinuance of the reclaimed water service by the City to the subject premises. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 13, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 86-280.8. - Adoption of Chapter 17-610 F.A.C. 
    The construction, maintenance and use of the reclaimed water system of the City shall be in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 17-610, Florida Administrative Code. In the event any of the provisions of Chapter 17-610 are more restrictive than the provisions of this Code, the applicable provisions of Chapter 17-610 F.A.C. shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 94-793, § 14, 2-21-94) 
ARTICLE IV. - WELLS 

Sec. 86-281. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Deep water well means a well 75 feet or more in depth. 
(Code 1982, § 93.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-282. - Violation of Article. 
    In addition to any other penalty provided for violation of the provisions of this Article, violations shall be held to be a nuisance, and the Director of Public Works is authorized to have any action taken that is necessary to abate the nuisance or to prevent the violation of any of the terms or provisions of this Article. The owner or occupant of the property has the right, within ten days of the Director of Public Works' decision, to appeal the decision to the City Commission. The action shall be stayed during the appeal procedure. 
(Code 1982, § 93.43) 
Sec. 86-283. - Registration; testing of water. 
    Citizens owning or operating water wells on property located within the City, except those used exclusively for exterior irrigation purposes, shall, within 30 days from December 21, 1970, accomplish the following: 
(1)  Register the location of all water wells used for human consumption by describing the wells as follows: 
a.  An exact legal description. 
b.  The exact street address. 
c.  The property ownership. 
d.  The date of the last water analysis. 
e.  The results of the last water analysis. 
f.  The date the water was last used for human consumption. 
(2)  Furnish test results every six months to the City. These results shall be furnished in accordance with standards established by the state board of health. 
(3)  Furnish test results every 30 days or at such other times as shall be required to ensure that the water produced is fit for human consumption, when prior tests show the water produced to be unfit for human consumption. 
(Code 1982, § 93.41) 
Sec. 86-284. - Wells to be covered or enclosed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, maintain or permit to be operated or maintained any well system within the City unless the well system is covered where required, or protected by an enclosure sufficient to prevent any person from falling into or entering the well system. Any covering or enclosure of any deep well system to be dug or abandoned must be approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1982, § 93.42) 
Secs. 86-285-86-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STORMWATER AND LAKE MANAGEMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Stormwater management, ULDR Pt. III, § 3-12.1 et seq. 

Sec. 86-301. - Creation of stormwater and lake management utility; statement of purpose. 
    There is hereby created and established in the City a stormwater and lake management utility. This utility shall be responsible for the City's stormwater and lake management program and shall have equal status with the other utility services provided by the City. This utility is intended to acquire, own, construct, equip, operate, maintain, and manage open drainageways, underground storm drains, equipment, and appurtenances necessary, useful, or convenient for the City's stormwater and lake management program, including maintenance, extension, and reconstruction of the present stormwater management system of the City; to minimize by suitable means the system's contribution to flooding; to minimize by suitable means the system's adverse effect on the water quality of streams and lakes, and to seek the cooperation of the State, Seminole County, and other municipalities in minimizing the effects of stormwaters and other sources of accelerated runoff on the water quality of surface and ground water in the City. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.10), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-302. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated unless the context requires otherwise: 
    Beneficiaries of drainage service. All real properties within the City which benefit by the provision of maintenance, operation, and improvement of the stormwater control system and lake management program and all newly developed real properties which will ultimately benefit from the overall City drainage system in both tangible and intangible benefits. Such benefits may include, but are not limited to, the provision of adequate systems of collection, conveyance, detention, retention, treatment, and release of stormwater, the reduction of hazard to property and life resulting from stormwater runoff, improvement in the general health and welfare through reduction of undesirable stormwater conditions and improvements to the water quality in the storm and surface water system and its receiving waters. 
    Contributors of drainage waters. All real properties located within the City. 
    Detention. The collection and temporary storage of stormwater with subsequent gradual release to surface water conveyances at a controlled rate. 
    Developed. Any property altered in appearance by removal of 40 percent or more of its vegetation, grading of the ground surface, or construction of a structure or impervious surface, except bona fide agricultural property in an Agricultural Zoning District. 
    Director. The Supervisor of the Stormwater and Lake Management Utility appointed or designated by the Public Works Director or the City Manager. 
    Equivalent residential unit (ERU). The average impervious area in square feet for all residential dwelling units in the City and the basic unit for the computation of stormwater and lake management fees as established by resolution of the City Commission. 
    Fee. Stormwater and lake management fees authorized herein and set by resolution of the City Commission. 
    Hydrologic response. The manner and means by which stormwater collects upon real property and is conveyed from real property, and which is a function dependent upon a number of interacting factors including, but not limited to, topography, vegetation, surfacial geologic conditions, antecedent soil moisture conditions and ground water conditions. The principal measure of the hydrologic system may be stated in terms of total runoff volume as a percentage of total precipitation which runs off, or in terms of the peak rate of flow generated in the event of a storm of given duration and intensity, or statistical interval of return (frequency). 
    Impervious areas. Those hard-surfaced areas which either prevent or retard the entry of water into the soil mantle as it entered under natural conditions prior to development, and/or cause water to run off from the surface in greater quantities or at an increased rate of flow from that present under natural conditions prior to development. Common impervious surfaces include, but are not limited to, rooftops, sidewalks, walkways, patio areas, driveways, parking lots, storage areas, and other surfaces which similarly impact the natural infiltration or runoff patterns which existed prior to development. 
    Multiple dwelling unit. Any building or facility consisting of more than one dwelling unit, each such unit consisting of one or more rooms with bathroom and kitchen facilities designed for occupancy by one family, regardless of whether more than one unit in such building or facility is served by a single water meter. 
    Nonresidential unit. Any building, structure, or facility used other than as a residential dwelling unit or single family unit. 
    Open drainageway. A natural or manmade open-cut which has the specific function of transmitting natural stream water or storm runoff water from a point of higher elevation to a point of lower elevation. Included are such conveyances as swales, ditches, canals, streams, and creeks. 
    Peak flow. The highest instantaneous rate of stormwater runoff measured or estimated in cubic feet of water per second. It is differentiated from total flow volume by the introduction of a unit of time measure during which the maximum rate of flow is measured, calculated, or estimated. 
    Residential dwelling unit. One or more rooms with bathroom and kitchen facilities designed for occupancy by one family such as houses, townhouses, apartment units, duplex units, condominiums, zero-lot-line units, mobile homes, et cetera, where the units are sold, deeded, or leased as single family units whether or not they have individual water meters. 
    Retention. The prevention of discharge of a given volume of stormwater runoff by complete onsite storage. Removal of the water caused only by percolation, evaporation, or evapotranspiration. 
    Single family unit (SFU). One or more rooms with bathroom and kitchen facilities intended for residential occupancy by one family including single family detached homes or detached townhouses or detached villas, all located on fee simple individual, distinct lots or land parcels where the units are sold and deeded as individual family parcels. Included are leased single family detached units meeting the above definition. 
    Stormwater control system. Any and all structures or appurtenances used in the control, treatment, or conveyance of stormwater. Common systems include, but are not limited to, retention and/or detention ponds, swales, inlets, pipes, gutters, filters, weirs, and other control structures. 
    Total flow. The accumulative volume of stormwater discharged from a property, basin, or watershed. The total flow is quantified in measures such as acre feet or cubic feet of water. 
    Utility. The Stormwater and Lake Management Utility. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.20), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-303. - Stormwater and lake management utility fee. 
(a)  A stormwater and lake management utility fee is hereby imposed upon all owners or occupants of each developed lot and parcel within the City for services and facilities provided by the stormwater and lake management utility program. For purposes of imposing the stormwater and lake management fee, all developed lots and parcels within the City are classified as residential or nonresidential. 
(b)  The City Manager, or his designee, is directed to prepare a list of developed lots and parcels within the City and assign a classification of residential or nonresidential. 
(c)  Stormwater and lake management fees shall apply to all developed properties within the City including those properties classified as nonprofit or tax exempt for ad valorem tax purposes. It shall apply to all developed properties owned or occupied by a governmental entity, including properties of the City. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.30), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-304. - Schedule of fees. 
    Stormwater and lake management utility fees shall be established by separate resolution of the City Commission in accordance with the following classifications: 
(1)  Residential. Each residential unit, regardless of residential class, shall be considered one equivalent residential unit (ERU) for billing purposes. The charge for one ERU shall be set at a flat rate by resolution of the City Commission. For residential accounts not individually metered for water, the account holder of the master water meter shall be billed the fee established for one ERU multiplied by the number of residential units. 
(2)  Nonresidential. Each nonresidential customer shall be charged a stormwater fee based on the number of ERUs computed by using the following formula: 
 No. of ERU =  Total Impervious Area of Each Parcel Average Impervious Area of 1.0 ERU  
A minimum value of 1.0 ERU shall be assigned to each nonresidential property. The impervious area of each parcel of property shall be determined by the Director or designee. The average impervious area of each 1.0 ERU for the City shall be set by resolution of the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.40), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-305. - Billing and collection of stormwater management utility fee. 
(a)  The frequency of billing is to be established by the City Manager based on an evaluation of the most efficient, effective, and equitable method of billing and collections available to the utility. The stormwater fee shall be billed at least annually by the City but no more than 12 times in one calendar year. 
(b)  All stormwater fees not paid within 30 days after the bill is due, or that are not under active appeal, shall be considered delinquent. All charges delinquent hereunder shall be subject to an interest charge at the State statutory rate. In the event such premises shall be served by the waterworks or sanitary sewer system of the City, the City may cease to serve such premises with those services until all delinquent utility fees and interest have been paid. 
(c)  The stormwater fee shall constitute a debt to the City for which the owner, tenant, and/or occupant shall be jointly and severally liable. The records of the City shall be kept open for the inspection by the owner, tenant, and/or occupant, and it shall be the responsibility of the owner, tenant, and occupant to ascertain that the prescribed fees are paid. 
(d)  Charges which remain unpaid for a period of 60 days may be reported to the City Commission. The City Commission may direct the City Attorney to file suit thereon and to collect all such unpaid fees and interest, including actual attorney's fees and costs of the litigation. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.50), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-306. - Credits for onsite stormwater management facilities. 
(a)  Credits for onsite stormwater management facilities shall be allowed and calculated as follows: 
(1)  In order to encourage a reduction in stormwater runoff and improvement of the quality of stormwater runoff, a credit against the stormwater and lake management utility fee is authorized for those developed properties which are addressed by a stormwater retention facility designed and constructed for the purpose of stormwater flow mitigation and pollution reduction if it meets defined standards. Detention facilities are not eligible for credit. 
(2)  A reduction in a stormwater fee may be allowed for a particular property only if the stormwater runoff from the property is served by a stormwater management facility that has been designed, constructed and is maintained properly for the purpose of stormwater flow mitigation and pollution reduction as measured against a defined standard established by the City. To be eligible for the stormwater retention credit, the facility must be constructed, owned, operated, and maintained by other than the City. The facility must also be on land owned by other parties than the City and upon which there are no drainage easements dedicated to the public for the general purposes of drainage retention, flow mitigation, or stormwater pollution abatement. 
(3)  For applicable properties, a credit may be calculated and the fee may be reduced based upon defined standards and a formula the City Commission may establish by resolution from time to time. No property shall have a verified right to the use of any particular formula or fee reduction other than that established by the City Commission by resolution. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to apply for the retention credit and supply all information needed to substantiate the credit under the defined standards, formula, and procedures established by the City. The City Manager or his designee shall be responsible for verifying or disallowing any fee reduction credit for a stormwater retention facility. 
(b)  In no event will the reduction in fee cause the fee to be paid to be less than 50 percent of the fee due without the credit. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.60), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-307. - Discretionary differential rates. 
    The City Commission may, by resolution, from time to time establish and implement differential rates and other rate credits to meet the specific needs of the citizens of the City considering, but not by way of limitation, the following: 
(1)  Age of property owner; 
(2)  Age of customer; 
(3)  Senior citizen status; 
(4)  Income impairment; 
(5)  Such other unusual customer circumstances as shall give rise to the need for the establishment and implementation of differential rates and/or other rate credits. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.80), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-308. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any customer or property owner who feels that the stormwater fee or credit for his or her property has been calculated or computed incorrectly may petition in writing to the City Manager or designee for a review of his or her account. 
(b)  If not satisfied with the determination of the City Manager or designee, the petitioner may ask for a hearing before the City Commission, whose decision shall be final. Any credits authorized by the appeal process shall only be effective against billings subsequent to the date of the appellate decision. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.80), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-309. - Stormwater utility fund. 
(a)  A stormwater and lake management utility trust fund is hereby established into which all revenues from users fees, grants, or other funding sources shall be deposited and from which all expenditures related to the City's stormwater and lake management utility shall be paid. 
(b)  Expenditures for activities that are not related to the City's stormwater and lake management program shall not be permitted from the fund except for a prorated charge for general City government services as is in effect for other City utility funds. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.90), 6-7-93) 
Sec. 86-310. - Flooding; liability. 
    Floods from stormwater runoff may occur which exceed the capacity of storm drainage facilities constructed, operated, or maintained by funds made available under this Article. This Article shall not be construed or interpreted to mean that property subject to the fees and charges established herein will always, or at any time, be free from stormwater flooding or flood damage, or that stormwater systems capable of handling all storm events can be cost effectively constructed, operated, or maintained. Nor shall this Article create any liability on the part of, or cause of action against, the City, or any official or employee thereof, for any flood damage or water quality problems that may result from such storms or the runoff thereof. Nor does this Article purport to reduce the need or the necessity for obtaining flood insurance by individual property owners. 
(Ord. No. 759, § I(52.100), 6-7-93) 
Secs. 86-311-86-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WATER CONSERVATION AND LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency management, Ch. 30; conservation of potable water supply, ULDR Part III, § 3-11.11. 

DIVISION 1. - WATER CONSERVATION GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-321. - Establishment; intent. 
    The public health, safety, convenience and welfare require the harmonious, orderly and progressive development of a water conservation program within the City. The establishment of a water conservation program is a vital step in the progress to ensure adequate water supply to the citizens of the City. The general welfare, health, safety and convenience of the community are directly affected by the use and availability of water. It is, therefore, in the interest of the public that a water conservation program be designed and developed in accordance with sound rules and proper minimum standards. The purpose and intent of this Article is as follows: 
(1)  To establish design standards for low flow fixtures that will encourage water conservation practices; and 
(2)  To establish procedures for the declaration of a water shortage emergency; and 
(3)  To provide regulations and rules to be enforced at all times and during a water shortage emergency. 
(4)  To protect the water resources of the City of Casselberry from the harmful effects of over utilization during periods of water shortage and allocate available water supplies equitably among its customers. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 01-1015, 4-23-01; Ord. No. 07-1220, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 86-322. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Article, the following terms shall have the meaning set forth in this Section. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the past and future tenses, and words in the singular shall include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and the word "may" is directive. 
    Certificate of occupancy shall mean that certificate issued by the Community Development Department, subsequent to final inspection, that all improvements have been completed in conformity with all applicable building and construction regulations in the City and the construction plans and specifications approved by the City. 
    District is the St. Johns River Water Management District. 
    Individual shall mean any person, firm, corporation or other legal entity, whether public or private. 
    Local enforcement agency shall mean the Code Enforcement Officers within the Community Development Department established and authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of applicable plumbing codes and amendments thereto. 
    New building refers to any proposed new construction for which plumbing fixtures are required and for which a valid building permit has not been issued, prior to the effective date of this Article [October 18, 1993]. 
    Person shall mean any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Water refers to water taken from any water source in the City, whether ground water or surface water, lakes, ponds, water percolating, standing, or flowing beneath the surface of the ground or from any public or private supply source. 
    Water resource shall mean any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground, including natural or artificial watercourses, lakes, ponds, or diffused surface water, and water percolating, standing, or flowing beneath the surface of the ground and reclaimed water. 
    Water shortage refers to the declaration by the St. Johns River Water Management District or the City Commissioners of Casselberry, Florida, that a water shortage exists. 
    Water shortage condition shall mean when sufficient water is not available to meet present or anticipated needs of persons using the water resource, or when conditions are such as to require temporary reduction in total water usage within a particular area to protect the water resource from serious harm. A water shortage condition may occur due to drought, contamination, damaged water facilities, natural disaster, or any other situation having an adverse effect on the water resource. 
    Well refers to any excavation that is drilled, cored, bored, washed, driven, dug, jetted or otherwise constructed when the intended use of such excavation is for the location, acquisition, development or artificial recharge of ground water. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 2, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01) 
Sec. 86-323. - Plumbing and low-flow fixtures. 
(a)  The escaping of water through defective plumbing or the allowing of water to escape through a system that is in disrepair is prohibited. 
(b)  All new buildings shall comply with the requirements set forth below, as a condition precedent to obtaining a certificate of occupancy. 
(1)  The water consumption of water closets operated by flush tanks shall not exceed an average of 1.6 gallons per flush cycle over a range of test pressures from 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. 
(2)  The water consumption of water closets operated by flush valves shall not exceed an average of 1.6 gallons per flush cycle over a range of test pressures from 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. The flush valve shall be adjusted according to the manufacturer's specifications. 
(3)  Urinal water consumption shall not exceed an average of 1.0 gallons per flush cycle over a range of test pressures from 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. 
(4)  Showerhead discharge rates shall not exceed 2.5 gallons of water per minute over a range of test pressures from 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. 
(5)  Kitchen sink faucet discharge rates shall not exceed 2.5 gallons of water per minute over a range of test pressures from 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. 
(6)  Residential lavatory sink faucet discharge rates shall not exceed 2.0 gallons of water per minute over a range of test pressures from 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. 
(7)  Nonresidential lavatory faucets shall be either self-closing or metering faucets as described below: 
a.  Self-closing faucets shall not exceed an average discharge rate of 0.5 gallons of water per minute between the pressures of 20 to 80 pounds per square inch. 
b.  Metering faucets shall be field adjustable and set so that the discharge quantity shall not exceed 0.5 gallons of water per cycle. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 3, 10-18-93) 
Sec. 86-324. - Water conservation standards. 
(a)  Master meters are prohibited for new residential, multi-family, or commercial complexes. 
(b)  Washing of impervious surfaces of houses, mobile homes, and buildings, shall utilize an automatic shutoff/self-canceling spray nozzle or low pressure cleaner. Excessive use of water for cleaning impervious surfaces is discouraged and runoff shall be directed as much as possible toward pervious areas. 
(c)  Noncommercial or private washing of motor vehicles, boats and trailers shall utilize an automatic shutoff/self-canceling spray nozzle or low volume pressure cleaner. Washing shall be on pervious surfaces during permitted watering periods only, or at a commercial water recycling automobile facility. Fund raising car washing projects are permitted at all times and must utilize an automatic shutoff/self-canceling spray nozzle and shall be conducted on pervious surfaces when possible. 
(d)  The use of water for the washing of sidewalks, driveways, and parking lots is prohibited. 
(e)  Filling or refilling of swimming pools is prohibited except as necessary during the construction process, including resurfacing of pools, and except as necessary to maintain the level of water a maximum of one inch above the pool's skimmer. 
(f)  Water to air heating and air conditioning systems and irrigation using reclaimed water (treated wastewater effluent) shall be exempt from provisions of this Article. 
(g)  New domestic and commercial landscape installations which have been planted less than 30 days may be irrigated at any time but only to the extent necessary for plant establishment. 
(h)  Excessive, wasteful and unnecessary water use is strongly discouraged under any circumstances and is specifically prohibited by the City under its minimum standards for water conservation. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 4, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 07-1220, § 3, 9-24-07) 
Cross reference- Swimming pools, Ch. 74. 
Sec. 86-325. - Application of Article. 
    The provisions of this Article shall apply within the City of Casselberry and to all persons using the water resources within the City boundaries whether from public or privately owned water utility systems, private wells, or private connection with surface water bodies. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 5, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01; Ord. No. 07-1220, § 4, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 86-326. - Implementation. 
    The provisions of this Article shall be implemented by adoption of a Resolution by the City Commission, declaring an emergency water shortage condition exists. Adoption of the Resolution shall be coordinated with the District and supported by appropriate findings which establish the existence of an emergency water shortage condition such as, for example: 
A declaration by the District that an emergency water shortage condition exists affecting Casselberry; or 
The City Commission, after consultation and advice from the Public Works Department, determines that an emergency water shortage condition exists and that appropriate measures be taken to alleviate the water shortage or other water condition requiring emergency action. 
(Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01) 
Sec. 86-327. - Water uses, surcharges and factors considered. 
    Upon determination that an emergency condition of water shortage exists, the City Commission may order the restriction or curtailment of the use of water resources to the extent necessary to alleviate the water shortage and may implement any or all of the following: 
(1)  Uses of water resources which may be restricted or curtailed include, but are not limited to the following: 
The sprinkling, watering, or irrigating of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, including the specification of certain days, hours or periods of time, as well as place limitations, when lawns and shrubbery may be watered; 
The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers, mobiles homes, campers, boats, railroad cars, airplanes, or any other type of mobile equipment; except bona fide business enterprise where vehicle washing is done; 
The washing of sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts, filling station aprons, porches, exterior of homes, apartments, office buildings or other outdoor hard-surface areas; 
The washing of any business or industrial equipment and machinery, except where required by public health; 
The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure using water without a recirculating system; 
The operation of swimming and wading pools not using a filter and recirculating system; and/or 
The escape of water through defective plumbing, when it is known or reasonably should be known that water is escaping through the system that is in disrepair. 
(2)  Businesses and industries may be restricted to the minimum amount of water necessary to conduct operations and may be required to curtail or prohibit any use of water including, but not limited to: 
a.  The use of water to serve a customer in a restaurant unless requested by a customer; 
b.  The use of water for the expansion of commercial nursery facilities; 
c.  The use of water from hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills, or any purpose other than fire-fighting; 
d.  The use of water to put new agricultural land into production; 
e.  The use of water by a golf course; and 
f.  The use of water for dust control. 
(3)  Extension of water service. Approval of Applications to the City owned utility to begin a new use or modify an existing use, requiring water service connections, meters, service lines, pipeline extensions, mains, or other water service facilities of any kind may be withheld, while the water shortage is in effect, subject to exceptions specified in Section 19-206. 
(4)  Surcharges may be imposed by the City Commission on customers of the City owned utility. 
(5)  The City Commission may consider the following factors in determining the measures to reduce water consumption: 
The severity of the drought; 
The specific measures required by the District and/or Public Works Department; 
The extent that the city owned potable or reclaimed utility is not supplying the demand of the service; 
The severity of saltwater intrusion; 
The availability of potable water; and 
Any other competent, relevant data. 
(Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01) 
Sec. 86-328. - Enforcement. 
    Each Police Officer of the City Police Department and City Code Enforcement Officer shall, in connection with his/her duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this Article. 
    The City Manager may designate other employees of the City of Casselberry to assist in the enforcement of this Article including, but not limited to, employees of the Public Works Department. Any designated employee shall have the duty and are hereby authorized to enforce the provisions of this Article and shall have the power to issue written warning notices, and/or citations as set for in Section 2-201 et seq. of the Code of Ordinances. A violation of this Article shall be subject to fines and penalties prescribed at Section 86-330 below. 
(Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01; Ord. No. 16-1442, § 24, 5-9-16) 
Sec. 86-329. - Exceptions. 
    The City Commission upon recommendation of the County Health Department, Public Works Department, or upon its own Motion, shall have the authority to permit a reasonable use of water in any case determined necessary to maintain adequate health and sanitation standards. 
    The City Manager or designee thereof shall have the authority to permit a reasonable use of water in any case determined necessary to preserve and protect property for aesthetic values of the community or for planned activities and sporting events. 
(1)  In making this determination, the City Manager or designee thereof shall consider the following: 
a.  Severity of drought; 
b.  Anticipated length of drought; 
c.  Availability of potable water; 
d.  Length of proposed exemption; and 
e.  Magnitude of proposed exemption (i.e. quantity of water) 
(2)  In granting an exemption pursuant to this Section, the City Manager or designee thereof may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this Article. 
(Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01) 
Sec. 86-330. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Article which shall be implemented by adoption of a Resolution shall, upon being found in violation, be punished as follows, and shall also be responsible for reimbursing the City of Casselberry any reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in correcting the violation. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day during which a violation, disobedience, omission, neglect or refusal shall continue: 
1 st Violation: Written Warning 2 nd Violation: $50.00 Fine 3 rd Violation: $150.00 Fine Subsequent Violations: Fine not to exceed $500.00*  
*Mandatory Court Appearance Required. 
    Violators may only receive one written warning. The City, in addition to the civil sanctions contained herein, may take any other appropriate legal action, including but not limited to emergency injunctive action, to enforce the provisions of this Article. If a person chooses to contest the citation pursuant to Section 2-211 and is unsuccessful in such contest, the person shall reimburse the City of Casselberry for its attorney's fees and costs incurred in prosecuting the violator before any court of competent jurisdiction. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day during which a violation, disobedience, omission, neglect or refusal shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01) 
Sec. 86-331. - Water use constitutes acceptance of provisions of Article. 
    The acceptance of water service from the City of Casselberry and withdrawal from any water resource servicing property located within the City of Casselberry shall be in itself the acceptance of the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 01-1015, § 1, 4-23-01) 
DIVISION 2. - LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION 

Sec. 86-332. - Legislative intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent and purpose of this division to implement provisions, processes and procedures that promote water conservation through the more efficient use of landscape irrigation within the City of Casselberry. 
(Ord. No. 07-1220, § 5, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 86-333. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division and the administrative actions of the City, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. The following words shall be defined as follows: 
    Address means the house number of a physical location of a specific property. This includes "rural route" numbers but excludes post office box numbers. If a lot number in a mobile home park or similar community is used by the U.S. Postal Service to determine a delivery location, the lot number shall be the property's address. An "even numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 or the letters A-M. An "odd numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 or the letters N-Z. 
    District means the St. Johns River Water Management District. 
    Landscape irrigation means the outside watering of plants in a landscape such as shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens and other such flora that are situated in such diverse locations as residential areas, public, commercial, and industrial establishments, and public medians and rights-of-way. "Landscape irrigation" does not include agricultural crops, nursery plants, cemeteries, golf course greens, tees, fairways, primary roughs, and vegetation associated with recreational areas such as, playgrounds, and football, baseball and soccer fields. 
    Nonresidential landscape irrigation means the irrigation of landscape not included within the definition of "residential landscape irrigation," such as that associated with public, commercial and industrial property, including commercial or transient housing units, hotel and motel units, and public medians and rights-of-way. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Residential landscape irrigation means the irrigation of landscape associated with any housing unit having sanitary and kitchen facilities designed to accommodate one or more residents, including multiple housing units and mobile homes. 
(Ord. No. 07-1220, § 5, 9-24-07; Ord. No. 10-1333, § 1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 86-334. - Irrigation schedules. 
(1)  When Daylight Savings Time is in effect, landscape irrigation shall occur only in accordance with the following irrigation schedule: 
(a)  Residential landscape irrigation at odd numbered addresses or no addresses may only occur on Wednesdays and Saturdays and must not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on the days specified. 
(b)  Residential landscape irrigation at even numbered addresses may only occur on Thursdays and Sundays and must not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on the days specified. 
(c)  Nonresidential landscape irrigation may occur only on Tuesday and Friday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
(d)  No more than 3/4 inch of water may be applied per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs, and in no event shall irrigation occur for more than one hour per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs. 
(2)  When Eastern Standard Time is in effect, landscape irrigation shall occur only in accordance with the following irrigation schedule: 
(a)  Residential landscape irrigation at odd numbered addresses or no address may occur only on Saturday and must not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and
